PETITION.TITLE: Medicare
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
We have become the innocent victims of your Government's Medicare scheme.
We are forced to pay 1 per cent of our wages only to receive less per capita benefits than the people of other States.

Without canvassing the rights or wrongs of the dispute between the Federal Government and the State of Queensland the fact is that because of it over one million Queenslanders, who contribute to health funds, are being blatantly discriminated against compared with people in the rest of Australia.
Because of the dispute over the introduction of Medicare, Queensland public hospital bed charges are $120 per day compared with $80 per day in the other States. This is grossly unfair.
As it was the Federal Government which decided to introduce Medicare, we believe it is their responsibility to take action allowing health funds' rates in Queensland to be kept at reasonable levels.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should use its influence with Government so as to avoid the discrimination (of $ 40 per day) against insured Queenslanders.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Disarmament
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That your petitioners are concerned about foreign owned military bases on Australian territory and the entry into Australian waters and territory of foreign warships and aircraft carrying nuclear weaponry. And that the Australian Government should take an active and constructive role in the promotion of a nuclear-free world. Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should:
1. Promote the expression of Australian sovereignty by legislating to bring foreign military bases on Australian territory under the control of the Australian Government.

2. Make it compulsory that the disclosure of weaponry carried by foreign warships and aircraft be given in confidence to the Australian Government prior to a request for entry. And that foreign warships and aircraft that carry nuclear weaponry be banned from Australian waters and territory.
3. Legislate for the cessation of all uranium mining in Australia and its subsequent export.

4. Urge the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to pose to the Governments of the United States and the Soviet Union that both countries agree to immediately halt the testing, production and further deployment of all nuclear weapons, missiles and delivery systems in a way that can be checked and verified by both sides.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

On 30 November 1983 the Australian Secret Intelligence Service-ASIS-conducted an exercise at the Sheraton Hotel in Melbourne which was the subject of Mr Justice Hope's report tabled in the Senate on 29 February 1984. As a result of the incident at the Sheraton Hotel, the Victorian Police, together with the Victorian Director of Public Prosecutions, are considering prosecuting certain persons for breaches of the criminal law in Victoria. On the advice of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden), confirmed by Mr Justice Hope, the Government considers that there are very strong grounds for believing that the disclosure of the names of some, if not all, of these persons in the ordinary course of criminal proceedings, would be prejudicial to the national or international security of Australia. In these circumstances, there has been detailed consultation between Commonwealth and Victorian Ministers and officials with a view to meeting the concerns of both governments by means of State legislation specifically empowering Victorian courts, in appropriate circumstances, to make orders for confidentiality upon grounds of prejudice to the national or international security of Australia, or, in addition to that, to the safety of persons involved in the litigation or other persons. Complementary Commonwealth legislation is necessary to give effect to such orders outside Victoria.

On 29 February 1984, the Victorian Government introduced into State Parliament the Criminal Proceedings Bill 1984 to specifically empower the courts of that State to make certain orders for confidentiality in relation to criminal proceedings arising out of the Sheraton Hotel incident. The Bill now before the Senate represents the Commonwealth's part of the arrangement and complements that Victorian Bill. This Bill amends the Judiciary Act 1903 by inserting into that Act a new Part under which any such orders for confidentiality made by the criminal courts of Victoria in relation to those criminal proceedings are applied, by force of Commonwealth law, throughout Australia. Under the Bill, the Federal Court of Australia is, in effect, given power to punish contravention of these confidentiality orders in the same way as contempt of court is punished.

The new Part is inserted by clause 3 of the Bill. Proposed section 46 provides that the Part is to apply only to orders made by Victorian courts in criminal proceedings arising out of the Sheraton Hotel incident. Proposed sub-section 49 (1) makes it clear, furthermore, that it applies only to orders made on grounds of necessity or desirability 'in the interests of the national or international security of Australia or in the interests of the physical safety of the accused, of a witness or of any other person'. The particular types of confidentiality orders to be applied by the Part are spelt out in proposed sub-section 49 (3) as follows: Orders for the whole or part of the proceedings to take place in a closed hearing; orders excluding a person or class of persons from the whole or part of the proceedings; orders prohibiting or restricting disclosure of information respecting the whole or part of the proceedings; orders prohibiting or restricting publication of a report relating to the whole or part of the proceedings; orders ensuring that, without the approval of the court, no person has access-before, during or after the hearing-to any document used in, or court records of, the proceedings; and orders combining any two or more of the foregoing.

The scheme of these amendments can be summarised as follows: If a Victorian court should make, under the specific power to be conferred by the Victorian Criminal Proceedings Act 1984, an order to which the present Bill applies, that order would by force of proposed sub-section 49 (2), take effect throughout Australia and beyond, applying to all natural persons, whether Australian citizens or Australian residents or not, and all bodies corporate as provided in proposed section 47. Any contravention of the order-for example, by someone in New South Wales-would be punishable by the Federal Court of Australia under proposed sub-section 49 (4) as if it were a contempt of that court. These amendments have been introduced to meet the particular issues of concern to the Commonwealth and Victorian governments arising out of the Sheraton Hotel incident and it is not proposed to give them general or permanent force. Thus the Bill contains, in proposed section 51, a sunset clause limiting the application of the Bill to orders made within two years after the commencement of the Victorian legislation. This limitation expressely recognises the exceptional nature of the amendments and the particular circumstances which they are designed to meet. In addition, the Bill contains, in proposed section 50, a specific provision to ensure public accountability in regard to the operation of the Part. It requires the Attorney-General to make an annual report to Parliament on the number of proceedings known to him in which relevant confidentiality orders were made, and the outcome of those proceedings. Such annual reports are to be made in terms that would not breach the confidentiality orders involved.

I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that provisions of the type proposed in the present Bill and the Victorian legislation it complements are not entirely novel. There are precedent provisions for confidentiality orders in the United Kingdom Official Secrets Act 1920 and also in existing Australian legislation. For example, section 85B of the Crimes Act 1914 gives judges and magistrates in Federal jurisdiction a power to make orders similar to those referred to in proposed section 49 if satisfied that such an order is expedient in the interest of the defence of the Commonwealth. Again section 50 of the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976 gives that Court power, at any time during or after the hearing of a proceeding, to make such orders forbidding or restricting the publication of evidence or the name of a party or witness, as appear to the Court necessary in order to prevent prejudice to the administration of justice or the security of the Commonwealth.

The amendments contained in this Bill will enable the criminal law of Victoria to take its due course, but at the same time will provide a procedure designed to ensure that the national or international security of Australia, or the physical safety of persons, is not prejudiced in the process. No significant financial impact is expected. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

There were adequate provisions in the income tax law that would have prevented the company getting deductions under such schemes.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commissioner of Taxation should have looked thoroughly at the trust deed. He should have been satisfied that there was adequate communication of the rights, benefits and privileges to employees. He did not do so. He had an opportunity, I submit, under section 23F to tax the scheme in the early stages for non compliance. Initially, or at the time those superannuation schemes were executed, he did not satisfy himself as to the bona fides of the schemes. I challenge the Minister to bring forward the evidence that the present provisions are not working, that the Taxation Office has discharged its duties fully rather than in a negligent manner, as I put forward.

Those schemes that have slipped through are, I submit, the responsibility of the Commissioner of Taxation for not doing his job. What will happen under this proposed legislation? I think it is regrettable when that retrospective legislation is used so blatantly in these cases that it not only catches one or two guilty offenders but also picks up a host of innocent people. Because of the recession many businesses have had a downturn in their activity; some have had to be wound up prematurely, and some of their superannuation schemes will now be caught under this Bill.

I think the Bill is a wide-ranging one and covers a whole range of issues. I admit that some of these issues have been picked up from initiatives taken by the former Treasurer, John Howard. I refer to measures on leverage leasing. It is significant that while New South Wales Premier Neville Wran attacked John Howard because he felt some of the provisions in that legislation could affect the financing arrangements of one of his New South Wales power stations, now that the Federal Labor Government has picked up this leverage leasing issue and is bringing it forward as a Bill there is no such criticism coming from Neville Wran. Have we any evidence that this is an identical Bill to the leverage leasing legislation proposed by John Howard? Some private contractors in Victoria who are working for instrumentalities whose income is exempt from tax could be unfairly treated as a result of this legislation. I think there are several other abhorrent features in relation to this Bill. I mention bonuses and other amounts received in respect of certain term life assurance policies and so -called tax avoidance policies, in relation to employees' superannuation funds.

Never before in this country have we seen a government so paranoid about tax avoidance that it is prepared to steal-I have to use that word because retrospective legislation of this kind has that implication-from those people who have been prepared to operate within the law. Never before has this country seen a government more obsessed with superannuation schemes-an obsession that has led the Government to attack all such schemes except one; that is, the scheme operating for its own members.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you talking about?

—Senator Button knows what I am talking about. I am talking about the Government superannuation scheme. Why have I prefaced my comments in this way? I have done so because this Government now wishes to take away from people who have been prepared to operate within the law. In other words, the Government is stealing from genuine taxpayers. No one in this chamber wants to condone blatant tax evasion schemes. I am referring to the devious methods used by this Government through iniquitous means of retrospectivity in legislation such as that which is before this chamber at present. The current legislation seeks to insert a new provision into the Income Tax Act; a new section that permits stealing by retrospectivity. As I said, no honourable senator condones tax avoidance. But essentially evaders steal from the community. They steal, as I said, from those who are prepared to operate within the law. If there is a loophole in the law-there have been many examples over the years-I submit that it is only proper that the matter be corrected promptly in the interests of all those who are trying to ensure justice and equity for all. However, to make the correction of taxation loopholes retrospective is to operate at the same level as those who openly defy the law and bring themselves down to the same level. Retrospectivity cannot be justified by any amount of dollars and cents as this Government has attempted to do in the past. For reasons of justice and fairness no legislation should have retrospective aspects in it.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill seeks to insert new section 26AFA after section 26AF of the Income Tax Assessment Act. One can really see the rationale for seeking such an insertion and sympathise with the victims of such schemes that section 26AFA seeks to prevent from proliferating but not retrospectively. Section 26AFA, as proposed, seeks to prevent the operation of what is undoubtedly a case of using a loophole within the tax laws by a few operators. I think this is the distinction that the Government has failed to make. Of all the schemes, those section 23F funds-if the Commissioner has done his job continuously throughout the life of those funds-should be the least of all superannuation-type funds allowed in the Income Tax Act to be subject to any tax avoiding scheme. The implication of this is that the Commissioner is throwing back the matter onto the Parliament and saying: 'You haven't done your job in the past by adequate legislation'. I am submitting that the Commissioner has not done his job by administering the Act, examining the details of the trust deed, looking at the communications to the members, examining the loan backs-the relationship between superannuation accounts and company accounts-and examining the situation where maximum benefits have been paid to diminishing numbers of employees along the line. Had all this been done this legislation would never have had to be contemplated.

As I said, I agree that the operation of such funds and such practices of a blatant kind should be halted and, if need be, declared illegal. But they must be declared illegal from the date of the announcement of the Government's proposed legislative change. Proposed new section 26AFA provides that in a year of income and on or after 1 July 1977, this legislation seeks to recoup-not recoup but really steal because it is retrospective-funds in the form of tax on moneys which have hitherto not been subject to law providing all the conditions have been complied with. In regard to section 23F funds-the employee funds to which I have referred-if the benefit is excessive or one to which the taxpayer has no entitlement and the Commissioner is satisfied that the taxpayer has received the benefit because he or she was or had been a member of the fund, a dependant of the fund or an associated person of the fund, the amount or value of the benefit is included in the assessable income of the taxpayer. I can see a situation where an amount is to be included in taxable income under this proposed new section 26AFA but section 26 (d) of the original Act, which includes only 5 per cent as assessable income, will apply and the whole of the benefit will then be subject to tax. We are retrospectively changing the law which previously permitted 5 per cent to include the whole amount. What an iniquitous piece of legislation we are asked to pass today.

If this Bill were not such a blatant and artificial piece of retrospectivity and because it is a Budget Bill the Government might have expected the Opposition to go along with it. However, because of the intense nature of this retrospectivity and because it will be so damaging to some innocent people who abided by the law, some of us on this side of the chamber reject this part of the Bill. I submit that it is in essence iniquitous since it seeks to make taxable moneys which are clearly included under section 26 (d) of the original Act subject now to a far higher rate of taxation than would apply under this legislation.

It would also appear that notwithstanding the provisions of proposed new section 26AFA, a certain degree of discretion in the application of that section can be exercised by the Commissioner. I say that if the Government wants to make this distinction between artificial and genuine kinds of winding up, let it place a framework within the legislation to give the Commissioner guidelines and to give the trustees and the directors of the companies which set up these funds some understanding of how the Commissioner will exercise his discretion. In the past the Commissioner has been given a wide range of guidelines in exercising discretion in other areas. Because of the uncertainty the appropriate time to introduce those guidelines into the Parliament is now, in this Bill, and not in two or three years' time. Proposed new section 26AFA will produce an anomaly in the rate of taxation. It should be subject to much closer scrutiny and be seen for what it is-an unjustifiable taxation impost of an order not applicable until the present time.

Proposed new section 26AFA contains aspects of retrospectivity in the creation of tax liabilities where none existed before or where they existed in a limited kind under section 26 (d). This must be seen as a matter of urgency. People must be able to act in accordance with the law, even those few who may be exploiting the law. It is the job of the Commissioner of Taxation to plug the loopholes but not to plug them retrospectively. Retrospectivity pervades clause 6 of this legislation.

I want to comment on section 26AH which will make bonuses from life assurance policies assessable income for income tax purposes. It will operate in respect of life assurance policies which are issued after 27 August 1982 and will apply to amounts received under the policy during either the first four or 10 years of the policy, depending on its commencement date.

While a number of exclusions to the operation of this clause are proposed, we will now find a 10-year taxing period on new policies taken out after December last year when the Bill was introduced into Parliament. This is a new tax being imposed on people in this country by this high spending, high deficit Labor Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elstob Sen R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will comment briefly on the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1983. Last night Senator Cook went through the whole of the Bill and explained how working class people have been deprived of their just rights. I will reiterate what he said because I am sick of the Opposition's crocodile tears over this Bill. In this case we are applying retrospectivity to people who have been defrauding those who should have got pensions out of these schemes. Firms that showed a profit put the money into funds and in the normal course of events taxation was not paid on it.

SPEECH.PARA: I will tell honourable senators what has happened. Some firms in this country told their employees that they would set up a non-contributory pension scheme. I and many people in the trade union movement have ample evidence of this. If anyone wants to investigate the documents thoroughly the management of the company says to its employees: 'This person is a trouble maker; he is a communist and we have to get him out of the industry'. This actually happens. Senator Watson may laugh but I can assure him that this is quite true. The relevant documents are displayed in the head office. Only top management sees them. They are on display but to only selected people. Employees of the industry are told that management will do the right thing by them, that it will look after their interests and that it will provide a non-contributory pension scheme . But part of the scheme is set out in small print and the employees do not know about it. These schemes, although they vary, usually operate for 10 or 15 years or to the retirement age of 65 years for men and 60 for women. Employees who retire one day early do not receive a penny. People have been led to believe that if they provide good service to their industry they will receive help when they retire. I have heard that some people had expected to receive anything from $30,000 to $90,000 or $100,000. But what has happened? A week or so before their nominated date for retirement they have been sacked, encouraged to retire early, or some redundancy provision has been brought into force. They have been talked into getting out of the scheme early and consequently have received nothing.

These schemes have been designed for top management, the managing directors and accountants. They ensure that they are in the scheme until they are due to retire. Usually only two or three people get the full benefit which, when the scheme is wound up, sometimes amounts to $2m or $3m. Honourable senators should not forget that this money is profit and tax has not been paid on it. Tax should have been paid. Money also has been lent to the company or to subsidiary companies. Evidence reveals that this money has been lent at an interest rate of 3 1/2 per cent. It is almost a giveaway. Management draws on the fund and also get all sorts of perks such as cars. However, the working people get nothing out of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't know what you are talking about.

—I do know what I am talking about. This is what is going on. There are other schemes into which workers contribute. As a result of various adjustments contributors to such a scheme finish up getting what they put into it plus about 3 1/2 per cent. There is evidence to show that.

SPEECH.PARA: Private retirement schemes in this country have been badly organised. There is no legislation to cover money invested in these schemes. As I have said, money paid into these private schemes is lent out at a ridiculously low rate of interest. No proper provision is made by governments. Over the many years that the Liberal Party of Australia has been in office it has never seen fit to introduce legislation to cover the proper investment of money in these schemes. There are many loopholes and it will certainly be necessary to look at them. Why should not people involved in these schemes who have defrauded the whole community be liable to pay tax retrospectively? Such people should be made to pay back to the community what they have stolen from the community.

These schemes are not totally illegal. There is no way that working people can get the money that they should have got. The schemes are legally drawn up so that people who retire early cannot get the money to which they are entitled. As I have said, the schemes have been designed for top management and there is no way that an ordinary worker can get any benefit from those funds.

Honourable senators opposite are saying how unfair retrospective legislation is . Yet people who have contrived these schemes, whether they be bottom of the harbour schemes or the scheme about retirement allowances, have robbed the general community. They have also robbed the people in the work force who thought they were to get some benefit on their retirement. Businesses such as these have an unfair advantage over the great majority of businesses and people in this country who are honest. That is the difference-the very big difference. How can an honest business hope to operate and compete against a business which is so dishonest that it pays virtually no taxation or very little? Retrospective legislation is necessary.

The Hawke Labor Government is being successful in its attempts to bring about conciliation between management and labour. Yet how can we do this while schemes exist in which working people have no faith? As a result some doubt surrounds all schemes, as to whether they are legal or illegal. Legislation has to be put into place to stop all that. People who have deliberately gone out of their way to rob other people in this country who have taken their coats off and contributed to the work force should be punished. Why should not businesses which have operated honestly and decently be protected? An important aspect of the legislation is retrospectivity. There has to be retrospectivity. I do not like retrospective laws any more than anybody else, but I believe that they are necessary as far as taxation is concerned because this problem has got out of hand. I think that retrospective legislation has to be applied to people who have deliberately tried to increase the benefits to themselves by the use of such schemes. I believe that they have to be taught a lesson. I have no sympathy for such people.

Taxation in this country is far too high. There are several reasons for that. In the past there has been bad management by Liberal governments. There is no doubt about that. But while people and businesses are allowed to be dishonest, are knowingly dishonest, how can we reduce taxation for the decent companies and the working people of this country? That is what we have to consider. For far too long all of us have had to pay for these thieves and rogues. I am sick of it . I am certain that the Australian population is sick of it. It is about time that we stood up and were counted. The only way to stop these practices is to bring in retrospective legislation for people who do not pay their correct taxation. It is despicable to think that such people are defrauding people who have worked in industries sometimes for 20 or 30 years.

This legislation goes back only to 1977. I have it on good authority that the schemes go back far longer than that. It was only in 1977 when these schemes started to mature that they came to the fore. I have no hesitation in saying that these people should be punished. These dishonest people have deprived and upset working class people whom I know have planned over many years to do certain things because they thought they would get a certain amount of money when they retired, yet finished up not getting one cent. I think that is despicable. That is no way to go about trying to create a system whereby we can have some conciliation between management and labour. There has to be complete trust. A law has to be seen to be just, otherwise nobody trusts it. I think it is the same with all of these schemes.

We can have a great country. There can be conciliation. We can have a better way of life. But not while some people in our community deliberately defraud, rob and plunder and treat other people like dirt. That is what they have been doing. I have no hesitation in supporting this Bill, which is designed to bring down retrospective legislation to recover the taxes that these people should have paid in the first place. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1983, which has been brought down by the Government. It is to be welcomed by the Parliament as a first attempt by the Government to address itself to the problems of tax avoidance which, of course, it has failed to do in its first 12 months in office. In fact, this is the first piece of legislation which touches the area of tax avoidance. It is also significant to note that this piece of legislation is based most substantially on decisions that were already taken by the former Fraser Government and announced by the former Treasurer, Mr Howard.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill falls into two parts. Firstly, there are those areas which cover natural disasters and the exemption of tax for the first two weeks of receipt of unemployment benefit and there is the question of leverage leasing. I will return to that matter a little later. The other areas are unexceptionable and the Opposition accepts them. Secondly, there are the areas in respect of short term life assurance policies and the question which has been so vigorously debated from this side of the House, by Senator Watson most lately, in respect of the superannuation funds and the retrospectivity which applies to them. I will also turn to those matters a little later.

To return for the moment to the question of leverage leasing, I note that the terminology of the Bill includes leased items which are described as being wholly and exclusively used for a particular purpose. In respect of that I take it that a small contractor, for instance, who is working with the Government, perhaps by contract with various government agencies which are tax exempt, might find that in fact he is caught by this general provision within the proposed legislation. We on this side of the House fully understand the reasoning behind the leverage leasing proposals, but we seek the assurance of the Government as to whether or not contractors who are operating exclusively on government contracts of one kind or another, who have leased equipment and who, in the course of their ordinary duties, come into contact day by day with tax exempt government bodies will be caught by this legislation. It would be a terrible shame if that were so. My colleague Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle will be addressing herself to that part when we come to debate the Bill at the Committee stage.

I turn now to the superannuation funds and the retrospectivity which has been raised very substantially from this side. First, I outline a little of the history of the taxation law in respect of superannuation funds over the years. I can well remember the Menzies Government's actions in 1964 to restrict tax avoidance through superannuation funds by introducing the guidelines which are now part and parcel of the way in which superannuation funds are established and put into practice by the Australian Taxation Office. In fact, it was that step which set the tone for the great thrust against tax avoidance which has followed since then on the part of various Liberal governments. The main features of the 1964 arrangements, as promulgated by guidelines sent out to practitioners and the general public by the Commissioner of Taxation at the time, set out clearly certain conditions under which superannuation funds should organise their affairs. Indeed, many of the features of section 23F of the legislation were brought into being as a result of amending legislation at that time, and these guidelines which I am about to mention flowed from that.

I well recall that in those guidelines there were requirements for superannuation fund trustees to advise employees of their benefits, advise them of the security of their benefits, certainly bring to their attention the rules of the fund and to indicate generally that the benefits would be available in the event of their contributing or, if it were a non-contributory fund, by the firm doing so. Along with a number of other matters designed to secure the benefits of employees, that was designed to establish a thoroughly commercial superannuation fund. Up to that time there had been some very great abuses of the system and consequently this was a step in the direction of putting on a proper footing the operations of private superannuation funds which may not have been operating so well in the past.

One major feature of that was the establishment of the system by which the Commissioner of Taxation determined a reasonable level of benefits. There has been much comment about that in the course of this debate. That is an extremely technical matter which we will not go into at this stage, but I would like to comment on it in the course of later remarks. Bearing in mind the actions that were taken at that time to bring the superannuation funds of the 1960s to account and to put them on a proper basis, from that time on it behoved the Taxation Office to ensure that the rules and guidelines that it had established for the operation of the funds in a proper commercial sense were complied with by the taxpayers. The law had been amended and the framework laid down whereby the conditions for the operation of superannuation funds were established. It then became a matter of supervision by the Government and by the Commissioner of Taxation as to whether those rules were actually applied.

Now we come to the point of this legislation which the Government has put before us. It talks of the problems of the so-called cherry picker schemes whereby people have been employed on a short term basis or, as Senator Elstob so graphically expressed it, have been fired within one day of their normal retirement date so that they were unable to obtain the full benefits which otherwise would have accrued to them under the superannuation scheme. In those circumstances all of us would deplore the motives and morals of those who run businesses and operate superannuation funds which would take advantage of the law in those ways. Under the present law there are arrangements by which those circumstances can be pursued and in fact denied. The Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh), who is at the table, has produced for our benefit a copy of the judgment in a case known as Kelly v. Raymor (Illawarra) Pty Ltd handed down by Mr Justice Wootten in the Supreme Court of New South Wales. It sets down the circumstances of a blatant misuse of the law and of superannuation funds. All of us would condemn the way in which that fund was operated. I have a complaint with the Government on this score because it has chosen to bring down this case which describes an extreme set of circumstances. One would have to admit that it is nowhere near typical of the great number of superannuation cases which would be reviewed by the Commissioner of Taxation in the course of his annual duties. Right throughout this case, as has been brought out by the judge, there were blatant breaches of trust by the trustees of the superannuation fund.

TALK.START.PARA: —A family feud.
—Yes, a family feud, as Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle points out. There were obvious breaches of the spirit of the law, if not the word.
—Do you think they should have to pay the tax they avoided?

—I will come to the point in a moment. Obviously that judgment sets out the most extreme and, as certainly Senator Chipp would say, obscene mismanagement of a superannuation fund. That case has been put before us by the Government with the intention of influencing us towards a particular point of view. I refer to Senator Walsh's letter to us enclosing that document. He says in the second paragraph of his letter:

SPEECH.PARA: It has been suggested that these schemes are not of the blatant or contrived kind.

Those words are particularly relevant because, as I have tried to demonstrate, the 1964 amendments to the legislation and the subsequent way in which the Taxation Office has operated in respect of superannuation funds were designed to establish a proper commercial footing for the operation of superannuation schemes. Since that time it has been up to the Taxation Office to ensure that those guidelines have been complied with. I agree that these schemes, as they have been operating, are blatant and certainly contrived, to use the words that Senator Walsh set out in his letter. For that reason we have to condemn them with all the spirit and vigour we can muster. The point that needs to be made in these circumstances is that the Government has chosen to try to apply this law retrospectively from 1 July 1977. The circumstances in which the Government has previously claimed that it is going to apply these laws retrospectively are mentioned in a statement issued by the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins) in April last year. It is identified as a 'Press release No. Tax 83/4'. I quote from page 2 of that statement:
Taxpayers involved in legitimate planning of their business and family affairs have nothing to fear from the policy I am formally announcing.
I interpose to say that that policy was one of retrospective legislation against taxation avoidance. Mr Dawkins continues:

The schemes against which we would legislate retrospectively are only those highly contrived and artificial schemes generally accepted as being unambiguously inspired by avoidance motives and having little if any legitimate commercial function.

The point I want to make is that, on the one hand the Government's policy of retrospectivity in respect of taxation avoidance is specifically aimed against, yes, blatant and, yes, contrived schemes-but it is also aimed against artificial schemes. It seems that there is some doubt as to whether the kind of scheme encapsulated in this legislation is in fact in any way artificial. As I have described, the law has generally been complied with; there has been the provision of security of rights for employees, and there has been provision of benefits over a period of time. But where a scheme has been manipulated, that has occurred because the Commissioner of Taxation has not fulfilled his obligation to the full by investigating the carrying on of the scheme over the years in which it has been operating. In other words the supervision responsibilities of the Government have been omitted in many cases.

Without pinning too much responsibility on individuals for those omissions-I understand the difficulties of doing that, having practised in accounting for some time-this matter is borne out only too clearly by the very judgment the Minister has put before us as an example of the extreme kind of case against which he is seeking to legislate. That is really a most extreme set of circumstances, in which, had the Government, through the Taxation Commissioner, been aware of, and acted upon, information coming to it, as was so graphically pointed out by Senator Watson, I think that action would have been taken such that the scheme might not have proliferated in the way it is claimed to have done

That is the real point I want to bring to the Senate in order to make the observation that there is no justification for the retrospective aspect of this legislation. Firstly, it breaches the Government's own definition of what is to be legislated against retrospectively by it not, by definition, being an artificial scheme, because it does not fall into the kind of artificial contrivance represented by the bottom of the harbour scheme or other schemes against which we have legislated over the years. I mention those schemes for which John Howard, as Treasurer, was given a great deal of credit for acting against. For that reason and, secondly, bearing in mind that there is considerable doubt as to whether the Commissioner of Taxation has acted promptly enough to shut off this kind of scheme in the past, there is a substantial argument against the retrospective aspects of this legislation. In the Committee stage my colleague Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle will be moving amendments to make this legislation apply only from the date in December on which the announcement of it was made.

Bearing in mind all those things, there are one or two other matters to which reference needs to be made. Back in November 1982, just before the election which brought the Hawke Government to power, there was considerable change in the way in which the Australian Taxation Office sought to administer the affairs of superannuation funds. There was established a set of guidelines further to those I mentioned earlier. They have imposed very great restrictions upon the freedom of superannuation funds to operate their affairs. There has been much complaint about that in certain quarters, but suffice it to say that I think that may of those changes have been thoroughly justified, in that the Department is seeking now to establish reasonable security for the rights of members and to impose conditions upon their operations to guard against the very things which Senator Elstob mentioned on behalf of the Government. Perhaps it would improve Senator Elstob's understanding of the matter if he were to read the guidelines that have been issued by the Commissioner of Taxation in recent times.

One other aspect of that matter which concerns me is that there is this duty upon the Commissioner of Taxation to determine what is known as a reasonable benefit for each employee. That has been set down through rules established over the last 20 years. I want to observe that the level of reasonable benefits available to employees through superannuation funds generally has not kept pace at all with the rate of inflation. In 1964 the level of reasonable benefits could be provided to people whose salaries were roughly four times average weekly earnings, but it is now only provided for salaries 1.3 times average weekly earnings. Very significant changes have occurred which have saved substantial revenue over that period as far as the Government is concerned because of the failure of 'reasonable benefits' to keep up with inflation. The longer term effects of that are that fewer private superannuation funds will be able to provide benefits for members and consequently there will be more and more dependency by individuals as they grow older upon the social security system. Leaving that aside, the most important aspect of the matter is that the controls that have been implemented by the Taxation Office in recent years are sufficient to ensure that superannuation funds are properly managed and will be maintained at the kind of level of operating performance and efficiency, and, one might say, honesty, that was expected when the original guidelines were introduced in 1964.

I turn quickly to one other aspect of the legislation, that of short term life insurance policies. The purpose of the legislation is to extend from four years to 10 years the minimum period for which a life insurance policy can be held without the proceeds being held as taxable in the hands of the recipient. Over the years there have been some attempts to develop alternative forms of investment through short term life assurance policies. One of those has been the kind of policy which is mentioned in this legislation. Of course, it is something that has been known about for some time. Indeed, the former Treasurer, John Howard, took action by announcing that he would legislate on this matter, and the legislation before us represents the outcome of that decision. The point I mention here is that the attack by this legislation on short term policies has been justified on the basis that there is some kind of tax avoidance incentive for people to involve themselves in these kinds of activities and policies, as against taking other kinds of investments.

I think we have to examine that a little further. The justification by the Government is that somehow a tax saving is available to people who make this kind of investment. The fact is, of course, that life assurance policies in any form are subject to the taxation laws that apply to life assurance companies. Generally speaking, the rules are that life assurance companies pay tax on their capital gains as they do on their other gains, which are then accumulated for the purpose of paying out benefits at the end of the term of the policy. The fact that capital gains are included means that one very significant group of taxpayers-life assurance companies-is paying tax on capital which the general community, by virtue of the present law, does not do. It means that if one were to invest in such a thing as a unit trust which is involved in property development, one would be able to secure a tax advantage compared with those who invest in superannuation funds and are taxed in the way in which I have just described. That means that in present circumstances the investor in life assurance is at a tax disadvantage compared with unit holders and those who are involved in other kinds of investments. It therefore does not follow that there is a justification for the Government's action in attacking life assurance in this way. In fact, the reverse is true. If there were to be an attempt to bring about tax neutrality in this area, perhaps other investors ought to be considered.

The point I am trying to make is that there is a very real incentive for people to invest in life assurance because of the benefits and security that it brings in the event of the death of the owner of the policy compared with other kinds of investment. Indeed, it is a worthy objective on the part of all in Australia. There are many reasons why people want to have life assurance, as we know. They wish to provide some kind of benefit for their funeral and for outstanding mortgages and/or debts upon the death of an individual and matters of that kind. So there is a perfectly legitimate reason for people to want to make this kind of investment. I think we have to ask: Why does the Government not see that as a legitimate form of investment? Why does it argue that it is a tax avoidance measure when clearly life assurance is at a disadvantage tax-wise compared with other forms of investment? We look to the Minister to provide the answer in the course of the debate, but judging from remarks made to date in the House of Representatives we will not be satisfied in that respect.

Finally, I refer again to superannuation funds. The Government has in recent months announced its intentions to tax lump sum superannuation payments. That has been a matter of great contention in the community and the Government, true to its usual form, has backed off from its original decision under pressure from its trade union allies. Indeed, it is no doubt again under pressure from the New South Wales Government, which is facing an election on 24 March. I wonder whether the Government is now prepared to bring forward that legislation for immediate debate ahead of the election. I hope that it will give us the opportunity of looking at that legislation in the not too distant future.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is only tomorrow.

—Well, the Government has tomorrow to do it. Bearing in mind the intentions of that legislation, people who invest in annuities will have a tax exemption for lump sum payments in the circumstances that are envisaged. There is said to be some tax advantage if people take their superannuation in a lump sum in such a way as to pay tax on only 5 per cent of the total amount, whereas a person taking a pension or an annuity pays tax at the full marginal rate on his or her income. I think what is overlooked in the logic of that situation is that a lump sum which comes to hand when somebody retires is invested immediately and of course, generally speaking, returns income immediately. Therefore that income is immediately subject to tax. For that reason the logic of the tax system has been that in order to take account of any intervening problems, only 5 per cent of that capital sum has been included in the income of the taxpayer in the year in which it is received, because tax would be payable immediately upon the income generated from the investment. For that reason we on this side of the chamber find it difficult to follow the logic of the Government in applying a special tax at the rate of 30 per cent on lump sums, which is said to be in order to iron out the tax discrepancies between that form of receipt of superannuation and pensions or annuities. In fact, as you would know, Mr President, the Opposition has promised that upon return to government it will repeal that proposed legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Again, it would be very interesting if the Government, now nine months from its original announcement, could produce this legislation so that we could examine it ahead of the New South Wales election. But one is starting to wonder whether we will even see the legislation before the election which Mr Hawke has promised us by the end of this year. The Opposition will oppose the retrospective aspects of the legislation and I thoroughly support that position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 5 ) 1983 deals with eight separate and unrelated aspects of our tax system. It provides for the withdrawal of investment allowance where the property is used in tax exempt activities, makes some changes to the arrangements for leverage leasing and similar arrangements, makes special tax concessions for Australian trading ships, provides some tax arrangements for bonuses received in respect of certain short term life assurance policies, changes the arrangements for deductions for investments in qualifying Australian films, provides for the exemption from tax of payments of special benefits to victims of major disasters and deals with tax avoidance practices in relation to employee superannuation funds. Some of these matters have been the subject of considerable debate. I wish to raise two matters that have not yet been debated at all in this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: The first matter I deal with was not debated at all in the House of Representatives. I refer to the changes to the arrangements for deductions for investment in qualifying Australian films. The Australian film industry has been one of the most dramatic internal and international success stories of recent years. It has been a great benefit to all Australians both in our internal appreciation of ourselves and our international reputation. It is important that the tax arrangements should encourage a continuation of the production of quality Australian films. This Bill reduces the income tax deduction allowable from 150 per cent of the amount invested to 133 per cent. That does not mean, by the way, as some people seem to think, that an investor has a bonus given back to him when he invests. The 150 per cent deduction really means that if a person invests money in a film 90 per cent of that investment is tax free. In fact that person is effectively investing only 10 per cent, he is risking only 10 per cent of his investment. The Government is intending to reduce the concession rate from 150 per cent to 133 per cent. The Government will also be reducing the exemption from income tax with regard to the net revenue from a film from 50 per cent to 33 per cent.

What does this do? The saving to revenue is estimated to be $1m in this financial year and about $4m in a full financial year. But this amount saved is more than offset by the $5m which has been given this year-and there is every indication that it will continue-to the Australian Film Commission. The Government's changes have not made any difference to the net cost to revenue. The Government has changed the structure of its support for the production of films and has given very much more direct control to the Australian Film Commission, a point to which I will come in a moment. The other change, one which we should certainly support unequivocally, permits the use of underwriting arrangements. An investor does not have to be a party to the contract for the production of a film but he can still invest in an underwriting arrangement. That is sensible and ordinary business administrative practice.

This legislation represents yet another broken promise by the Hawke Labor Government. Senator Ryan, who was spokesman on affairs concerning the arts before the last election, was quite adamant that not only would the income tax arrangements for film investors remain intact but also they would be increased by a Labor government. I will quote her:
Labor would pass legislation to stabilise the film industry and after passing this legislation would leave it untouched for two years. Among the measures was the provision for a 160%-
that is an increase-
income tax deduction if a film is completed within two years.

Labor honoured the two-year promise which was part of the policy of the former Liberal-National Party Government; we were doing that. But Labor did not-I repeat the word 'not'-honour the 160 per cent tax deduction. Instead of increasing it this Government has decreased it. This is yet another example, I suppose, of Hawkespeak, saying one thing and doing the opposite.

What is the effect of what this Government has done? A broken promise comes as no surprise; we are used to them. But it creates uncertainty. If the Government is going to change its mind in this way it causes uncertainty in investors. It is very doubtful whether the 133 per cent tax deduction is sufficient to create enough incentives for investment in feature films. Investing in films is a very chancy business. About one in six will show a profit. That standard in Australia , by the way, is higher than in a similar situation in America. What is also required by legislation-it has been required for some time-is that film producers have to spend considerable sums on prospectuses and dealers' licences. There are many other areas for speculative investment and unless the offerings are high enough in the film industry we will not get investment in films. One of the other problems in getting investment is that it is very difficult unless one has a distribution guarantee.

As a consequence the number of feature films being produced this year is a little more than half what it was in the previous year. Certainly, an industry of the size of the Australian industry can produce too many films. A number of films have been produced which should never have been produced. I suppose we could say that we could produce 20 or 25 quality films, but it looks as though we will only be producing about 12 this year. A responsible government must look to its policy to see what has caused this drop in production in an area which, as I said at the outset, is of great importance to Australia, far more important than any net returns in overseas trade. Films project an image of Australia both externally and internally which is very much to the advantage of all of us. The Government's policy is not working well. I am not suggesting that we should make rapid changes; that is even more damaging. But the Government's policy is not working effectively in encouraging investment in Australian films.

Worse still, the Government has transferred responsibility and enormous power to the Australian Film Commission. I have been concerned, as I think has everyone else, about giving such substantial concessions from revenue to people who invest in films. How do we ensure, within reasonable limits, that what is produced is culturally successful? One can never guarantee success in this area but we have been producing too many sub-standard films. I do not think the solution to that, though it is loved by the Australian Labor Party theoreticians and practitioners, is giving all power to a single body. The Australian Film Commission, with its $5m investment grant, is in an enormously powerful position in the Australian film industry. I very much doubt whether the effect of what it is doing and what it is likely to do will be to encourage wise investment and innovative, creative, successful new films.

I will give a couple of examples of the problems of trying to obtain investment in films. The film Lonely Hearts produced by Paul Cox, which won the best film award in 1982, had to be financed privately because the producer could not get either the Australian Film Commission or the State film corporation to invest in it. Yet it was a very successful film. The following year the same producer could not get any money for Man of Flowers from the Commission or the State corporation. That film won the best actor award. They are very successful films and have been given international acclaim. The producer of those films could not get any government film corporation investment. Now that Paul Cox is so successful, his new films will be supported by the State film corporation. But that is where the system failed. It has not been able to identify people who are not yet successful.

I will give just one more example although I could multiply these examples many times. Mad Max, one of the most financially successful films we have produced and also critically acclaimed by a section of the film-going public around the world, was privately funded because its producers could not get any investment from the State film corporation or the AFC. Mad Max II was also privately funded . Now that the producers are successful the AFC is investing $500,000 in a new Kennedy-Miller production, Bodyline.

I have heard a lot of criticism by the people in the film industry about that. After the producers' success with Mad Max and Mad Max II they do not need this sort of investment; other film makers need it more. I do not want to second- guess the AFC; I understand its problems. The point I am making is that if we give this tremendous power to a single authority to decide what is and what is not produced in film making in Australia I think we will do great cultural damage to an industry that must survive and grow by originality and diversity. I think the system of allowing investors to invest and make mistakes is better than giving too much power to a government body in an area so sensitive and so difficult as investment in films.

The second matter to which I turn is quite unrelated to films. I wish to deal with the special concessions for Australian trading ships. This Bill also introduces special provisions which will authorise depreciation over five years, in equal instalments, for eligible Australian trading ships. It will also provide for the extension of the investment allowance to those ships when used either outside Australia or on the coastal trade in Australia. Previously the investment allowance applied only to property used in Australia. The investment allowance applies to eligible Australian ships constructed or acquired on or after 29 July 1977. I said it applied to eligible Australian ships. The eligibility rules are that the ships must be engaged exclusively in the coastal or overseas carriage of cargo and passengers, they must be wholly owned or used by residents of Australia, they must be used wholly and exclusively to produce assessable income, they must be registered in Australia, they must be manned by residents of Australia or authorised non-residents and, most important of all-a point I will come back to-they must be manned at a level not exceeding the manning level determined for that ship.

What will be the cost to revenue? It will be $8m this year and next year, rising to $25m-of course, this is an estimate-in 1985-86. So we are embarking on a program of heavy subsidy for the Australian shipping industry. What is the problem-there are problems-with this sort of subsidy for shipping? Other countries do it on a long term basis. Some people argue that because others do it we must do it too. I would caution that the costs will be very high and the consequences may not be what we expect. I am not dealing for the moment-I will come back to this also-with the question of the necessity for shipping for defence purposes. The real purpose of this Bill is to encourage a growth for non -defence purposes.

One can only look at what has happened in the United States of America. Its shipping industry is very heavily subsidised. There has been a subsidy this year of $435m and this is not working. Despite these very heavy subsidies in the United States all its liner operations are in difficulties. There is a very small number of United States flag ships in overseas trade. The Americans have not got, under the American flag, an acceptable maritime industry. The reason is very simple. Its crew costs are too high. That may sound familiar, but the American costs are not as bad as the Australian costs. They are only just better ; they are just under Australian standards. The United States wage bill is nearly as high as ours and the Americans, too, have nearly two crews per ship.

I would like to make it clear that I am fully in agreement with the decision to extend the five-year depreciation period to ships, to provide the investment allowance for overseas ships and to eliminate-this is also provided in this legislation-the 2 per cent import tax on ships, but only provided that the crews are brought down to reasonable levels. I would also like to make it clear that I am all in favour of a revitalised Australian shipping industry but with two vital provisos: It does not increase the cost or the unreliability of our overseas trade. The shippers, the people who will have to pay the first cost-in the long run, the community pays the increased cost of overseas trade-have been consulted very little in this whole business. It looks to me like a very cosy deal between the Government, ship owners and unions. That, of course, is my worry.

Before I deal with that matter I would like to dispose of one other argument- the defence matter. At the moment coastal shipping is an Australian flag monopoly: We have 70 ships of 1.5 million tonnes on the coast with 13 ships of 450,000 tonnes engaged in overseas trade. I am sure that we could get enough ships from these to support even a Falklands scale operation, provided there was proper prior planning. We have not been doing that, but that is another story. The arguments advanced by the report of the Crawford Committee on Revitalisation of Australian Shipping are, in my view, all either wrong or suspect. It is unlikely that increased Australian flag shipping would make a significant net improvement in our balance of payments. It would be most unlikely to lead to increased employment and even more unlikely to provide a useful window on real shipping costs. But even if these advantages were realised they would still have to be balanced against the costs.

At present, the Australian National Line is the darling of the shipping conference with a cost structure which is so high that it raises the average freight rates for all the other members of the conference and we pay the resultant costs. At least $20m a year in extra unnecessary cost because of the ANL's involvement in the conference is created by our east Asian trade alone. That $20m a year is passed on to the Australian community. Why are our costs so high? Australian shipping is costly because excessive crews are demanded by unions. I will give honourable senators an example: Of the three sister ships on the Australia to West Coast of America service, the Swedish ship has a crew of 28, the British ship has a crew of 35 and the Australian ship has a crew of 36. That is typical. I will give honourable senators a couple of other examples of the effects of this overmanning. In 1981 the average cost of operating a 100,000 to 130,000 dead weight tonne ship on the open registry was $1.8m a year. For the British the same ship would cost $2.4m and for Australia-a ship manned by Australians-it would cost $3.8m, double the operating cost per year for the open registry. The Europeans estimate that to run their ships on Australian manning standards would cost them an additional $1m a year.

I will give honourable senators one further example. In 1975 the Labor Government brought the Christmas Island phosphate trade under the coastal shipping arrangements. The cost was $29,000 per job per year. That is now being passed on to the Australian farmer and is ultimately paid by the Australian public. Worse still, not only are the Australian crews the largest and the highest paid with the highest costs, such as workers compensation, but also they have five months leave a year, so we need nearly two crews for each ship, and they do less on-board maintenance than the smaller crews of other nationalities. This, of course, increases costs and reduces operational availability. I will give just one more small example: Stewards on our ships do not do any laundry. On ships of all the other countries they do. The result is laundry has to be done in port. That cost is $150,000 a year, which is passed on to our freight costs and passed on to the Australian community.

One of the main reasons for the excessive Australian crew numbers is that six unions are involved. Surely this is one of the areas in which we should be pressing for a single industry union and for appropriate cross-training. It has been suggested that about 12 ships might be added to the Australian flag in the next three years. The only way these could be economically justified would be if the unions show, by performance, that they are prepared to bring the total manpower cost-not just the crew numbers-of running an Australian flag ship into line with those of other developed countries, such as Sweden or Norway. But here we are in a catch-22 situation. The unions will not make more than token cuts in crewing until they see the new ships and ship owners cannot afford to spend, say , $40m on a new ship unless they know that their total crew costs, total manpower costs, are down to competitive world levels and they have some guarantee that these crew costs will stay down-a guarantee that might be difficult to accept.

The only other way to increase the proportion of our trade carried in Australian flag ships-other than by way of depreciation allowances or investment allowances-would be for the Government to give our flag ships and our ship owners a guaranteed proportion of the trade, regardless of the costs. This is what I think it will ultimately do, but it would be utterly disastrous for all Australians. I am all for bold initiatives that will overcome the high costs and low productivity of our shipping. But industrial peace can be bought at too high a price. I am fearful that we will burden ourselves with high cost ships providing unreliable services, with industrial blackmail being used to force shippers to use them despite their uncompetitive cost. What we may ultimately do is reduce our overseas shipping to the appalling level of our coastal shipping. The very high costs and low efficiency of our coastal shipping have caused grave damage to the whole economy of Australia and, as a result, to all Australians. I hope I am wrong in this fear, but I think I am right.

I would like two assurances from the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh). First, that ship owners will not be given tax and depreciation concessions for their ships unless the total manpower costs for their ships have been brought down to reasonable world levels. The Minister in his second reading speech stated that the manning levels must not exceed the manning level determined for that ship. I would like to ensure that when the Government talks about a manning level, it is not just talking about crew numbers at any given moment; that it is talking about the total manpower costs including what the crew does, and how many crews are needed to man a ship throughout the year. That is the basis on which we should be looking at the total manpower costs of an Australian flag ship. It is vital, if we are to have these considerable subventions from government revenue to encourage ships, that we must be sure that their total manpower costs are competitive with those of other developed countries. The second assurance I would like is that under no circumstances will the Minister agree to give Australian ships a guaranteed proportion of our overseas trade. If they are to get that guarantee, they must do so by being competitive on the world shipping market. If they are given a guaranteed proportion, regardless of costs, it would, as I said, reduce our overseas shipping standards to the very low standards we now have on the Australian coast .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 5) which covers a range of subjects which have been debated at increasing length in the Senate. I will speak to just one aspect of the Bill; that is, the part which addresses itself to the changed government policy in relation to the film industry. Senator Hamer early in his speech referred to this aspect. I want to pick up a number of the points that he raised and to make some others.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the Government's policy in relation to films is equal to any of the hypocrisies that have been listed against the Hawke Government on its broken promises. Just one year ago this Government was elected to office with a number of promises. As quickly as it could-within days-it ditched its promises on what are now shown to be spurious grounds. It ditched them on the grounds of an estimated forecast deficit. Only in the last few days the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the now discredited Treasurer, Mr Keating, have had cause to say that these figures mean nothing, because now that they are in government they are faced with releasing the same set of figures as was released at the time of the 1983 election. They have both said that it is not worth releasing the figures because they are meaningless. Twelve months ago those figures were the reason for the Australian Labor Party and Mr Hawke tearing up policy speeches and promises.

The arts area-the film industry, in particular-is one area which has been noteworthy in this respect. In some areas of the arts promises have not yet been kept. In other areas they have been broken. But the extreme hypocrisy of the Government in the matter of the film industry is that it cannot even use the spurious Budget deficit figures as its excuse for breaking its promises, because there is no financial gain to the Government, if its own statements and projections are correct. The Treasurer, in his second reading speech on this Bill, stated in relation to changes in taxation concessions:

These measures are estimated to save revenue of $1m for 1983-84 and $4m in a full year but this is more than offset by additional direct government assistance to the film industry through the Australian Film Commission.

I am curious about the fact that the Treasurer, having given the estimates of savings in revenue, did not then nominate this more-than-offsetting figure. When the announcement was made that the tax deductions for films were to be reduced, the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, Mr Cohen, said that it would be offset by a $5m grant to the Australian Film Commission. When I went to school one plus four equalled five, which would mean that $1m this year and $4m in a full year would equal the $5m given to the Australian Film Commission. I do not know what is meant by the Treasurer's statement that the measures would be 'more than offset by additional direct government assistance'. It can mean one of two things. It can mean that more money is being given to the Australian Film Commission that has not been announced and I doubt that. It could mean that the Treasurer, to put it in the kindest way that I can think of, is gilding the lily . Perhaps he is including the AFC's annual budget in the amount of money given to the AFC. But it is still only $5m. Therefore revenue savings by the taxation changes are offset by an additional grant to the Australian Film Commission. So the grounds of the Budget deficit, which were always spurious, cannot be given.

So what has happened? A number of promises were given and Senator Hamer has detailed them. I will detail those promises again and contrast them with the reality. The Labor Party in opposition promised to extend the eligibility for a previous tax deductibility to two years from completion of a film, as against the one year that applied earlier. The former Treasurer, Mr Howard, had announced at the beginning of the year that the Fraser Government has agreed to this extension, an extension which was being pressed on the Government for some little time before that announcement. I will return to that matter. So the promise of the extension of eligibility was kept. It was kept through legislation that passed this Senate with bipartisan support in May of last year. The promise-a bipartisan one-and the keeping of it so far remains intact.

Another promise was to allow marketing expenses of films to be tax deductible. One of the reasons for at least one element in the tax concessions that have been given to the film industry is that marketing expenses, for example, are not deductible. The only expenses that are eligible in the deduction area are those actually incurred in making the film. That can account for 80 per cent to 90 per cent of the total project cost to the point of revenue being earned. That reduces the apparent attractiveness of the tax concession. The Labor Party promised to allow those expenses to be deductions in addition to the taxation concessions that existed. That promise has not been kept, and will not be kept.

The Labor Party also promised that when it made its reforms to the film industry, which included an extension of eligibility to two years, an increase in the taxation rebate from 150 per cent to 160 per cent, and deductibility for marketing expenses, those changes would remain in place for two years. What has happened? I have mentioned the extension of eligibility to two years which was brought in in May. It was the policy of the Fraser Government and of the Labor Party during the 1983 election campaign. It passed through both houses with bipartisan support in May 1983. However, on Budget night in August 1983, less than three months after the change, the Treasurer announced that the tax concessions for film investment would be reduced.

I will briefly clear up a misconception about these concessions held by a number of people, both in this Parliament and certainly outside the Parliament, who do not invest in films. In the case of investment, there was previously a 150 per cent deduction. I think there are people who have the idea, when a 150 per cent tax deduction for films is mentioned, that if $100 is invested in a film the Government drops $150 into the investor's pocket and that therefore this concession is some great rort and the investor cannot lose. Of course, that is not so, as various Ministers for Home Affairs and Environment have been at pains to point out from time to time. The 150 per cent refers to a tax rebate, it does not refer to 150 per cent of investment. The tax rebate has now been reduced by the Government to 133 per cent. Again, that contrasts with the promise it made to increase the tax rebate to 160 per cent. The associated tax benefit was the exemption from income tax of 50 per cent of the net revenue. That has now been reduced to 33 per cent-another broken promise.

Putting it in the simplest terms possible the net effect is that the break-even point for a film has been increased by at least 20 per cent. That 20 per cent is the conservative calculation after taking all the factors into account, such as those items that are not deductible. I am informed by spokespeople for the film industry that in the case of some films these taxation changes by the Hawke Government have raised the break-even point by 36 per cent. It has already been stated in the Senate today that the film industry is a notoriously unreliable one in terms of return on investment. It is an extremely high risk industry for investors. A small percentage of films make a profit. Even so, in Australia our record has been pretty good compared with that of other countries. Nonetheless, the percentage of profit-making films is small; certainly it is less than half. The effect of raising the break-even point by at least 20 per cent-and possibly up to 40 per cent-must mean that the chances of a film returning a profit are reduced and the percentage of profitable films could thus be expected to reduce. The disincentive to investing in films because of the industry's high risk nature has always been there. The Government has compounded that disincentive.

In the last few days the 1982-83 report of the Australian Film Commission was tabled in Parliament. As it covers the period from 1 July 1982 to 30 June 1983 comments made in the report are therefore relevant to government action in that period. I will quote relevant parts of the Chief Executive's report. The report states in relation to 1982-83:
It was a turbulent year but some very solid gains were achieved.

In particular, substantial progress was made in resolving questions of industry regulation. The long-awaited adjustment to the completion requirement under the tax incentives legislation was introduced . . .

The industry has traditionally enjoyed bi-partisan political support and this support was reaffirmed when, after the change of Government in March 1983, promised legislation to amend 10BA was in due course effected.
The industry's greatest need now--
that is, as at 30 June 1983-
is for stability in its regulatory environment and the Commission draws comfort from recent undertakings by the Federal Government that the present incentives will stand for at least two years.

The incentives stood for two months-not two years-after the Chief Executive of the Australian Film Commission wrote that report. The need for stability in the industry, the need to know with certainty whether laws will be changed, is essential. It is essential for those with film projects so they can make their plans; it is essential for those who would seek to sell investment in the industry so they can know what the devil it is they are selling to investors. It is also essential to the thousands of people who work in the industry. It is not always realised that the film industry is very labour intensive. We see the actors, the up-front people, and we hear about the producers and directors, the people who get the awards and credit for artistic creation, but there are many other people, such as technicians and those in associated trades who are employed by the film industry. Thousands of Australians are employed in the Australian film industry. It is necessary for them to have stability so that they can continue to commit themselves to working in the industry and not leave with their experience, expertise and talents to seek more stability and security elsewhere.

This Government in breaking its promise stands condemned, and I reiterate that it is for no financial gain. In a debate in the Senate last year on a statement on such changes by the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment I pointed out that there were problems for the film industry in these changes.
