I addressed myself to the second aspect, which Senator Hamer has already addressed today. I am concerned that there has been a very real shift of power, through a shift of financial power, to the Australian Film Commission. The Australian Film Commission now has $5m to invest in Australian films. With the declining attractiveness of private investment that has to give the Film Commission a very powerful position in the market-place. One of the reasons the Minister gave for this was the quality of films being produced. I really do not think any politician should care whether people want to spend their money on seeing such movies as Mad Max or Alvin Purple or whether they want to spend it on films such as Man of Flowers. I do not think it is any of our business. The public will vote with its feet. The record shows that those films that have been commercially successful are about 50 per cent of the light-hearted variety and about 50 per cent of what we would roughly call the quality variety.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is nothing lighthearted about Mad Max. It is a very serious film.

—It is interesting that Senator Button raises that point because last year the matter was raised in an Estimates committee with Mr Skrzynski, the Chief Executive of the Australian Film Commission. When questions were being addressed to Mr Skrzynski as to how the Australian Film Commission intended to approach the disbursement of this money and what its self-imposed guidelines and standards would be, he was asked whether, if Mad Max or Puberty Blues scripts had been presented to the Australian Film Commission, under the guidelines that it had determined, it was likely that they would have been funded. His answer was no.
—Why?

—I was not interested in pursuing that. They are two very successful films. Mad Max is an extremely successful film financially-a film I have not seen because I do not like films of violence but apparently a lot of people do because they spend their money on it. Puberty Blues was a low budget, very sensitive film and would fall into that category that we call 'quality'. But those films would not have been so regarded by the Australian Film Commission. While Mr Skrzynski admitted it would have been a mistake not to finance them they would not have fallen into those guidelines. This illustrates that people vary in their standards of judgment. I reiterate: It is not the business of government what the quality of a film is, at least not in the sense the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has used that word. I do not think it is the business of a statutory corporation either but the Government has now made it the business of the Australian Film Commission. We should all be a little nervous when government and government agencies have such power over the content of films. I am not suggesting that the choices that have been made by the Film Commission so far are in any way sinister but I do not think it is a healthy trend in attitudes of government towards the content of artistic endeavour.

SPEECH.PARA: In recent days there has been some controversy about the net effect that the changes in the taxation concessions will have on the Australian feature film industry. Some have predicted that it will be such a blow to the Australian feature film industry that very few-maybe only three or four-feature films will be financed this financial year. Some have said that it is the death blow to the feature film industry--

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you think?

—I will give an indication later-and that in future investors will be interested in investing only in television series because there is an advance sale to a television channel before the series is made. The Australian Film Commission has entered this controversy and talked up the market a little. There may be good reasons for doing that but even so, without deciding on this date, because I think it is one for the future, I find the claim by Mr Skrzynski a little confusing. Mr Skrzynski, the Chief Executive of the Australian Film Commission, is quoted in the Australian Financial Review of 24 February in an article headed 'No tax ''disaster''-commission head' as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: He-
that is, Mr Skrzynski-
named 12 films and two television mini-series which were already under way . . . and then produced a list of another 12 films and four mini-series which were expected to go into production.

Of these, he said the Film Commission had been informed that at least five films were definite starters, three of which were being funded under the new tax regime, along with the four mini-series . . .

In one sentence it is stated that 12 films are under way and 12 other films are expected to go into production. One would be excused for thinking that the Chief Executive of the Film Commission was indicating that maybe 24 feature films would be funded this year. However, he goes on to say that at least five are definite starters. I am not sure which five of which 12; whether it is five of the 12 that are already under way-in which case one wonders why he says 12 are definite starters-or five out of the 12 which are expected to go into production --

TALK.START.PARA: —Three out of one and two out of the other.

—I repeat for Senator Tate, who has not been listening all the time, that Mr Skrzynski produced a list of 12 films under way and another list of 12 films which were expected to go into production. He said that he had been informed that at least five films were definite starters. I do not know what the difference is between 'expected to go into production' and 'definite starters'. Perhaps Senator Tate knows and can explain it to the Senate. I thought they meant the same thing.
—In relation to films?

—Yes. I am not attempting to predict whether 24 films, five or none will be financed this year. The proof of the pudding will be on 30 June this year when we will know the number of films that have actually started under the new tax regime. Investment in the film industry has traditionally been rather bunched towards the end of the financial year and it will be the figures that emerge at the end of the financial year which will give us the answer. I do not want to talk down investment in the industry but I do not think it is very helpful to talk it up. I have been concerned ever since the changes were announced as is everyone I know who is involved in the film industry, apart from the Minister and the Australian Film Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: I reiterate what I said at the beginning. This was all so unnecessary. If the Government had only maintained its promise to extend the previous tax concession to two years the film industry would be on the sound basis it believed it was on after May 1983 when it looked forward to a period of stability. Maybe there are people in the film industry who have a fairly healthy scepticism who did not expect the Government actually to increase the tax concession from 150 per cent to 160 per cent as promised, and who did not really expect the Government to allow marketing costs as a tax deduction as promised. However, I know of no one who anticipated the reductions in taxation incentives. I know of no one who expected the Government within three months of changing the rules, flying in the face of a two-year stability promise, to change them yet again and for no good reason.

Promises have been broken without even the excuse of saving money, of having to buy one's way out of something. Therefore one must ask the question: Why were the promises broken? There are a number of possible answers. The Minister has given none. I will suggest a couple. One is to take the sinister view which was referred to also by Senator Hamer that this Government is interested in control of the content of Australian films. However, Mr Skrzynski himself has admitted that one cannot objectively measure the viability of a film and that the Australian Film Commission would have made a mistake about two outstandingly successful films. Alternatively, perhaps the Government really is not interested in the film industry. I know the Minister is interested in the film industry. It seems to give a great charge to his adrenalin to go to Los Angeles and make speeches on the film industry. He has done it and good luck to him. I agree with the pride in the Australian film industry that he expressed in his speeches. But the adrenalin of investors in the Australian film industry is not flowing so fast. It may well be that there will not be many future occasions on which the Minister can make such speeches. As I said, the Minister is undoubtedly interested in the film industry; the Government clearly is not. It would have cost very little, if anything, for the Government to keep its promises. Whatever the results for Australian films prove to be, including the effect on thousands of jobs in the industry, the Government will bear the consequences in due course .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Income Tax Assessment Bill (No. 5) 1983. Details of the proposed amendments contained in this Bill have been very fully, very well and very clearly explained and debated by my colleagues. Rather than again canvass all the details of those amendments I will restrict myself to the retrospective provisions of clause 5 (1 ) of the Bill. This clause proposes to amend section 23F of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, which relates to superannuation funds. It proposes to make those amendments retrospective to 1 July 1977. Section 23F funds, of course, are private superannuation funds set up by employers for employees. The objective of the amendment to section 23F funds contained in the Bill before us is to remove abuses resulting from contrived and artificial schemes.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly there have been abuses of the very worst kind. Perhaps there is no better example than the Raymor case, which concerned a superannuation fund which was allegedly set up to provide benefits for employees of the company. In fact the real purpose of that fund was not to provide benefits to the employees for their years of service but was rather a blatant process to artificially provide taxation deductions for the employers at the expense of the employees. And what an expense it was. As the various employees approached retiring age and became eligible for superannuation benefits they were removed from the employers' payroll. By way of various confidence tricks they were persuaded to leave their employers and axiomatically to surrender their rights and entitlements to the fund. It was disgraceful that they should have been denied their benefit. The scheme was set up to be of benefit to the employees, not the employers. The employees were removed from the payroll when the time they could enjoy the benefit of the scheme approached. Those whose jobs were in greatest danger were those who had served the firm longest and presumably were in the older age bracket. They would have found it more difficult to find alternative work. Such conduct by employers can, of course, only be abhorred. It should create outrage within the whole community.

However, irrespective of the amendments before us, I would have thought that such schemes and arrangements would not have fallen within the terms of the provisions of section 23F. In fact, I would have thought that probably they would have run the very real risk of falling within the terms of the Crimes Act, particularly when one considers the opinion Brinsden QC, now a judge of the Supreme Court of Western Australia, gave in an earlier case. Surely the new, enlightened interpretation which was cast upon the Income Tax Assessment Act by the High Court of Australia would allow section 260 to be available. I certainly think that part IVA should be available. Section 170 seems to me to be appropriate, as was suggested by Senator Hill. That section provides an opportunity for the Commissioner of Taxation, notwithstanding the fact that assessments have been made, to reopen the case and to issue new assessments. If any one of the provisions I have referred to apply, it would seem totally unnecessary to have legislation of a retrospective nature such as that we have before us at the moment.

However, putting that aside, I record the view that I expressed previously: I have grave objection to the principle of retrospectivity. On my reading of this Bill as it relates to section 23F of the Act, not only will it catch employers of the type in the case I referred to but also it will catch many other innocent people. They will face not only a retrospective tax but also a new tax. I am moved to observe that the judge in the Kelly v. Raymor case referred his judgment to the Attorney-General of New South Wales and to the Commissioner of Taxation. I am sure that he did not do that for purely academic reasons. I am sure that he did it because he believed that enforceable provisions might come within the power of either the Commissioner or of the Attorney-General.
In regard to retrospectivity, I refer to no less a person than Mr Temby QC, the Government's new Director of Public Prosecutions. In referring to retrospectivity he said:
What justification can there be for making a person suffer on account of actions which were legal when performed?
He went on to say:

Any person who understands the topic, whatever view they might have about the moral obligation upon all to pay a fair share of the cost of running the community, should be outraged by that which is proposed.
Again referring to the principle of retrospectivity, he concluded:
All who care about the rule of law should feel outraged by such a proposal.

That is what Mr Temby thought about retrospectivity. In regard to catching the innocent, I notice that the Commissioner of Taxation, when responding to the previous Treasurer's suggestion that section 23F schemes be examined, made this observation:

Because in revenue terms we have many larger tax avoidance problems in other areas and also because of the need to make certain that no avoidable difficulties are created in genuine superannuation funds I would recommend that you await the comments of the Task Force.

So clearly at that time the Commissioner had grave concern that the type of legislation which we now have before us would catch innocent people. As I said, my fundamental objection to the legislation before us is its retrospective nature. It is retrospective, I might add, to 1 July 1977. While many provisions within the total package of the Bill give me grave concern, I would be prepared to support the Bill if clause 5 were deleted from it. In the event that clause 5 is still in the Bill at the time of the third reading, I propose to vote against the whole package.
Debate interrupted.
Sitting suspended from 12.42 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Attorney-General: Was the Minister who ordered the release of Mr Ramon Sala in 1974 and the return of his passport the then Attorney-General, Senator Lionel Murphy? Who made representations to the Minister for Mr Sala's release? Was the current Attorney-General in any way involved in advising the then Attorney-General on the Sala case? If so, in what capacity? Has the Government yet decided whether it will table the Menzies report into the handling of this matter? Will it also table any relevant departmental or Federal or State police files?

—It will come as no surprise to know that the Attorney- General of the Commonwealth in April-May 1974 was the then Senator Lionel Murphy , now Mr Justice Murphy, and he was the Minister involved in that particular case. Representations were made on behalf of Sala by his solicitors, and that is a matter of record within the Department and is not disputed. As to whether or not I advised on any matter relating to this case, the answer is no. I was at the time a part time consultant to the Attorney-General on racial discrimination and human rights matters, but I certainly had no role in the day to day operation of matters of this kind. As to whether the Government has completed its consideration of whether we will table the Menzies report on this matter, the answer is no. As to whether we are likely to consider tabling or be prepared to table other departmental files on this matter, including police investigation reports, I think the answer is not likely in the case of police reports for familiar reasons that I indicated, amongst other occasions, when I made the tabling statement in relation to this whole matter. As to the details of the departmental files, that is a question which needs to be resolved on the application of freedom of information principles and we will give consideration to that.

—I refer the Attorney-General to yesterday's bombing of the home of Mr Justice Gee of the Family Court. In view of the obvious implications of this incident for the security of judges of that court, will the Attorney- General indicate what steps the Government proposes to take to review and improve security arrangements? Will the Attorney-General approach the newly- created Electoral Commission and request it to grant silent listings on the electoral rolls to Family Court judges?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated in a Press statement yesterday, I am appalled by the bombing of Mr Justice Gee's home and the injuries sustained by him and his young neighbour, as indeed any Australian would be. It is a great relief to the Government and, I am sure, to this Parliament and to everyone else in the country that neither the judge nor his family nor the young girl next door sustained serious injury. The Family Courts has a very difficult job to do in a jurisdiction where emotions very often run very high indeed. While the great majority of litigants accept the court's role, inevitably there are a few predisposed to violence who will not accept the due process of law.

ANSWER.PARA: A number of measures have been taken to minimise the risks to judges and to their families, but unfortunately, as we have now discovered, serious incidents do still occur. The judges are well aware of those risks but regard themselves as having a duty to uphold the law in spite of the personal dangers associated with that role. I place on record my own very great respect and admiration for the way in which Mr Justice Gee and his fellow judges of the Family Court, under the leadership of Chief Judge Elizabeth Evatt, perform their vitally important functions in difficult and often dangerous circumstances. I find it regrettable that so many members of the legal profession tend to undervalue the role of the Family Court and Family Court judges in this respect.

In recognition of the need for urgent action to be taken to review and improve security measures for Family Court judges, I am glad to be able to announce that I have today approved the calling early next week of a top level meeting of relevant departments and authorities, of which there are a large number with a possible role here, to consider a series of recommendations relating to the security of courts and judges. I give my personal assurance that I will make every effort, including in relation to the matter raised by Senator Ray about ensuring silent numbers for those Family Court Judges who want them and who do not already have them, as indeed most of them do, to ensure that the recommendations flowing from that meeting are implemented as fully and as speedily as possible.

I have also approved, and will take steps to arrange, that the security of judges and courts be placed on the agenda of the meeting of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General which occurs in Adelaide the day after tomorrow in order to maximise the co-operation of State Ministers and authorities. A great deal needs to be done to involve the States, particularly the State police forces, in effective security in the family law area. We will be taking every step ensure that, so far as it is humanly possible to achieve, that tragedy does not occur again.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Attorney-General to his answer yesterday to Senator Hill on the Sala case. Is it a fact that Mr Sala was holding a French passport? If so, why did the Attorney-General assert so definitely yesterday that the only country of destination under deportation would be Spain, a destination unsafe for Mr Sala? If it was thought that the French passport may have been a forgery, was that not even stronger grounds for holding him in detention until that possibility was properly investigated?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —What I meant to indicate yesterday was that the only appropriate country of destination for a deportee in the event that his passport was withdrawn from him on the ground of suspected forgery or otherwise would have been his country of origin-in this case, Spain. I thought I had made that clear, but if I have not that is the explanation for that. It was the case that questions had been raised as to whether or not the passport was a valid French passport or a forgery. Differences of opinion within the bureaucracy as to what ought to flow from that possibility are evident on the departmental files and are no doubt the reason why this particular matter surfaces again after all these years. Views were certainly held that the passport, given the queries that had been raised about it, should not have been returned.

ANSWER.PARA: The particular point I was making yesterday, and I make again today, was that a mere suspicion that a passport may be a false one is not enough by itself in this or any other civilised country to keep a person in gaol when there is no other justification for doing so. We are not in the habit, mercifully, of holding people in custody on an open-ended basis while investigations of this kind proceed. The police in this matter had had Mr Sala's passport in their possession not for four or five weeks, as I said yesterday when I was speaking without the benefit of the file and the report in front of me, but for six weeks . The reality of the matter was that had there been grounds for suspicion sufficient to lay a charge there had been ample time for that suspicion to be checked out. It had not reached that stage by the time representations were made for the release of the person. In those circumstances, a decision, which I believe was a perfectly proper decision and which my senior departmental officer has found on investigation to be a perfectly proper decision, was made.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Attorney-General has said that there were grounds to believe that there might be a forged passport. Therefore, why were steps not taken to check whether the passport was forged? It may not have been necessary to hold the man in gaol while doing that, but it would have been necessary to hold the passport.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —All that I can say about that is that the files demonstrate that steps had been taken to determine whether it was a forgery. The opinion of the French Consul-General had been obtained, and his view was that it might be. The passport had been sent to Interpol, or inquiries had been made of Interpol. The response did not come back until a considerable number of days after Sala had left the country.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —The point is that the investigation had been proceeding for about six weeks. Despite the jungle-like fashion in which some members of this society, including some of those in this chamber, behave, our society is not a legal jungle such that people can be, or should be or are kept in gaol on an open-ended basis while the suspicions, which may or may not prove accurate, are made the subject of investigation. I indicated yesterday that, following the reaction of the French Consul-General or following the preliminary views that had been received that the passport may have been false, the views of the Foreign Affairs Department were sought as to what would be the international implications so far as the reaction of the country in question, namely France, was concerned, if the passport was returned to the person with a question mark still existing about it. I was able to tell the Senate yesterday, as I repeat today, that the view of the Foreign Affairs Department was that in all the circumstances of the case it would be understood that Australia should take the particular course of action that in fact occurred in this matter. There is no reason for anyone to apologise for anything in respect of what occurred.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Special Minister of State. I refer to Press reports this week of a ballot to be conducted by the South Australian Electoral Office involving the counting of votes and the distribution of preferences by means of an electronic computer and to the proposal put to the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform that Totalisator Agency Board networks be considered for voting purposes. Will the Commonwealth be monitoring the counting of votes by computer in Adelaide to see whether there is scope for the use of this technology in Commonwealth elections? Has any further work been done by the Commonwealth on the broader and even more important subject of computerised voting since the tabling last year of the Select Committee report?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that a computerised machine to read ballot papers is being used for a poll for the State Superannuation Board and that State officials will then make an assessment of its success in South Australia. The Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform examined the whole question of the application of computer technology, and while concluding that computer votes would be possible in Australia, the Committee did not recommend the application of computer technology at this stage. The Committee also said that it believed:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . that the level of computer education among electors would need to be high to overcome the complications of a computer ballot paper . . . The present system has in its favour a close degree of supervision which might not be possible with computerisation. However, with developing computer-consumer education and the spread of technology, the Committee recommends that the proposal should be kept in mind.

That appeared at paragraph 3.44 of the report. In the light of the Committee's comments, the recent amendments to the Commonwealth Electoral Act do not provide for computerised voting. However, I understand that the Electoral Commission is aware of the South Australian experiment and will be monitoring it closely with a view to the possible application, as Senator Maguire suggests, of that experience to the Federal voting sphere.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNITED STATES OF AMERICA: SPACE-BASED WEAPONS PROGRAM

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to a question that I asked him on 2 December last year concerning the United States of America's decision to proceed with the development of a space-based weapons program. A very early reply was promised by the Minister. Is he aware that no such reply has been presented, three months later? Does this failure to inform the Senate indicate that the Government and its advisers have not yet determined a view on Australia's reaction to this escalation of the nuclear arms race to space? Is the Minister aware that on 6 January President Reagan signed National Security Decision Directive 119, which allocates up to $27 billion for research and development of space-based weapons? Given Australia's links to the United States military space programs through the United States bases at Pine Gap and Narrungar, has the Government been in consultation with the Reagan Administration as to this new phase in the nuclear arms race? What views have the Government's representatives conveyed to the United States Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is in my note here that I at least partially followed up Senator Chipp's original question with a statement at the end of Question Time on 2 December, when I said:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is aware that various estimates have been made of the cost of establishing a satellite-based weapons system. It is generally agreed that any such system would be extremely expensive. The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) said in his speech to the United Nations General Assembly on 4 October that Australia will seek with all possible vigour an international agreement to ensure that the arms race does not extend to outer space. The contents of confidential consultations with other countries has to remain confidential. Honourable senators may be assured, however, that the Government's views are conveyed whenever appropriate.

As to the other points in the honourable senator's question, I reiterate that the Government has stated on many occasions-I presume that this relates to the original question-that it is opposed to an extension of the arms race into outer space. The Minister for Foreign Affairs made this clear on a number of occasions and notably did so again recently at the University of Western Australia on 18 January. I am aware that the United States has investigated the feasibility of employing new and existing technologies for use in a defensive system against ballistic missiles. In addition to the vast expense that would almost certainly be involved, it is also generally agreed that the development of such a system is many years away if, indeed, it could be developed. I am not entirely sure whether that completely picks up all of the matters that Senator Chipp has raised, but I shall look again at the terms of his question and endeavour to give him an answer as soon as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I thank Senator Evans for that partial answer. Flowing out of it, I now ask, in the simplest of terms: Has the Department of Foreign Affairs or its Minister embraced the ultimate insanity of President Reagan of putting nuclear weapons into space? Secondly, what has been the Australian Government's reaction to that ultimate insanity?
—I do not think that, as a government, we are in the business of embracing insanity in any form, no matter by whom it is perpetrated.
—Nor do you denounce it.
—I will refer Senator Chipp's question to the appropriate Minister to see whether he is in a mood for denunciation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology. I refer the Minister to a report in the West Australian of 9 January relating to a wave power discovery by researchers of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation in Western Australia and in particular to the statements by Dr Allison that:

Now it is up to some industrial development company to take it further if they think the idea has potential.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science and Technology has not provided me with a brief on this matter; so it is quite possible that his attention has not yet been drawn to the very interesting developments covered in Senator Coleman's question. —My question is addressed to the Attorney-General. As members of the Federal judiciary are involved in the judgment of cases affecting State responsibilities, will the Attorney-General take steps to ensure that the Attorneys-General of the States are satisfied that the judge named in the transcripts of the Age tapes has committed no impropriety that could, in their view, prejudice the exercise of his responsibilities affecting the States?

—Senator Boswell's question seems to be premised on the same extraordinary assumptions as permeated the contributions to the debate, if it can be so described, of Mr Lane and Mr Jennings, his State Party colleages. There is no foundation for any such enterprise on the Commonwealth's part, and I do not propose to satisfy the expectations, lurid or otherwise, of Senator Boswell and those who pull the strings whenever he opens his mouth.

—I ask the Minister for Veterans' Affairs whether has has seen the letter about the assets test signed by Senator Walters and published recently in various newspapers, including today's issue of the Australian, suggesting Government compensation for ill-advised changes made by a constituent to her financial arrangements. Does Senator Walters have any grounds for her expressed delight at what she describes as the Government's backdown? Does she have any grounds for claiming compensation for her constituent?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of points I think should be made regarding the letter written by Senator Walters. The first is that her credentials as an investment adviser are, as most honourable senators would agree, less than compelling. I do not think she has any expertise at all in that area. Secondly and most importantly, if Senator Walters's constituent has a case for compensation it should be against the Opposition, not against the Government. It is the Opposition which has created the delay, the confusion and the concern in implementing a matter that was clearly spelt out in the Budget presented to the Parliament in August 1983. As to the suggestion that the Government has backed down, of course, that is Senator Walters's observation and clearly ignores what the Prime Minister, Senator Grimes and I have said on this matter. Surely the confusion can be traced to dishonesty and opportunism on the part of the Opposition. It does not have any issue on which to fight the Government, so it has been suggesting that many people will be affected as a result of the assets test.

ANSWER.PARA: Finally, I point out that the Government and expert investment consultants have consistently and repeatedly advised pensioners against investing their exempt assets in order to circumvent the test. The test was designed to encourage pensioners to invest their capital so as to have an adequate return on the funds they are able to invest at market interest rates. Any suggestion, therefore, which Senator Walters has made that there ought to be some examination of her constituent investing in furniture is a travesty of the legislation and has absolutely no bearing upon what should be the rights of pensioners properly to invest their surplus funds.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Attorney-General whether he recalls telling the Senate on 29 April 1980, as recorded on page 1924 of Hansard:

QUESTION.PARA: But the fact remains that the standards we require of our judiciary are higher than might be reasonable to require of anyone else.
Does he believe that the actions of the judge referred to in the Age tapes are consistent with such high standards?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the assumption, which is not accepted, that the material is authentic-I premise every remark about these tapes on that basis in case that is overlooked-I accept that the behaviour there revealed is not inconsistent with the standards appropriate to the occupancy of the judiciary. The context in which I made that statement in 1980, as I previously indicated to this Parliament, was the motion I moved in relation to the establishment of a parliamentary committee of inquiry, of the same order as that which I notice has been proposed by Senator Durack in a notice of motion today, to look at aspects of the affairs of the then Chief Justice, Sir Garfield Barwick, relating to his directorship of a private land and investment company called Mundroola Pty Ltd.

ANSWER.PARA: What was in issue in that affair, as I have said before to this place, was pre- emimently a question of bias in the conduct of judicial office. Questions were squarely raised about conflict of interest in the exercise of the judicial function, a conflict of interest arising from the fact that shares were held in at least three companies-CSR Ltd, Brambles and Ampol-by Sir Garfield Barwick's company, which companies were involved in litigation before the High Court in circumstances where the Chief Justice hearing and determining those cases failed utterly to put on record any disclosure of his interest in the matter or to disqualify himself, both of which are the only appropriate course of behaviour for a judge in those circumstances.

Nobody suggests that judges should be entirely isolated from commercial investments, any more than they should be entirely isolated from the rest of the world, socially or otherwise, but there are ground rules and standards of behaviour appropriate for members of the judiciary in the conduct of their judicial office. That, among other things, is what is involved in the concept of misbehaviour under the Constitution. It is that sort of behaviour and, in addition, criminal misconduct of a kind which is inappropriate for continued tenure of judicial office, that justifies parliamentary inquiry, but that is the only sort of thing that justifies parliamentary inquiry. Absolutely nothing in what I said in 1980 is inconsistent in any way with the position that I and the Government have taken on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. In view of the fact that the Minister is concerned with the effects of bombing and war disabilities, I refer him to the widely reported bomb outrage inflicted on a Family Court judge in Sydney yesterday. I ask whether there are any notable similarities with the bombing of his house in Caringbah which took place 13 years ago, almost to the day. Does the Minister have reason to believe that the perpetrator or perpetrators of this most recent outrage are more likely to be brought to justice than those responsible for the attack on him in 1971?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it was Senator Childs who asked me a question in the last session of Parliament about the rather dubious behaviour of a group of people who, whilst not identified, have subsequently been said to have been members of the defence forces. Had they been injured or in any way involved in bomb attacks, rifle fire or any other activity that created injury, of course they would have come within my jurisdiction as serving personnel eligible for pensions and compensation as a result of that sort of violent activity.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the other part of Senator Childs's question, I think it is something of a coincidence that 13 years ago, almost to the very day, and certainly to the very hour, a bomb was placed on my front step. It consisted of 17 sticks of gelignite , which I understand is a similar amount to that placed on Judge Gee's front steps. The only difference was that his house was demolished and mine was not. One aspect of the incident affecting me I found distasteful. Both Senator Murphy and Senator Anderson from the Government benches sent me messages of sympathy and support about the experience I had on that occasion. The State police, who in my view did a remarkable job of gathering evidence in respect of that matter, subsequently found that the then Liberal Attorney-General in New South Wales, the Hon. Mr McCaw, finally refused to prosecute the persons who the police claimed were responsible for that bomb outrage. One finds it very difficult to understand the double standards about corruption and law and order that seem to emanate from those who want to gain government in New South Wales. When they have the opportunity to do something about crime they refuse to act.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Attorney-General to the fact that widespread publication has been given to the naming in the Queensland Parliament of a judge as the judge referred to in the Age tapes. Does the Attorney-General deny the allegation which has been made in the Queensland Parliament?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already indicated on numerous occasions that the Government will not release the names of any of the persons supposedly involved in these tapes, nor confirm nor deny any allegations which may be made about the identity of people in State parliaments. It has become very evident indeed in recent days that the Opposition has the material in its possession-or a substantial proportion of it-that was published in the Age. So much was evident from the deafening silence with which the Opposition leadership responded to Senator Chipp's challenge in this chamber a couple of nights ago to respond affirmatively or negatively to the suggestion that the Opposition had this material. So much is also very evident from John Howard's contribution to the radio program PM when he was debating the subject with me last night.

ANSWER.PARA: If the Opposition is so keen to have the names of the people in question on the public record then it is up to the Opposition to do its own dirty work and put those names on the public record as it knows perfectly well what the names are. I make no concession that the names in question are in any way authentic in the sense of the conversations having occurred. But to the extent that names have been bandied around they are within the knowledge of the Opposition. If members of the Opposition want to go on with the job in this debate, rather than hiding behind the skirts of the thugs-if that is not a mixed metaphor-in State parliaments, then that is a matter for them. I note the rather neat description of the role of the Opposition in this respect in the report by Greg Hywood and Robert MacDonald in the Australian Financial Review this morning when they said:
The Opposition appears to be attempting to play a double game of pushing the issue into prominence to help the coalition in the NSW election but staying ' clean'-
the inverted commas are very appropriate-
by not naming names without evidence of wrongdoing.

There is no way in which the Opposition can stay clean as a result of its performance and conduct in this matter. Given the way it has behaved in this matter, whether or not it comes forward with the names in question, there is no way in which it will be able to redeem its reputation in the minds of the great mass of honest and decent Australians who regard as quite contemptible the way in which the Opposition is trying to misuse this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Attorney-general to the report on this morning's Australian Broadcasting Corporation news of the views expressed by a Queensland Government back bencher, Mr Jennings, to the effect that the Queensland Parliament should exercise its alleged constitutional right to establish its own inquiry into allegations against a judge named in that Parliament yesterday. What is the Government's response to this proposal for a Queensland parliamentary inquiry?
—A man who was thrown out of the Liberal Party in Victoria.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —No one will be surprised to learn that the constitutional views of Mr Jennings expressed in the Queensland Parliament can only be described as constitutional codswallop. The situation is that an inquiry by State parliaments would be a quite unconstitutional intrusion into Federal affairs. State parliaments do not have any powers or role in relation to Federal judges and their capacity as members of the Federal judiciary any more than they have powers in relation to the conduct of Federal Parliament or, for that matter , the actions of the Federal Executive. Any steps at all in that direction and particularly in the direction of the purported inquiry into the judiciary would, of course, be a grave threat to the independence of the Federal judiciary. The findings of such an inquiry would have no legal standing or force of any kind.

ANSWER.PARA: It is interesting to note in passing the identity of the persons who are responsible for these suggestions. As I think Senator Robert Ray indicated in an interjection a few moments ago, Mr Jennings was thrown out of the Liberal Party in Victoria for treachery, for betraying the secrets of his own Party room. Mr Lane, the Minister, whose bravery has precipitated his appearance on the front page of the nation's newspapers this morning is, of course, the turncoat, the man who switched parties for the price of a ministry just a few short months ago .

It is also worth recalling just how reminiscent the present events in the Queensland Parliament are of that infamous occasion in 1975, just four days before the Federal election in that year, when a special one-day sitting was called of the Queensland Parliament in order to enable Mr Bjelke-Petersen, the then Premier-he is still Premier regrettably-to make outrageous, never substantiated and never subsequently pursued, allegations of serious criminal misconduct against Ministers in the Whitlam Government. Here we go it seems all over again.

I conclude by saying that Mr Lane apparently said: 'All that is needed to be a Federal Attorney-General is a seven-inch whitewash brush'. I indicate, as I said in my statement last night, that it would need a darn sight bigger brush than one seven inches wide to whitewash Mr Lane and his colleagues in the Queensland Parliament. The standard equipment of any Minister in the Bjelke-Petersen Government is not so much a brush but a large bucket full of excrement. That Government should be treated with exactly the contempt that it deserves.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Attorney-General, arises out of answers the Attorney gave earlier today to Senator MacGibbon and Senator Sir John Carrick. I ask: Who was the solicitor who made representations to the then Attorney-General, Senator Murphy, for the return of the passport to Mr Sala ? What views did Interpol express when those representations were received by the Government in regard to returning the passport to Mr Sala?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know who the individual solicitor was in that case who made the representations but the telegram on the record which seeks the immediate release and deportation-not the return of the passport but the release and deportation-of the person in question, was the Sydney firm of Morgan Ryan and Brock. Of course, the reason why the Age and everybody else has got so excited and why this piece of scuttlebutt has emerged is the naming of Mr Morgan Ryan, whether accurately or not, in various other places around the nation in recent days. ANSWER.PARA: The question, however, in that case is what the situation was at the time that the person in question was in custody without having been the subject of any charge-a charge which could have been laid at any time if there had been a reasonable suspicion. The law is such that such charges can be made. No doubt the circumstances are such that an order for the remand in custody of the person could have been obtained from a court. Apparently the police were not prepared to go so far, on the basis of the information available to them, and in accordance with quite familiar practice of the application of legal principles, the man in question was released from custody in circumstances which I have already explained. I can appreciate the enthusiasm of members of the Opposition, aided and abetted by some encouragement, I notice, from members of the media this morning, to pursue this matter because it appears to them, quite clearly by now, that there is no substance whatever in any of the other allegations that they are pursuing. TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call Senator Bolkus I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's gallery of former Senator O'Byrne, former Senator Bishop and former Senator Cavanagh. —Is the Minister for Industry and Commerce aware of a recent report which finds that commercial motor vehicles could be economically produced within Australia under a pre-determined local content plan which would provide a level of 30 per cent protection? Is the Minister in a position to state the Government's response to this report?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been a lot of rumouring that there is a report from the Bureau of Industry Economics on this topic. That is not so. Senator Bolkus at least will recall that in November of last year I set up a Car Industry Council which was representative of the various interests in relation to the car industry to examine a number of questions relating to the industry. In the course of that Council's deliberations a report was commissioned from PA Australia, management consultants, to look into the question of the possible manufacture of light commercial vehicles in Australia and the feasibility of such manufacture. The consultants came down with a report which was dependent on a number of questions. That report was appended to the report of the Car Industry Council which was published on 14 December.

ANSWER.PARA: The report had a number of qualifications in it. It in fact said that there should be only one manufacturer if light commercial vehicles were manufactured here; that there would have to be re-badging by other planned producers and acceptance by the market of a re-badged series of models; and that there would have to be protection involving quotas to limit imports to 30 per cent of the market and duties ranging from 35 per cent in respect of local assembly, going up to 67 per cent in respect of local manufacture if local manufacture were to take place. Since the Car Industry Council brought down its report, with the report of the management consultants appended to it, that question has been under consideration by the Government in the context of its review of the post- 1984 passenger vehicle policy. I hope that an announcement will be made within the next few weeks on all those matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Health aware of the latest data presented for publication in the Medical Journal of Australia showing that 21 per cent of 13-year-old girls smoke regularly and that by the age of 15 years this figure climbs to 38 per cent for girls and 32 per cent for boys? Has he read the claim by TV Week to advertisers that young teenagers are prime weekly targets for fashion, cosmetics, skin care, jewellery, perfume and travel? Is he aware that the most advertised product inTV Week is tobacco? What does the Minister intend to do to protect children who may respond to the advertisement in last week's issue of TV Week which invites readers of all ages to write in for two free packets of Camel cigarettes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I am not aware of the data to which Senator Jack Evans refers which he says is for publication in the Medical Journal of Australia. To my knowledge it has not appeared there yet. Perhaps he gets an early edition of that august journal; I do not. I certainly am not surprised at the sorts of figures that he quotes. The only thing that surprises me in these figures ever is that young girls smoke more than young boys. I have been assured by many of my colleagues that young girls are smarter than young boys, but in this instance they do not seem to be. This has been a problem. We have all been aware in this place of the fact that more teenagers are smoking, whereas those of us who are getting closer to impending dissolution are giving it up. I give it up every day . We have always been concerned about this increase in smoking, particularly the increase in the rate of smoking by young girls. This matter has caused the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare considerable concern. Senator Evans will know that advertising of tobacco in the print media in this country is subject to a voluntary code that is monitored by the Department of Health. I am one of those people-and I think he is too-who are not very satisfied with the way in which that voluntary code operates. ANSWER.PARA: As for the advertisements in TV Week and the offer for people to send away for a couple of packets of Camel cigarettes, I would suggest, first of all, that that is clearly contrary to the voluntary code in that it makes no distinction between age groups. Nor can it make any distinction between age groups. I suggest that the company that is doing this is quite irresponsible. TV Week, like all journals of that type, relies heavily on tobacco advertising. I believe that the nature of that advertising should be looked at more carefully by the State authorities who in fact license those journals for distribution. I believe , in the end, that the voluntary code is not sufficient. If we are to retain the advertising of cigarettes in the print media, the State and Federal Ministers will have to legislate to ensure that that code is complied with, but that is a matter for discussion between State and Federal authorities. In the meantime, the Department of Health will continue its monitoring role, but I suppose that until it has teeth to take some action insofar as that monitoring is concerned we will have the difficulties Senator Evans has pointed out today. TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women aware of the concern of the Women's International Zionist Organisation that extraneous political issues which emerged during the mid-term World Conference of the United Nations Decade for Women might recur and perhaps mar the 1985 World Conference in Nairobi to mark the end point of the decade?

—I am aware of the concern expressed by the Women's International Zionist Organization on that matter. Indeed, I have heard informally other expressions of concern by women and women's organisations throughout Australia who do wish to see the end of decade conference devoting itself to matters of central concern to women. Our Government certainly wishes to see the important work of the World Conference to mark the end of the United Nations Decade for Women not side-tracked by a focus on political issues which are not central to the important goals of the United Nations Decade for Women and which are more appropriately dealt with in other international forums. Our Government will be making every effort to ensure that such issues do not distract the 1985 conference in Nairobi from its primary task of reviewing achievements in the decade and developing forward-looking strategies for further action by the United Nations and other member states. Australia will continue to work to maintain the consensus which is developed internationally on measures to advance the status of women in all countries.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COUNTRY WOMEN'S ASSOCIATION: MOBILE OUTBACK SUPPORT TEAM

In view of the demonstrated importance of this type of project to people in isolated areas, will the Minister undertake to give this submission a high priority? Can the Minister indicate when a decision on the submission will be available?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I can confirm that the Queensland Country Women's Association has applied for a mobile outback support team to be established in central-western Queensland similar to the one which was established at Mount Isa for north-west Queensland in the past. As Senator Martin will know, the sponsorship of the Mount Isa project has recently been changed by me on behalf of the Government because of some difficulties which occurred. These difficulties, I believe, were largely the result of defects in the manner in which the sponsorship contract was established and not necessarily due to any behavioural problems of either the people employed or the organisation employing the group. As a result of that change, the Government offered the Queensland Country Women's Association the opportunity to establish one or more outback support teams. ANSWER.PARA: I have ascertained today that at the moment discussions are going on between the Department and the Queensland CWA as to the details of the establishment of that group. QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DAMMING AND DIVERSION OF NORTHERN NEW SOUTH WALES RIVERS

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Resources and Energy been drawn to a series of letters to newspaper editors from a Mr Jack Beale advocating the damming and diversion inland of northern New South Wales rivers? Is he aware of Mr Beale? Has Mr Beale always advocated the policy that he now advocates?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Beale could be fairly described as a tireless Press correspondent. He has had dozens of letters published in the last 12 months or so advocating the damming and diversion inland of the coastal flowing northern New South Wales rivers. He has received particularly extensive coverage from that rusty flagship of the Murdoch fleet, the Australian, which has published no fewer than three letters from Mr Beale in the last five or six weeks including, I add, a reply to a letter of mine which was not itself published. I was advised very recently by that newspaper that it is not a good idea to send letters to it by telex because it was suggested to me that the three letters I had sent had all been lost because they were sent by telex-an act of carelessness and an oversight for which I suppose I should apologise.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Beale is a former New South Wales State Liberal Party politician. He was at one stage the Minister for Conservation in the Government of Sir Robert Askin. In that capacity he issued on 7 February 1968-this is most pertinent to Senator McIntosh's question-a Press statement headed: 'Coastal Diversions Inland Uneconomic'. In the Press statement, among other things, he stated:
The time is opportune to put this matter--
that is, the diversion of coastal flowing rivers-
in proper perspective, otherwise agitation for inland diversions might become a barrier to effective water development in this state.
The most economic water projects are those already included in the state government's water plan.
He also stated:

Those propositions have all been contradicted by Mr Beale's recent statements on this subject. I suppose two conclusions are possible from the reversal of opinion that he has displayed. One is that when he was actually charged with directing public expenditure he was more rational and responsible than he now is . The other, I suppose is, that the years have taken toll of his cerebral capacity.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry and Commerce. Is the Government considering recommendations that a tariff be imposed on imported tractors, which will mean a cost of millions of dollars to Australian primary producers? Does the Minister realise that if the Government were to accept a 15 per cent tariff on imported tractors, as it did in the case of imported grain harvesters last year, the cost to primary industry would be about $43m? Will the Minister give an assurance that the Government does not intend to penalise the rural industry by imposing a tariff on imported tractors?

—I do not recall whether the Industries Assistance Commission is considering the question of a tariff or some other duty on imported tractors. I assure the honourable senator that I am not considering it. I suppose that the answer to the question is that I am not considering, and the Government is not considering, the question of the imposition of a tariff on tractors. I am asked whether I will give an unqualified undertaking that, if the Government ever considers the question of the imposition of a tariff on tractors, no such tariff will be imposed. The answer to that question is no. I say to the honourable senator that we must all do our best to make up our minds about issues on an informed basis. I will try to do that. It may be that the conclusion we will reach in making up our minds on an informed basis is that there should be no such duty on tractors. But until we are in that position, I will not go into the realms of spooky speculation for the gratification of ill-informed members of the National Party in the outback of Queensland.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. I refer to the report recently published by the Bureau of Labour Market Research entitled 'Retired, Unemployed or at Risk'. Will the Minister give some indication of whether he is giving consideration to measures to assist the older group of unemployed people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have read the report by the Bureau of Labour Market Research concerning, largely, the older unemployed. It is certainly a valuable addition to information on the labour market experience of older workers, highlighting developments which have occurred in the last decade or so concerning individuals in this area. In particular, the report looks at the reasons for the decline in the labour force participation of older workers which has occurred over this time. Among the reasons for the decline over the last decade are voluntary early retirement over the period and the increasing numbers of discouraged older workers who have left the work force because of the economic downturn. The report also notes that while unemployment for this group is low compared with young unemployed workers-part of that is due to the discouraged worker effect- the duration of unemployment for older workers is almost twice as long as the average. That is in many cases a tragedy and certainly very unsatisfactory.

ANSWER.PARA: The findings of the inquiry raise a number of important concerns that must be under consideration by the Government and, I suggest, should be under consideration by everyone in the community. As the report states, the economic recession has played a large part in the declining labour force participation of older people. In many cases, when older workers who have been retrenched find it extremely difficult to find another job, they frequently seek other means of support through not only unemployment benefit but also in some cases invalid pensions and other forms of social security payments. The best way we can overcome this situation is, of course, to increase employment in this area. Nevertheless, consideration must be given to whether the unemployment situation warrants special attention for this group. The sorts of things we could look at would include increasing the unemployment benefit to people in this age group. Certainly the Government is committed to raising the unemployment benefit to close the gap between that benefit and the standard rate of pensions which has dropped considerably since 1978. We made the first steps immediately on coming to government and we continued to take steps in the last Budget in this regard. The difficulty faced by older people when leaving their employment is that they frequently find they are faced with high rents and high fixed costs. The question is whether we should not assist them further through increased public housing and increasing the supplementary assistance available to them. We certainly need to look at easing the work test for unemployed people in this age group whose skills are no longer appropriate or whose strength is no longer capable of enabling them to compete in the work force.

Finally, we should all consider whether the trend to early retirement should be encouraged. There are some in the community who argue that we should give more active encouragement to people to retire and that this will in fact give increased job opportunities to younger people. Conversely, there are those who argue that further encouragement to people to retire early would result in a net loss of jobs and commit the Government to substantial additional costs in pensions for the retired which might be of particular concern given the prospective ageing of the population. Obviously this is a difficult issue. It is an issue that governments of all persuasions will have to face. As I have noted, the best thing we can do is to continue the present Government's policies of increasing economic recovery and the number of people in the work force. In view of this the Government will have to continue giving special consideration to this area. I urge the Opposition to give sensible consideration to this area rather than to the nitpicking that has gone on in the past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to make a personal explanation which I think arises naturally out of Question Time yesterday. In answering the questions yesterday from Senator Hill on the Sala case I made an inadvertent slip at one point in my narrative which I take the opportunity now to correct. The correction does not in any way alter the substance of my answer or the conclusions which I expressed. According to the Hansard pinks which I checked this morning, what I said was:

SPEECH.PARA: The files are noted with the comments of senior departmental officers in the Attorney-General's Department stating that they agreed with the course of action proposed by the Attorney-General.

Having now checked the files in question and Mr Menzies' report-which I did not have in front of me at the time I was giving the answer-a more precisely accurate statement would have been as follows: The files are noted with the comments of a senior departmental officer in the Attorney-General's Department stating that another more senior officer agreed with the course of action proposed by the Attorney-General although the first officer did not.

There were, as I indicated in my reply-certainly in my reply today-and perhaps a little more clearly in my letter to Mr Steele Hall, a number of disagreements within the bureaucracy at the time as to the way the matter should best have been handled. No doubt, as I said again today, that is why the story has surfaced now as it has. The disagreement within the Attorney-General's Department was not, however, of any particular significance. The more senior officer concerned who agreed with the Minister's decision, was Mr Frank Mahony, then Deputy Secretary of the Attorney-General's Department and one of the best known and most widely respected men in the whole Commonwealth Public Service then, as now. His recollections, when he was interviewed by Mr Menzies, were consistent with the notation of his views-that is, of his agreement at the time.

The less senior officer involved who disagreed at the time, Mr A. R. Watson, then a Senior Assistant Secretary in the Department, was also recently interviewed by Mr Menzies. The following quotes from Mr Menzies' report to me record Mr Watson's present views. These are:
While the recollections of [the former Minister]-
as I said today, the then Senator Murphy-

and Mr Watson are not identical, there is no significant inconsistency between them. Mr Watson adds that [the former Minister's] attitude to the case was consistent with that he displayed in a number of other cases, namely a strong concern that a person should not be kept in prison for any longer than was abolutely necessary.
The report continued a little further down:
Mr Watson's attitude to the decision now in question was that, while he disagreed with it, he recognised that it was within the Attorney-General's discretion and he saw no impropriety in it.

I thought it appropriate, given the concern, quite properly, of the Opposition to ensure complete accuracy in these matters, that I correct the record even though, as I repeat, that makes no substantial difference whatsoever to the character of the answer that I gave on this matter yesterday or, indeed, to the character of the answers I gave today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition from moving forthwith the following motion:

That the Senate censures the Attorney-General for his handling of the Age tapes , and in particular his persistent refusal to provide information to the Parliament in order that it might properly perform its role in matters relating to the Judiciary.

I have not yet had an indication from the Government, which has only just heard of this motion, as to whether it agrees to the suspension of Standing Orders. I therefore wish to address the question as to why the Opposition believes this motion of censure of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) should be brought on now. I am sure there is absolutely no doubt in anybody's mind that this is a matter of very great importance. It is a matter which has raised very considerable issues. It is a matter which has attracted a great deal of public attention. One of the issues which have been raised goes to the behaviour of someone who is described in the original reports as a senior judge. Subsequently , it has been identified that the person referred to is a senior federal judge. Therefore, the matter is one which goes to an important aspect of the Government 's administration of Australia. The Opposition has made it quite clear in a number of debates that it regards the activities and approach of the Attorney- General as unsatisfactory in a number of respects. The Attorney-General, for his part, has made his attitude clear by the sending off of the tapes debate until after the New South Wales election. He has made it quite clear that he believes that the decisions which he has taken are decisions which he is entitled to substitute for the decisions which are properly those of the Parliament. The Opposition does not regard that as satisfactory and believes that there are important issues of the role of Parliament in this matter and of the rights of Parliament. The Opposition has persisted in its attempts to get informaion from the Attorney-General. It has sought to use Question Time and it has made quite specific requests of the Attorney-General, which have been refused. It has requested from him the transcripts which are the basis on which he has been able to make his judgment. It has sought from him the transcripts which have been the basis on which counsel he has retained have been able to make judgments. Those documents have not been available to us and hence we, the people who have the constitutional responsibility in this matter, are left to rely upon the newspaper reports on which the public is also left to rely.

The Opposition does not regard that as satisfactory. It has sought from the Attorney-General the assistance of an aide-memoire which he told us was prepared of two conversations between him and the judge who has been named in the tapes. In a throw-away line the Attorney-General, at the tail end of a debate two days ago, offered to make that aide-memoire available. He made that offer on the run in debate. He said that it was an offer that had previously been made to the Opposition, which he later conceded it had not. He made the offer on the basis that the aide-memoire should be available only on a private basis to those to whom it was given and that it could not be used. Clearly that is a ludicrous situation in which to leave the Senate when one bears in mind that our duty, the duty we are given under the Constitution, is to have the supervision of these matters. To suggest that a number of honourable senators holding whatever office could take this information from the Attorney-General and then agree not to use it if it was relevant to the duties of the Senate is obviously laughable.

The Opposition believes that this is becoming a matter of wide public concern. It has become the subject of discussion in another Parliament in Australia. Although attempts have been made to link the Opposition with that-attempts which are not based on fact at all-the fact is that public discussion of these matters has been considerably widened by that event.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I am sorry to interrupt Senator Chaney, but the Democrats and the Senate will be called upon at any moment to vote on a very important substantial issue. Neither I nor any member of my Party have been paid the courtesy of being told what we are debating. —I certainly regret that Senator Chipp was not here when I moved the motion. I am very happy to repeat it. The motion states:

—I am speaking to the suspension of Standing Orders and the reason why the Opposition believes this is a matter which should be brought before the Parliament today. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition seeks to suspend Standing Orders in order to bring forward this censure motion as a matter of some urgency. There are two elements to the censure motion. One is the censure of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans ) for his 'handling' of the Age tapes incident, and the second is his refusal to supply information. I think the two elements have to be distinguished a little one from the other.
