Motion of Censure

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate censures the Attorney-General for his handling of the Age tapes , and in particular his persistent refusal to provide information to the Parliament in order that it might properly perform its role in matters relating to the Judiciary.

I move that motion after another Question Time during which the Opposition sought information from the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans), information which it believes it legitimately requires to do its duty in this matter, and when again it was refused information by the Attorney. I think that the judgments which could be made on the substance of this matter need to be considered, because in all of the argument, all of the political argy-bargy that goes on in this place, it is terribly easy to overlook the substance of what it is we are talking about. I think the substance was raised by Senator Townley in a question he asked today. Senator Townley asked the Attorney-General a question , quoting the Attorney-General in the course of it. Senator Townley said:
I ask the Attorney-General whether he recalls telling the Senate on 29 April 1980 as recorded on page 1924 of Hansard:
But that fact remains that the standards we require of our judiciary are higher than might be reasonable to require of anyone else.
Does he believe that the actions of the judge referred to in the Age tapes are consistent with such high standards?

The answer that the Attorney gave was that he thought that the behaviour of the judge as disclosed in the tapes 'was not inconsistent with those standards'. In other words, his view is that what is disclosed in the tapes is consistent with the standards required. The point is that the Attorney-General made it abundantly clear today that in his view what has been disclosed is consistent with the standards which are required of the judiciary. The Opposition does not have access to some material because it has sought it from the Attorney and it has been refused. What the Opposition has is the access which has been granted to the Australian people by a combination of-one can only guess at it-presumably policemen and the Age newspaper. But the Age newspaper first brought these matters to the Commonwealth Government's attention and first brought them to the attention of the Australian people.
I remind the Senate of what is said to be the contents of the tapes in so far as they relate to the judge, because that is all we have to go on.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are just a merchant of smear.

—This is what apparently the Attorney-General is saying is consistent with the standards required of the judiciary. I quote exactly from what has been reported in the Age because that is the source that I have. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: A senior judge and a solicitor discussed trying to publicly denigrate a former leading Federal Government figure, who was being considered for a senior public position.
The plan has been revealed in secret police tape recordings of telephone conversations between the judge and the solicitor . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about Ellicott's and Sankey's association. Let us talk about Judge Ellicott and Sankey.

—I note that in all this concern on the other side about smearing , they are quite happy to call out names by way of interjection. The first allegation is that a senior judge and a solicitor had a discussion about trying to publicly denigrate a former leading Federal Government figure who was being considered for a senior public position. That apparently is not inconsistent with the standards that this Attorney-General expects of the judiciary. The Age goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: On one occasion the judge complained that the solicitor 'had done nothing about ' a Sydney suburban alderman and suggested that the alderman frequented 'one of these gay restaurants, where all these homosexuals hang out'.
Again that appears to be a matter which, in the view of the Attorney, can either be explained away or is not inconsistent with the standards he expects or requires. It goes on to say:
The telephone taps reveal that the judge promised to ask a prominent New South Wales Government figure to help secure a highly paid Public Service job for a man connected with the solicitor.
Later the report says:
A police summary of the transcripts says that it appears that the solicitor organised women for the judge 'when times permit'. . . .
There is more in the report. I merely wish--
Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the Opposition has moved a very serious motion and I ask that he be heard in silence.

—I merely wish to point out that that is the information which has been put before the Australian people not by the Opposition but by the Age newspaper on the basis of information which it has and the veracity of which it has made efforts to satisfy itself about. We have had from the Attorney-General an explanation which does not amount in any way to a denial of these matters. At best it could be described as an explanation. With respect to some conversations he says that detail cannot be provided because of legal professional privilege. With respect to others he says that the context throws a different light on the matter. But the important point, and the reason why the Opposition is dissatisfied and believes that the Attorney-General has not done his duty in this matter, is that the Attorney-General has not provided for us the information on which he claims to make that judgement.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no dispute in this chamber about the fact that it is the duty of this Parliament to deal with these matters. That is accepted by all those who have given an opinion on it. The fact is that the Attorney-General has received this material. He has gone behind the material to some extent. He has had a couple of discussions with the judge concerned. He has not given Parliament the detail of that. He has said: 'On the basis of the additional information I have it is my judgment that there is no misbehaviour within the meaning of the Constitution and, therefore, the information should not be provided to the Parliament as has been requested'. We see a fundamental fallacy in the approach adopted by the Attorney-General. Within the last day he has said in this Parliament: 'I agree that this is a matter for the Parliament and, if it makes a decision, that decision is not justiciable'. In other words, it is not a matter for the courts. It is not a matter for lawyers. It is a matter for this Parliament. He says no more than that perhaps in some marginal case there might be a chance to interfere. I understand that the high point of the Government's claim that this is a matter for the courts would be the view put forward by, I think, Senator Tate that in some cases there may be some power for the courts to interfere. But in general the Attorney has taken the view that this is a matter for the Parliament and that it is not justiciable-it is not for the courts.

That is also, I believe, in the ultimate the view that one gets from the opinions which have been proffered by the Attorney-General in support of his position. I quoted yesterday from the opinion of Mr Temby, I think on page 2, where he said that this is a matter for the Parliament. The opinion of Mr Griffith, the Solicitor-General, the second law officer of the Commonwealth, is that this is a matter for the Parliament. The opinion of Professor Lane that I quoted yesterday was that it was a matter for the Parliament. It is everybody's opinion that it is a matter for the Parliament. Yet it is not the Parliament which has been given the material on which to make a judgment but the Attorney- General and his advisers. If that cannot be seen to be a false position, a fictitious position, a position which cannot be sustained, I think we have lost sight of logic in this place. It is no use conceding, on the one hand, that it is the responsibility of this place and of the House of Representatives and, on the other hand, saying: 'I am sorry, the material cannot be made available to you. It has been made available to two lawyers'-no matter how learned the lawyers-'and they say that on their reading of it there is no misbehaviour'.

The weakness of that position is borne out by the fact that even those lawyers have not had the benefit of all the information available to the Attorney- General. We are told, for example, that they have not had the advantage of the detail of any conversations that he has had with the judge. But that does not really matter. The simple fact, and the complaint of the Opposition, is that the Attorney-General has adopted a position inconsistent with the Australian Constitution and with the responsibilities vested in this Pariament. We censure the Attorney-General for that and we censure him for his persistent refusal to provide information to the Parliament in order that it might properly perform its role in matters relating to a question about the judiciary.

A debating point has been made by Senator Chipp. Senator Chipp is an old campaigner in this place and I have not lost my admiration for his ability to find a quick debating point and to make it well. But two days ago when the Opposition sought by parliamentary motion to get the information it required from the Government we saw an inconsistent performance on the part of the Australian Democrats. Our motion was quite clear. What was sought by the Opposition at that time? The Opposition sought the tapes and the transcripts- those two bodies of material on which others have been called upon to make a judgment. We sought them with one reservation. We said that they should be treated; that the names should be deleted so that privacy could be preserved. We asked for the removal of names. We asked-although not in those terms-for a sort of sanitisation.
Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —All this baying is for naught. If the information is not to be provided properly, it is the way of these things that the sort of campaign that has developed will occur. The fact is that the Government is having to be dragged screaming to the point where it admits anything. I have very little confidence that the Government would have done anything at all were it not for the publication by the Age of these matters. To go back to the motion, let me stick to the cold, hard facts as they occurred. We moved a motion which asked the Government to produce those tapes and transcripts and that they be sanitised , to use the Attorney-General's expression. We wanted them to be available to us so that we could do the job that the Constitution gives to us. What did the Democrats do? Let us quietly examine and analyse that. Before dinner the Democrats moved an amendment. They moved that a word should be inserted so that the motion related not to the typed material, the transcripts, but solely to the recording. They said that we should get the transcripts plus authenticated recordings.
—And genuine.

—Authenticated and genuine recordings. That matter was quite clear, because the point was made not only in the Senate chamber but also in discussion. I do not think there is any argument that the original proposition of the Democrats was merely to place some restriction on the tapes, those very important pieces of evidence, because there are a limited number of conversations which can be subject to some aural checking.
—What a terrible thing to do-ask for authentic tapes!

—Quite. The first point taken by the Democrats was that only that should be made available. We had reservations about that for the simple reason that the Attorney-General, of course, is quick to claim doubts about authenticity whenever he wants to keep something from us. That is an argument which will be very hard to settle, whether we have a parliamentary inquiry or however this matter is dealt with. But when the Democrats came back after dinner they adopted a quite different stance. They adopted a stance which said that all of the material was to be subject to this restriction which originally they tried to impose only on the tapes.
—Because you changed the wording of your motion; now be honest.
—Order! I ask that the Leader of the Opposition be heard in silence.

—I will not be accused of dishonesty in this matter by Senator Chipp, because the amendment that we had before us was an amendment which was discussed and an amendment was proposed with respect to a particular part of it, and subsequently that amendment was widened by the Democrats. The reason that the Opposition did not accept that was that we believed that the Democrats' amendment provided the Government with a semi-permanent if not a permanent out from ever providing material to the Parliament. We believed that it would leave the Attorney-General and the Government far too much room to manoeuvre, far too much opportunity simply to say: 'We will not provide material because we, the Government, are not satisfied as to its authenticity'. We believe that if there are questions of authenticity to be determined-I accept that there are-those questions need to be considered by the Parliament, too, and not merely by the Attorney-General and his officers. We do not agree that the responsibilities of this Parliament in that respect or in other respects can be lifted off our shoulders and assumed by some all-wise, all-benevolent Attorney-General, and we certainly do not believe that that can be done while Senator Gareth Evans is the Attorney-General.

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the attempt that we made last week-it was frustrated by the Government and, indeed, frustrated with the help of the Democrats-to get access to the material which was provided by the Attorney-General to the lawyers he has chosen to advise him, has left us in a situation in which, as a parliament, we have an inability to make the judgments which our duty requires and which the Constitution requires. If the Democrats claim that in some way we were rejecting material on the tapes two days ago, I would suggest to them that that is a simple misreading of history and that they should examine Hansard, in which they will find that the position is as I have outlined. The position as I have outlined would have left us with no guarantee whatever that this Government would ever have produced the information which was sought.

I have made the point that these are matters of great seriousness. I would not wish to minimise the fact that they are matters of great difficulty and awkwardness. I do not envy the Attorney-General his having to deal with the matters. I agree that they are difficult and delicate. But perhaps they are not difficult and delicate for everyone. A number of people have been publicly named in this matter. When I switched on AM this morning, I was very struck when I heard one of the people who have been named come out and give a simple and forthright denial. That is a course which is open to anyone. This morning a man who many honourable senators present will say was smeared in the Queensland Parliament last night, and many honourable senators will be very unhappy at his name having been mentioned in that Parliament, came out and said: 'That is a rotten thing and it isn't true'. I believe that that is a very good and straightforward response; because if something is not true, it should be denied. That is not a bad starting point in the defence of this sort of thing. If people believe that they have been wrongly accused, let them deny it.

The fascinating thing about what this Attorney-General has done over the last seven days is that he has never made a denial. He has not made the simple denial that would have been possible if that was open to him. The Attorney-General has admitted that when he went to see the judge he did not even ask him, having given him a copy of the tape: 'Is that you on the tape? Is that a conversation that occurred?' I ask the Attorney-General in what capacity he went to see the judge, and I still do not know what the answer is. Did he go as a friend, as a confidante, as an Attorney-General, as a prosecutor or as a policeman?

TALK.START.PARA: —As an Attorney-General, you twerp.
—He went, we are told, 'As an Attorney-General, you twerp'. I acknowledge the interjection, and I reciprocate.
—Sanctimonious twerp.
—Order! We will keep the debate within the terms of the Standing Orders.

—I am sorry, Mr President. I have the great difficulty that if I treat matters seriously, the Attorney-General complains, and if I treat them lightly he complains. I have found that there is only one way to please the Attorney-General and that is to praise him. I have no intention of praising him during this debate.
—That would really bury me.
—Order! I ask that the Leader of the Opposition be heard in silence.

—The simple point I am making is that some advice has been given to us by the Attorney-General on this matter, but what we have not had from him is any suggestion of a denial. At best we have had questions about the authenticity of the tape and explanations. What I heard this morning was a refreshing reminder of the fact that someone who is wronged can take the step and say: 'That was wrong'. That is something that we have yet to see in this place on the serious matters that I am trying to address today.

SPEECH.PARA: It is true that we have had a series of debates on this matter and that the Opposition's discontent with the behaviour of the Attorney-General has been detailed in part before. I have made it clear that we are concerned that the Attorney-General-and this is moving on to matters of lesser import and more of detail-chose to appoint as the Special Prosecutor in this matter a man with the very heavy task, the very onerous responsibility, of starting the new office of Director of Public Prosecutions. That concern is based partly on workload and partly on the fact that the two duties have a different statutory basis or statutory relationship vis-a-vis the Attorney-General. A matter that has been canvassed here is such that in one area Mr Temby will be subject to the direction of the Attorney-General and in the other he will not. We are concerned about that matter because we believe that in something that is as difficult and important as this, the Special Prosecutor should have no blurring of his independence by the merging of two roles.

We are concerned, and we have expressed this concern before, about the short time that was given to Mr Temby to give his opinion on a great bulk of material. It remains a significant point of difference between us and the Attorney-General . The Attorney-General can walk into this chamber, as he did a few months ago, and say: 'I am not relying on advice when I give the Senate this assurance. I am relying on the fact that I have read this material'. We find out later that he has read 700 pages in 20 minutes.

These are the sorts of matters which require long and careful consideration. We are concerned about the confusion in the Attorney's role when he saw the judge on two occasions. We are concerned at the Attorney's carelessness or his incompetence, whichever it is, in not seeking an answer to the simple direct question which could satisfy some of the doubts in this case, doubts which, in my view, he seems keen to foster. Why has the judge not been asked: 'Is that your voice on the tape? Is that a conversation which occurred? Is it a full record of a conversation which occurred?'

All of these are legitimate matters which go to the concern felt by the Opposition about the behaviour of the Attorney-General in this matter. At times it is difficult to separate out the irritation that the Attorney occasions by his behaviour in this place, which was referred to by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) in responding to the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders, but in this debate I have tried to separate out those personal idiosyncrasies of the Attorney-General, which are no more than annoying, from the complaints of real substance which we have about his performance. I have said before that the Attorney-General stands to be judged in a harsher light than his front bench colleagues. When we talk of the duties of Senator Grimes or of any of the Ministers opposite, we make judgments on them about their political, ministerial and parliamentary duties which allow for a fair amount of latitude. But it is certainly true that the judgments which are made of an Attorney-General are made on a narrower and much more defined basis. They are made on the basis that the Attorney-General has a special, peculiar role in government. He has a role to put aside the partisanship and the defence of his party and his government when there is any suggestion that that might be in conflict with the public duties that he has.

I and other senators have quoted over recent weeks the very famous words of Lord Shawcross. I quote them again because I think they go to the heart of the basis of our belief that the Attorney-General is worthy of censure. The Attorney -General is required to act in a way which gives prior regard not to the private interest, not to the party interest but to the public interest. Lord Shawcross said he had a duty-
. . . to be wholly detached, wholly independent and to accept the implications of an obligation to protect what he conceives to be the public interest whatever the political results may be.

It is in that very heavy duty that we see the Attorney-General having failed and it is for that reason that we have moved this motion of censure. We believe that the Attorney-General has not shown himself fit for the very high office which he holds.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call the Attorney-General, I point out that a most serious motion has been moved against him. As I requested silence for the Leader of the Opposition, I also request that the same courtesy be extended to the Attorney-General.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chaney tells me that I have lost the confidence of the Opposition. I wear that loss of confidence of the Opposition like a badge of honour. It suggests that, for all my notorious faults, I still at least possess some of those characteristics of common decency, respect for human rights, respect for privacy and respect for due process which are so conspicuously now lacking, if indeed they were ever present, in the Opposition and in particular its leadership.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Button has referred in his remarks on the procedural motion to the way in which members of the Opposition have been labouring mightily for the last six parliamentary days, trying desperately, although without, of course, dirtying their hands in the process, to build something to help themselves out of the dreadful political bind in which they now find themselves in New South Wales. Now it is the seventh day of their parliamentary labours. It seems that on the seventh day their feverish brains have now rested. Their moral sense has long since rested and their integrity has long since rested. Their integrity has not been evident at all in this parliamentary session. It is very clear from the terms of this motion that their brains, such rationality as they possessed, have rested as well.

The reality is that this censure motion not only lacks justification as to its basic substance but also in its formulation makes, as Senator Chipp very effectively said, no sense at all. One of the things for which I am being censured is my persistent refusal to provide information to the Parliament. I am censured for my refusal to provide information to the Parliament when the Opposition itself voted two days ago against the disclosure of information which it wanted. The Opposition, had it chosen to vote that way, could certainly have access to the aides-memoires. Certainly, it could have had access to the tapes and transcripts in question, or at least to so many of them as were authenticated. Certainly, the motion then before the Senate may have been less all-embracing than the one on which the Opposition had set its heart and mind but, equally certainly, there was a great deal of substance in the material referred to in the motion that was before the Parliament. I cannot do better than to put it in the way in which Senator Chipp put it when he referred to the quite grotesque hypocrisy, quite apart from everything else, unless it is sheer stupidity, that is involved in the terminology of this motion and the tactical genius that lies behind it.

Let me get down to the handling of this matter. Let me do so for the umpteenth time in this Parliament and repeat for the umpteenth time the points that have to be made to make clear that the Government's response and, I believe, my response have been consistent with the highest standards of government and, in my case, the highest standards which are appropriate to the first law officer of the nation. I readily concede, as I have done on previous occasions, that Senator Chaney is right when he says that higher standards or different standards are applicable to an Attorney-General than are applicable to Ministers generally. One not only has the political role of being a member of the government of the day but, at the same time, one is also responsible for the administration of justice and the maintenance of the integrity of the system of justice in this country. On occasions very difficult conflicts can arise, the most conspicuous example of which is perhaps that involving Mr Ellicott before me.

Allegations were made and have been responded to. They have been responded to both in the Executive domain and in this parliamentary forum. In both respects, I believe that that response has been perfectly appropriate. What has occurred at Executive level has been set out in full and elaborate length in my parliamentary statement-26 pages of it. It was one of the longer parliamentary statements, certainly in the lifetime of this Government and, I suspect, any government. It set out in complete detail, with nothing hidden, the sequence of events and series of steps that the Government had taken. The first was the immediate reference of the material to the Australian Federal Police. Secondly, when the preliminary report of the AFP came back that material and the accompanying police report were referred to an independent counsel, Mr Temby, QC , who is peculiarly well qualified by virtue of his background and his status as Director of Public Prosecutions designate to advise the Government on whether any Federal offences had been committed by anyone or pointed to by anyone in the material on the assumption of its authenticity and to advise the Government particularly on the question of whether anything in the material suggested proper grounds for action under section 72 of the Constitution relating to the misbehaviour of a judge.

Mr Temby advised accordingly a couple of days later. There has been a lot of sneering about the speed with which he responded to the Government's request. All I can say in that respect is that Mr Temby has not complained about being given that task. Senior barristers are well equipped to absorb a lot of material quickly and to respond quickly to requests of this kind. He was assisted by the Acting Crown Solicitor providing consultation and material assistance where necessary. He was assisted by the presence on the scene of the senior investigating officer from the AFP who was equally available to handle requests for the untangling of the material where there was doubt as to its contents, the indexing of it and so on. It was a prompt response and a very considered response nonetheless. It was a response moreover which, insofar as it made findings as to the proper law on the question of section 72 of the Constitution, was subsequently upheld in every significant respect by the Solicitor-General, who was asked as a further executive step by me shortly after receipt of Mr Temby's opinion to advise in a considered way, taking as much time as he needed, whether Mr Temby had got it right when he identified the criteria which were applicable to a parliamentary procedure for judicial misbehaviour under the Constitution.

The other executive step that was taken was the decision to refer the material with the wide-ranging terms of reference-not limited in any way-to Mr Temby in order that he could pursue those aspects of the material which might have given rise to or suggested the commission of Federal offences both as to the circumstances of the taping and as to other possible situations. That task force -a joint task force-has been created. It is working away quite effectively and vigorously at the moment under the independent supervision of Mr Temby, who now wears two statutory hats which are quite compatible with each other-that of Special Prosecutor with particular responsibilities in this matter and now that of Director of Public Prosecutions. That job will be done honestly, competently, vigorously and as soon as it can be done.

The other executive action which I took in this matter and about which I have been criticised was to visit the judge after I had received the police report and the first Temby report in order to give the judge the material in question as it affected him and to enable him to make such response to it as he chose to do. To act in this way was to act in accordance with what I believe are the finest principles of due process to enable the other side, as it were, to be heard in circumstances in which, as we all knew, there was every likelihood that the position of the judge would be called into question by those with various motives, high minded or unsavoury as the case may be. He was given an opportunity to be heard in circumstances which were deliberately formal and at arms length in character and which, I assure Senator Chaney, involved me acting as Attorney-General and in no other capacity. Just to complete that, I add that that step was taken, as I have said repeatedly, only after I was satisfied both by the police report and by Mr Temby's opinion, when specifically canvassed or sought from him, that to approach the judge in this way, to give him the material in this way, would not in any way prejudice any possible further criminal investigations which the police might be minded to make or which Mr Temby thought might be necessary. The other Executive action that was taken was, as I have already reported to the Parliament, the reference of certain parts of the material to the Special Prosecutor in Victoria, Mr Robert Redlich, and to Mr Justice Stewart under his continuing residual terms of reference in the Terence Clark matter and possibly also in relation to his present terms of reference relating to Nugan Hand. Further Executive action was taken to ensure that the New South Wales Government and police force were fully apprised of that part of the material which gave rise to possible suggestions of the commission of offences in that jurisdiction and which were otherwise quite outside the Commonwealth's competence.

As I have said over and over again, in every single respect the Government has acted promptly-it seems rather too promptly for Senator Durack, whose metabolism operates at a rather slower pace in these matters than the present Government's. It has acted promptly, responsibly, responsively and properly. I do not believe there can be any conceivable foundation for a censure motion based in whole, or even in part, upon the conduct of the Government and myself at an executive level. To suggest otherwise, to argue otherwise, is cant and humbug, I say to Senator Chaney.

The question then comes down to the parliamentary performance of the Government and of me in particular. That parliamentary performance is attacked wholly so far as it concerns the issue of the judge and the tapes. There has been complete indifference in the parliamentary forum to the 2,986 conversations which do not involve the judge. There are 11 conversations on the four tapes, only one of which involves the judge directly. All but 10, 11, 12-I still have not had time to count them-of the conversations or summaries of conversations in the written material, and there are just on 3,000 of those, do not involve the judge again. But that has not concerned members of the Opposition in this Parliament. They have concentrated wholly on the position of the judge, no doubt because they believe, for a variety of sordid motives, that there may be something in it politically for them. It is on that basis that I have responded.

The nub of the criticism comes down today on my failure to supply the information, not as it concerns everybody else in the Commonwealth who may have been named or in some other way purportedly identified in this material but as it comes down on the judge. We are told by Senator Chaney that the emphasis comes down on the judge because this is a peculiarly parliamentary responsibility to deal with on the question of misbehaviour. That is not a new suggestion. It is one that has been with us since day one and present to my mind since day one, which is why I asked Mr Temby and then subsequently the Solicitor -General to advise on this very question of how the material should be treated, bearing in mind Parliament's responsibility. At the end of the day the answers come down to this, and they are in two parts and have always been in two parts. I have repeated this part of the argument over and over again. I am perfectly prepared to accept, without having it dragged out of me in any way-it does not amount to an admission or concession; it is just a statement of, I believe, legal fact-that this Parliament has the decisive constitutional role in determining whether or not misbehaviour has occurred. I add the caveat, as I always have, that it may be in the case of a quite exceptional and spectacular misuse or abuse of parliamentary power that the judiciary would wish to retain some sort of residual capacity to come in over the top and second-guess the Parliament. That is in the realm of speculation.

On the face of it, this sort of question is not justiciable. On the face of it, it is Parliament's responsibility. True, true indeed, but what sort of responsibility does Parliament have? Here the point I have made, and made at the threshold every time I have risen to my feet on this matter, is that Parliament' s responsibility in relation to the judiciary is, and necessarily is, a very narrow one under the terms of the Constitution. It was recognised to be such by the founding fathers and is inherently such, given the language that they employed in the Constitution. The role of the Parliament is very much narrower than is the role of the United Kingdom Parliament when it comes to consideration of judicial misbehaviour. In the United Kingdom the authorities are perfectly clear that the Crown, the government of the day, the political majority of the day, has the power to remove of its own motion, without the necessity for any parliamentary intervention, a judge who has committed a crime that is incompatible with his continued membership of the Bench, or a judge who behaves in some other way improperly in the conduct of his judicial office. The government of the day has that power in Britain without reference to the Parliament. Parliament has a residual power for any other reason to pray for the removal of a judge or, by extension, the censuring, the admonition or, in some other way, the chastising of a judge on a whole variety of grounds that are well established and set out quite extensively in the book by Shetreet, which Senator Durack has recently discovered. It is a discovery it seems that he had not made in 1980, when I made my speech on Sir Garfield Barwick and made extensive reliance on the authority therein contained.

In Australia, Parliament's role is, by contrast with the British situation, a very much narrower one. In Australia, there is no basis on which the executive government itself can act alone to remove a judge whom it does not like or for whom it believes there is some ground for removal. That that is so was readily acknowledged by the founding fathers. Indeed, they wrote the Constitution in such a way to ensure that the executive government of the day would not have that power. The reason they did so was because Australia is a Federal system-God help us-and it operates under a written constitution with an inbuilt separation of powers necessary, accordingly, in principle and in practice, to preserve the elements of that written constitutional federal system. As such it would be quite inappropriate for an executive government to be able to ensure the removal of a member of the judiciary for any reasons.

So the role is given to the Parliament. The role that is given to the Parliament is the role which in Britain vests in the Government, and it is confined to two basic heads. They can be spread out to three-I think Senator Tate does this every time he speaks on this matter-but I prefer to describe them as two because there are two basic categories. The first is the conduct of judicial office, either positive misbehaviour in the conduct of judicial office involving bias or conflict of interest of the kind that was suggested may have been applicable to Sir Garfield Barwick in 1980-that is what I wanted tested then and I still believe it should have been tested but the government of the day refused to have anything to do with it-or negatively, neglect, default in the conduct of one's office, that being the other side of the coin. That is the first head-misbehaviour directly related to the conduct of one's judicial office . The second head under which persons can be removed for misbehaviour from the Australian judiciary is where there has been the commission, proved under appropriate conditions and circumstances in the parliamentary forum, involving in effect a trial at the Bar of the House, of a criminal offence. Such offence could be, perhaps, forgery, physical assault or something of the kind to which one might be on occasions in this place tempted to resort. I refer to physical assault in this place and not, of course, forgery; I leave that to members of the other House. There are occasions when criminal offences are committed of which proof can be produced which are quite incompatible with continued occupancy of a seat on the Bench. Those two broad categories are the only categories available to the Parliament. For parliament to do anything else than that is for parliament to go beyond its proper constitutional functions.

TALK.START.PARA: —But who makes the judgment?

—That of course is by no means the end of the matter. As Senator Chaney has said, we then have to address the second question: On what basis does Parliament make a decision as to whether those criteria have been satisfied? I am glad that at least the baying has stopped so far as the first part of the argument is concerned, because up until now there has been a great deal of resistance even to accepting that.

—Mr President, I take a point of order. The Opposition has shown a great deal of restraint as far as interjection is concerned, but if the Attorney-General is going to try to interpret silence in the face of some of his asinine suggestions as consent, then I do not believe we can be held to the view that you put to us that we should hear him in silence. I suggest that he can have it one way but not both.
—Order! I suggest that the Attorney-General should restrain himself.

—Mr President, with the utmost respect, my restraint I think has been quite spectacular in the circumstances, but I do not canvass your ruling. The second question is: What are the circumstances in which it is appropriate for Parliament to have available to it the information which it might say it needs or thinks it needs in order to determine whether or not indeed there has been misbehaviour in one or other of the two categories I have mentioned? What I am saying to the Parliament and what I have been saying for days on end is not that Parliament cannot call for such information but that Parliament should not call for it. The Parliament should exercise an appropriate self-restraint in circumstances of the kind that already are in issue in this particular case.

SPEECH.PARA: What is it that makes these circumstances so special and so different? Well, I will tell the Parliament what makes these circumstances so special and so different and I will say it for the umpteenth time. The circumstances are these: The material here is unauthenticated; the material here is, even if it is authentic, illegally obtained; the material here, even if it is authentic and even if it were legally obtained, involves a grotesque invasion of privacy and the material here is of such a character, particularly that part of it which the Opposition is so anxious to have on the public record which obviously does involve-notwithstanding satisfying all those other descriptions-something of an assault on the credibility and stature of the judiciary and individual members of it. It is the case, and it is understandable that the Australian Democrats should be so concerned about this, that the real threshold issue is the doubts and the concerns about the authenticity of this material. We have here, as I have repeated endlessly, something like 3,000 conversations for which there is not even electronic tape backing them up to be capable of being tested. Thus the only test of authenticity is not the nonsensical effort perpetrated by the Age of checking the telephone numbers in the tapes to see if they were in fact the same telephone numbers as the persons named in real life possess; the only way one can check the authenticity of written material of that kind, unaccompanied by electronic tapes backing it up, is by reference to ordinary techniques of police investigation, interviewing the persons concerned, seeking extrinsic evidence from one source or another to back it up. Their evidentiary status is worthless. They would not be admitted as evidence in any court in this land in the form in which those transcripts, that documentary material now stands.

As to the tapes themselves, the considerations are different. As I have readily acknowledged there is a prima facie plausibility about voices on a tape. Of course that is so, but, equally, we know enough about the capacity of modern electronic techniques to tamper, to edit, to vary the quality of records to make that a matter of doubt too. I am able to report to the Senate today, not only as I have previously that expert assistance is being sought in this respect, but also that we have had a further interim report which I called for today, the substance of which is that detailed further investigation is necessary. There does appear to be prima facie evidence of editing or tampering in some form. Whether that is significant is something that can be tested only by further electronic means and that will take a considerable time; but that is occurring. The matter is in the hands of an independent expert and we are awaiting his advice. At the end of the day that then is the problem so far as this material is concerned. It is unauthenticated and even if it is, I repeat as I have repeated endlessly, it is illegal, it invades privacy and it is just simply not the kind of material which ought to be put into the public domain without a better provenance than it has.

Notwithstanding all of that it is, of course, open to Parliament to insist on the matter of the production of this material. I have not argued that Parliament cannot do it, I have not argued that Parliament lacks the power; I have argued that Parliament should not. The point that I make is that so far Parliament has accepted that argument that the material should not be produced. The Opposition over there, this skerrick, this remnant, have not accepted it, but the Parliament as a whole-the majority of course in the House of Representatives but also the majority in this place-have not accepted that it is appropriate for this matter to be put forward in its present unauthenticated form. Here in this chamber the Government obviously cannot control the numbers. Here in this chamber of the Parliament it is open to the Senate-if it believes in the force of what Senator Chaney has been saying in this motion-to insist on its prerogatives. So far at least the Democrats have taken the view, the decent view , the humane view, the view that does respect due process and privacy, and human rights and values of this kind, that it is inappropriate for these names to be bandied about and this material to be lovingly and lasciviously put on the public record to be poured over by the political lechers on the other side of this chamber.

It is important to appreciate the significance of what is being claimed in this particular respect. It is particularly important to appreciate in contrast to that, why the Government will not produce the names and why we will not confirm or deny the names that have been produced elsewhere. It is because to do so in the circumstances of this particular case where this material is of the kind that I have described would be to plunge the position of every public figure in this country and every institution those public figures are a part of onto a very slippery slide, to use one of Senator Chaney's favoured expressions. It is very easy, it is the easiest thing in the world, to make the kinds of allegations that are contained in this material interstices. It is an iron law of human nature that allegations of this kind containing mud will result in some of that mud sticking. Mud particularly sticks and mud particularly stinks in circumstances where the full details are put out with all the gravity and all the seriousness of a parliamentary forum and a parliamentary debate to be, as I said, lovingly and lasciviously poured over by the kinds of people we have on the other side of this chamber.

Incidentally, my recollection to meet Senator Chaney's point head on in this respect, is that Mr Ducker this morning-I presume it was Mr Ducker on AM to which Senator Chaney was referring-did not in fact deny outright his own involvement in this matter although certainly he said the material was scurrilous and certainly a denial was a clear inference to be derived from what he said. But the reason, as I recall it, that he did not deny it specifically is exactly the reason that I have refused to identify, to confirm or to deny names and so on in this particular place-because to do so would be to dignify something which is beneath contempt. To respond to these sorts of allegations in the terms in which the allegations are made would be to dignify those allegations with a dignity their character simply does not deserve. This is the very point the Government is making and has been making, that material of this kind of character simply does not deserve that kind of reply.

It is on that basis that I defend, and the Government defends, our handling of this particular matter. It is on this basis that I reject outright the censure motion-absurdly worded though it may be-that has been moved today. I believe that I can stand on the record of my involvement in this matter over the month or more that it has been on my plate. I believe, equally, that the Government can stand not only on its performance on this matter but also in the proper respect for the credibility of the parliamentary institution that the Government has displayed at all times. To accede to the demands of some elements within this institution of the minority in this place-clearly not the majority in the House of Representatives obviously nor ever the majority here-would indeed be to reduce this Parliament, not to elevate its stature, to something of a lack of dignity, a lack of concern for human rights, a lack of concern for privacy and a lack of concern for the due process that really would bring this Parliament into the contempt of all decent Australians. I reject this censure motion and I trust that the Parliament will do likewise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is nearly 12 months since the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) was sworn into office shortly after the Hawke Government was elected. Over that period, indeed from his early days in office, he has been riding for a very serious fall. I believe, and the Opposition believes, that the point has been reached where that fall should be emphasised and the Attorney-General should suffer it. Honourable senators should look at some of the other spectacular failures of the Attorney-General over that period of 12 months. Think of the incredible, infamous spy flights over Tasmania perpetrated by him, entirely on his own initiative within a few weeks of assuming office.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a series of other matters in which he was deeply involved and about which he has offended a great number of people, particularly in relation to David Combe. I have already pointed out the complete contrast of the stance he is now taking and the paramount importance he has given in this matter to privacy-he has placed emphasis again today on the right of privacy-to the way in which he treated David Combe. That other extraordinary event also has paralells in this case. He dealt with David Combe and extracted a statement from him under very considerable pressure of time. Of course, Mr Combe repudiated it. There was also his entirely premature opinion in relation to Mr Young and the decision he made not to prosecute Mr Young even though there may have been breaches of the Crimes Act-a situation which pre-empted the decision of the Royal Commissioner Mr Justice Hope, in that matter. There have been many other matters of that kind .

The Opposition has brought this motion of censure forward today because in a sense it represents a culmination of a great many matters in which the Attorney- General has failed in his duty as Attorney-General, failed in administering his office in his executive capacity, and failed in the proper treatment of this Parliament. His attitude to the role, powers and rights of this Parliament and, indeed, his general attitude to the institution itself and those who serve in it , is really the last straw. It was notable that in defending himself against this censure motion today, he assumed a posture and used language in relation to the members of this chamber in the way he has done repeatedly in every debate in which he has taken part as Attorney-General. We heard him in silence today in order to give him the fullest opportunity of being heard on such an important charge. Except for one quite justifiable protest from the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, we endured in silence while the Attorney-General defended himself by accusing us of being a remnant, accusing us of stupidity, cant and humbug. That is the sort of language he used the other day when he accused the Opposition of being tedious, tendentious and sanctimonious. Although this is not the subject of the censure motion, it is an indication of the continual attitude of the Attorney-General to this Senate and to those who serve in it, at least on this side of the chamber. I wonder to what extent those who sit on the other side receive the same treatment in private.

The Opposition has complained over the last two weeks, and we complained before that time, about the way in which the Attorney-General has handled this matter. I want to deal with the two limbs of the Opposition's case that it has brought today. The motion covers both the attitude of the Attorney-General to the Parliament and his ability in handling this case. We have discussed these matters on a number of occasions. I do not want to labour them again in any detail today but I think they must be repeated. I have conceded that the Attorney-General treated the tapes seriously and referred them to a police task force for a report, which he obtained within a fortnight. I think the material was received on 1 February and he received the report from the police task force on 13 February. It was very interesting that in the peroration of the Attorney- General today he said that he thought a proper response to the material and the allegations was not to dignify them. But the Attorney-General took them very seriously from the word go. He has certainly continued to take the matter very seriously because, having received the police report, he referred it for opinion to Mr Temby. Having received Mr Temby's opinion, he appointed Mr Temby as Special Prosecutor and set up a joint police task force to look at the whole range of material. That is at work. He also obtained the opinion of the Solicitor-General, although he was rather slow in doing that. So the Attorney- General has treated the matter very seriously.

One of the first and major complaints of the Opposition is that he set aside further consideration of the matter. He made it clear in his major statement on the matter on 17 February that, in relation to the further investigation by Mr Temby as Special Prosecutor and by the police task force, no further inquiry would be made or was required in respect of the judge. That is the first and most major criticism that we make of the Attorney's executive handling of this matter. We have also pointed out that he put great pressure on Mr Temby for a speedy opinion and gave him the impossible task of analysing the vast mass of material and providing an opinion within less than 48 hours. Yet he asked the Opposition and the Parliament to accept Mr Temby's opinion. We then have the extraordinary conduct of the Attorney-General when he went, he now says, as Attorney-General, to interview the judge. He did not ask the judge the very pertinent question, as Senator Chaney has pointed out, as to whether the judge admitted that it was his voice on the tape. Yet the Attorney-General has been at great pains throughout this matter to throw the greatest possible doubt on the authenticity of the material.

We come now to the time when he had to face this Parliament. When we met for the first time after this problem had been faced by him, he made a statement to the Parliament in some detail and provided us with the opinions of the Solicitor -General and of Mr Temby. In regard to that statement, as I said on a previous occasion, he came into this Parliament wrapped in a cloak of unctuous piety about the rights of privacy, the untouchability of the judiciary and so on. The whole tenor of that statement was to shut up the Parliament and the Opposition. He thought that this matter should be accepted as closed and finished and that the Opposition should have no more to say about it. It has been a great complaint of the Attorney-General ever since that the Opposition has not taken that view. He said that he had answered the questions that I had raised, that that ought to be enough and that that should be the beginning and the end of the Opposition's interest in this matter. From the word go, from the time of that statement, there has been an offensive attitude to Parliament by the Attorney- General. He made it clear, through the whole tenor of his speech, that he wanted to emphasise that there was no authenticity, in his view, about this material. He even went on to say:

We simply have no means, and are unlikely in the future to have any means, of being sure that we have a full, untampered with, reliable account of the conversations that appear to have been intercepted.

He could not have emphasised more his wish to throw doubt on the matter. However , under the pressure of questioning, he has backed away from that. Indeed, in an interview, I think it was the very next morning, he backed away from that and said that it is almost certainly the case that a great many of the conversations between the parties in question did take place in some form or another. Indeed, in answer to a question-I think it was from Senator Sir John Carrick-about his conversation with the judge in relation to representations that allegedly the judge had made on behalf of somebody to obtain an appointment in New South Wales , Senator Gareth Evans told us that the judge had had some conversation to that effect, that the judge did agree with that. Yet the Attorney-General came into the Senate the next day and said that the judge made no admissions. I do not want to analyse all this material in great detail again. It has been analysed before. However, there is a very serious aspect of the Attorney-General's handling of this matter in that regard.

The Attorney-General has refused to table and make available the aide-memoire, he has refused to table the transcripts and today he refused to deny allegations as to the identity of the judge in question. We have the most ludicrous situation that the leading stories in many newspapers of Australia today have identified the judge on the basis of what may have been said in the Queensland Parliament, yet the Attorney-General is not prepared to confirm or deny that matter. He is not only making a fool of himself in adopting that attitude but also placing this chamber in a completely ludicrous position. We are talking about the material that the Age newspaper gave to the Attorney-General. The Attorney-General has that material. On his own admissions there is quite a likelihood of authenticity about many aspects of the material, to the extent that he went to see the judge on two occasions. The Attorney-General admits that the Parliament has the ultimate responsibility for the decisions about the conduct of the judiciary. Yet he persists in refusing to give to the Parliament, to this chamber, the material on which it can make that judgment.

The Attorney-General said, in one of his typically smart Alick defences that he adopts, that the Opposition could have had the aide-memoire. The Attorney- General himself-that is what the motion is about-has bitterly fought the tabling of the aide-memoire of his conversation with the judge. I am sure he will continue to do so. The matter the Attorney-General refers to is the Opposition's amendment seeking the tabling of all transcripts, including the transcripts of the tapes that had not been transcribed by the Age when it handed that material to the Attorney, and the aide-memoire. We moved an amendment asking for all that material to be tabled. The Australian Democrats, when they finally made up their minds about the matter, amended the amendment, rendering it in an unrecognisable and useless form, by requiring that the material should be authenticated and genuine material. That made it a completely different amendment. The original amendment was amended. How did the Democrats manage to amend it? The Attorney- General and those in Government supported the Democrats' amendment, thus emasculating the amendment that the Opposition moved. Now, with the aiding and abetting of the Australian Democrats, we have the Attorney-General saying that it was the Opposition's fault that it did not get the aide-memoire. The gravamen of our case is the attitude of the Attorney-General and the opposition he has maintained throughout this affair to giving the information to this chamber and to the Parliament.

That leads me to the other limb of the Opposition's censure motion against the Attorney-General; that is, that he will not provide and will bitterly fight at every step of the way the provision of the material to this Parliament on which it could make the judgment which he grudgingly but finally admitted it had the right to make. Anyone who read his statement to this chamber on 28 February, coupled as it was with the Solicitor-General's opinion, could only conclude that the Attorney-General was 'heavying' the Parliament to stop it from dealing with this matter because, he said, the Parliament had no power to deal with this matter. That was the approach of the Attorney-General.

He was backed into a corner a day or so ago, but he is now defending himself by saying what is his opinion. His opinion may be backed by that of the Solicitor- General, for what that is worth in view of some of the great omissions from his opinion. The Attorney-General is saying: 'Even though the Parliament has the ultimate power and it is not justiciable, except perhaps in some extreme circumstance, Parliament does not really have the power to determine what is misbehaviour or incapacity. That is very strictly defined. I have defined that with the opinion of the Solicitor-General'. Even accepting that that is the correct view of the matter, which we do not, the Attorney-General is still refusing to give Parliament the material on which it can make a judgment as to whether there has even been misbehaviour in the very narrow terms in which the Attorney-General himself defines it. Taking the argument further, there must be a wider power in Pariament. However, I am not going to debate that again today. We have debated that before.

As I said, the gravamen of the charge we make against the Attorney-General is that he has refused to give Parliament the material on which it can make any judgment, even in the narrow sense that the Attorney-General has laid down. The Opposition is seeking today to censure the Attorney-General for all the reasons I have given-for his handling of the matter in most steps of the way in this journey from the time the tapes were handed to him on 1 February this year, because of his inept handling of the matter and, more particularly, because of his own offensive attitude to Parliament and the denial of the rights of Parliament on this most important matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a motion of censure against the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans), a most important and dramatic expression, if it were passed, of the chamber's view of the discharge of the responsibilities of that high office held by my colleague Senator Gareth Evans. However, it is quite evident from the fact that only two or three back benchers of the Liberal Party of Australia have sat behind their speakers as they mounted this exercise that honourable senators opposite have well realised that this is just a show, a sham, a political exericse with no substance whatsoever. (Quorum formed) I renew my speech in defence of the Attorney-General in relation to this censure motion which still does not command tremendous allegiance from Opposition back benchers. It is an attack, as I said, of a purely political character and it is not mounted in the good faith which should be underlying any such serious charge against the Attorney-General.

SPEECH.PARA: As I listened to Senator Chaney, it seemed that he was making two points. First , he claimed that the Attorney had acted in a way inconsistent with the Australian Constitution. Secondly, there was the general charge that he had refused to provide information to this chamber. I intend to deal with both of those matters in sequence. It seems that there are two elements to the charge that the Attorney-General has failed to act in accordance with the Australian Constitution. However, when we look at the record we find that the Attorney, on the first day on which this Parliament was recalled this year, namely, 28 February, came into this chamber with the fullest statement and record of his activities in relation to the so-called Age tapes affair, so we had from the beginning a placing before Parliament for its scrutiny the activities of the Attorney. That was not dragged out of him as a result of some draconian motion passed in his chamber. He freely put down a very lengthy and very full statement. When one read that statement one found that the Attorney-it has not been challenged-acted in a timely fashion and with propriety. There was no attempt, as I say, to slow down or cover up the investigative processes.
