It was alleged by Senator Durack and Senator Chipp, because they could assume only bad faith on the part of the Attorney-General, that he had somehow ordered the Federal Police merely to look at the provenance, the coming into being, of these transcripts and tapes rather than their substance. That was never the case. It was always the case that they were free and were instructed to investigate not only the coming into being of these transcripts and tapes, but also the substance, if there were any, revealed in a reading of them or a listening to them.

It was the same with Mr Temby, Q.C., the designated Director of Public Prosecutions, a former President of the Law Council of Australia. I mention that because it shows he had not only the confidence of the Attorney in appointing him to that high office but also he clearly enjoyed the respect and confidence of his peers who had elected him to the presidency of the Law Council of Australia. There were no constraints, hindrances, restrictions or boundaries drawn for the opinion of Mr Temby. The Attorney was not aware of what Mr Temby might say as a result of his perusal of this material and his understanding of the law. In other words, the Attorney put himself and his Government in some political jeopardy. He did not know what the Director of Public Prosecutions designate, the Special Prosecutor in this instance, would conclude on the basis of his understanding of the law and his perusal of the materials.

There was proper fulfilling of Lord Shawcross's injunction which has been quoted to this chamber by Senator Chaney. Without the Hansard I have not been able to note it down, but it is to the effect that the Attorney must discharge his duties of office without fear of political repercussions or consequences . I believe that that has been shown to be the case. The Attorney was not content to rest with the opinion on the law of Mr Temby, Q.C.; he sought an opinion from the Solicitor-General. He sought an opinion without giving the Solicitor-General the materials-in other words, without trying to colour his perception of the law in any way. The Attorney was simply asking what was the relationship of this Parliament to the question of misbehaviour on the part of a federal judge. In that respect the Solicitor-General wrote a learned opinion which, as I read, is well based in the custom and precedents applicable to an understanding of the role of the Parliament in relation to Federal judges in Australia.

It is unfortunate for the Opposition-this is why I am so angry and disappointed -that those opinions do not give the Opposition the opportunity to do what it wants to. It wants to act as the English Parliament, the Westminster Parliament, is entitled to do in relation to judges of England and Wales. Honourable senators opposite want to come into this chamber and act as general censors over the conduct, the foibles and the misbehaviour in general of judges. Parliamentarians in England and Wales are able to do this; I do not know about Scotland because it has a different judicial system. It is quite clear that in relation to Australia, as the Attorney has pointed out and as the opinions assert, the framers of the Constitution deliberately denied to this Parliament the ability to undertake that general investigation into the conduct of judges. The Constitution limits the Parliament to praying for the removal of a judge on the ground of proved misbehaviour which must relate to some misuse of judicial office or some other matter which is a breach of general law such as could give rise to a conviction. The chambers of this Parliament are permitted to act in relation to those matters. That is the second point about the relationship of the Attorney to the Parliament.

It has been claimed that the Attorney has acted in a way which is inconsistent with the Australian Constitution. If the Attorney had said that this Parliament was not the final arbiter of the meaning and the carrying through of section 72 of the Constitution, he could be guilty of acting inconsistenly with it. In fact he has stated to this chamber, and it is not by way of admission but as part of the proper understanding of the Constitution, that it is indeed the case that this Parliament is ultimately responsible for the interpretation of section 72 and for the carrying into effect of any prayer for the removal of a Federal judge. The responsibility lies fairly and squarely within these four walls. No bench of justices can interfere with the carring out of the role assigned to the Parliament by section 72 of the Constitution.

It being the case that that responsibility lies fairly and squarely within these four walls, it is only proper that the Attorney-General should come into this chamber and attempt to aid the Parliament by pointing to a proper understanding of the law. As I have said, he has done that. He has laid on the table of this chamber the opinion of the Solicitor-General, supported as that opinion is by the underlying law used by Mr Temby on his persual and assessment of the material handed to him, it having been handed previously to the Attorney by the editor of the Age. As I have said before, in relation to those opinions the Attorney had no knowledge of the outcome of the perusal and understanding of the law by those two eminent lawyers. Nevertheless, he has put them into this chamber; he has made them available to us. In that, I believe he has discharged his duty as Attorney-General. So in relation to the constitutional propriety of the Attorney's action I believe there can be no question but that he has acted utterly in conformity with it, in the true spirit of an Attorney-General and not as a partisan political figure.

We come to the second charge which underlies this censure motion, that is, that the Attorney has somehow failed to provide, has refused, has put up a barrier to the provision of information to this chamber. What is the information that is sought? The real question is this: Is what the Opposition wants placed on the table of the Senate chamber information? Merely puting the label 'information' on a bundle of material, unauthenticated tapes and unauthenticated transcripts, does not make it information. It remains a bundle of material which may convey no information whatsoever.

Only yesterday, in reply to a question in the House of Representatives which received, wide publicity, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), very properly I think, told Parliament that the so-called corruption tapes were not authenticated, that transcripts existed which were not backed up by tapes, and that there was no identification of any person involved in taking the tapes. This is the whole crux of the matter. The Opposition is demanding of the Attorney that he place in this chamber quite unauthenticated material. It is to the credit of the Australian Democrats that they recognised that very important distinction and refused to support a motion which would have allowed that unauthenticated material to be placed on the table of the Senate. As I say, merely putting the label 'information' on a bundle of material does not make it information. I believe that the Democrats are to be congratulated for having accepted the force of that argument.

When one looks at Mr Temby's opinion one finds this point made time and time again in relation to various assertions, but to give an example from one sentence on page 2 of his opinion, as a prelude to his examination of the whole matter, he says:

The first general point to be made is that the material I have seen could not of itself warrant the laying of charges against anybody. Neither the tapes nor the documents are original, and it may be that they have been fabricated.
Yet the Opposition is asking us to lay that sort of material in this privileged chamber for public scrutiny, to expose it to the view of Australian society. As Mr Temby says:
The first step, if any aspect of the matter is to be taken further, is to establish their authenticity.

It is that very necessary first step which the Opposition will not allow to be taken. As I said, it is to the credit of the Democrats that they agree that that first step must be taken before these materials can be said to convey any information whatsoever. In case it be thought that the Government is dwelling too much on Mr Temby's opinion in relation to these matters, I think it is also important to go to the opinion of Miss Mary Gaudron, the Solicitor-General of New South Wales, who gave an opinion on the tapes and documents concerning these alleged telephone conversations between prominent legal and crime figures in New South Wales. Amongst other things, this is what she has to say:

In some conversations there are changes in speech patterns and/or speed which are to the untrained ear suggestive of 'editing'. Without full technical assessment it is not possible to exclude the possibility of 'editing' and/or ' patching' of conversations.

That is what the Opposition wants us to lay on the table-matters which the Solicitor-General of New South Wales, Miss Mary Gaudron, has said, to her untrained ear are suggestive of editing and where patching and editing of conversations are likely to have taken place. After several paragraphs Miss Gaudron goes on:
I have already stated that from a legal perspective the documents are wholly worthless.
That was said by the Solicitor-General of New South Wales. She continues:
The nature of the matter above quoted would lead me to the view that, in the absence of authentication it would be unwise to assume the accuracy of the various summaries.

There we have it. We have tapes which, to the untrained ear, are suggestive of editing and patching, running at different speeds. We have transcripts which are not backed up by any electronic tapes but which are merely pieces of paper which are totally unauthenticated, and which to be authenticated would require the usual police investigative techniques of interview and the taking of statements. That certainly has not been done to this point. The key point is that on the basis of Mr Temby's and Miss Mary Gaudron's review of these documents and these tapes, if these tapes and transcripts were made available to the chamber-a wholly privileged situation-they would not add to the information available to it. A moment ago I took the opportunity to look up the meaning of 'information' in the Oxford English Dictionary. Amongst other definitions, it states:
the action of informing . . . communication of the knowledge or 'news' of some fact or other occurrence; the action of telling or fact of being told of something.
As another possibility for the meaning of the word 'information' it states:
Knowledge communicated concerning some particular fact, subject or event.

The fact is that if there is no authentication of these tapes or transcripts there is no possibility of conveying knowledge of any fact, event or occurrence. The tapes are possibly edited and patched. The transcripts are unauthenticated and they do not cross-reference with any of the tapes available. Nothing in this bundle of material would allow one to say that there is a communication of some knowledge of fact, occurrence or event. They are merely assertions. We are dealing with an area of mere possibilities.

No assertion is possible that any conversation allegedly transcribed did in fact occur-that is incontestable-or that if any of the conversations occurred they occurred in the sequence or in the fullest manner of transcription. They could be just partial transcriptions, or the sequence of chronological order could be completely turned around. More importantly, even if one could say that those conversations occurred, there is nothing to say that any fact or event alleged to have occurred did, in fact, occur. These conversations could be based just on a completely false understanding or a malicious putting of matters that may or may not have occurred in the past and that may or may not occur in the future. Nothing in these transcripts allows one to say that conversations allegedly recorded took place or that, if they did take place, they convey any true knowledge of any particular facts or events. In other words, to put it simply, these tapes or transcripts would not be admissible in any court in Australia. Why not? Because they are not of sufficient certainty to allow, as a matter of natural justice, a judge or a jury to be influenced by exposure to them. They would not even get to first base. They would not be admissible, let alone put in the balance and weighed up or have their character assessed.

If the Opposition ever achieved the objective it appears to have of transforming this chamber from a legislative chamber to a judicial chamber, surely it should apply to itself the same constraints we have always applied in judicial proceedings under the traditions of the common law and should ask itself whether it should expose its judgment to material which would not be admissible in a court of law. If this material could not get into the meanest, remotest magistrate's court in the smallest town in Australia because it might wrongly influence a magistrate or a jury, it would be quite improper to bring it into this chamber when we are talking about the holders of high judicial office with perhaps dismissal from that office and the loss of livelihood of a person. It is a well known principle of natural justice that where the livelihood, status or employment of a person is at stake, of course one could not act on anything less than admissible evidence. Natural justice demands it. No course should be embarked upon which is not based upon admissible and authenticated evidence. That is not the case here.

The fact is that the Attorney-General has acted in a way which is wholly in accord with the Constitution of Australia and with the proper relation of his office to the Parliament as created by our Constitution. What is more, he has acted in a way which is wholly consistent with, explicable by and in harmony with the principles of natural justice. These are principles which commend themselves to the untutored mind of any decent, reasonable person. They are principles which have commended themselves to the common law as a proper basis for commencing any activity which may lead to the possibly dire consequences of that which the Opposition has embarked upon over the last several days. For these reasons and because the Attorney-General has acted wholly in accordance with the Constitution and with the principles of natural justice, I believe he deserves the support of this chamber and that the motion of censure should be repudiated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the following motion moved by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney):

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate censures the Attorney-General for his handling of the Age tapes and in particular his persistent refusal to provide information to the Parliament in order that it might properly perform its role in matters relating to the Judiciary.

If this motion is passed by the Senate it does not, as I understand it, by tradition mean the automatic resignation of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans). But I submit that if an Attorney-General is censured by the House in which he sits his position would be made intolerable, if not untenable. I am amazed by some of the wording of this Opposition motion which, of course, the Australian Democrats cannot and will not support, particularly the following words:
. . . in particular his persistent refusal to provide information to the Parliament . . . relating to the Judiciary.

As I mentioned before, only two days ago 25 members of the Opposition-I will name them if someone interjects on me again-voted with the Australian Labor Party against the motion which would have resulted in the provision of information concerning the judiciary, including an aide-memoire of conversations between the Attorney-General and the judge concerned. This was initiated two days ago by the Opposition which demanded that there be tabled certain transcripts of tapes concerning conversations between the judge and the solicitor involved, plus the aide-memoire to which I have referred. Senator Haines then did an outrageous thing, according to the Liberal Party. Senator Haines, my associate Democrat from South Australia, moved an amendment to the Liberal motion and said: The Democrats will go along with that provided the material is 'transcripts or parts of transcripts of authenticated and genuine tapes'. That was her amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is all you wanted.

—That is all we wanted-to make sure that the transcripts came from authenticated or genuine tapes. Because we moved that, 25 members of the Liberal Party voted against it. That was of no use to them. It was of no use to have genuine material brought before the Senate.
—Or even the aide-memoire.

—Or even the aide-memoire apparently. Yet today the Opposition has moved this outrageous censure motion because the Attorney will not provide information to the Parliament. I find it incomprehensible. When I spoke on the motion to suspend Standing Orders I said that every member of the Opposition then present voted against it. I now find that I have to apologise to Senators Jessop and Lewis because they do not figure on the list in the Journals of the Senate. They have reminded me of that. If I do not misrepresent them, I understand that Senator Lewis did not vote because he did not believe in the hypocritical stance which the Opposition and the Liberal Party were taking at that time. As I understand him, he deliberately absented himself. One must read into the non-acceptance of Senator Haines's amendment, which was to the effect that she and the Democrats wanted transcripts only of genuine and authenticated tapes, that the Liberal Party was interested only in material from unauthenticated or non-genuine tapes. That logic cannot be argued against.

SPEECH.PARA: I have said before-we seem to be saying it every day because the matter is before us every day-that whilst we have some criticism of the way in which the Attorney-General has handled this matter, we have no great concern in principle over his behaviour. He has expeditiously sought and gained legal opinions concerning the position of the judge. We might not agree with those opinions. I thank members of the Liberal Party such as Senator Missen and Senator Durack, both of whom I respect as lawyers, who have cast doubts on the strength of those legal opinions. I have some doubts about them myself. But at least the Attorney gained those legal opinions expeditiously. He established and referred appropriate matters to a joint police task force. We are now awaiting its report . He also expeditiously referred other matters to the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking, to Special Prosecutor Redlich and to Director of Public Prosecutions designate Temby. With respect to the tapes the Attorney took overt and positive action on five different fronts. However, as I have said twice before in this place, we have some areas of criticism. When the Age tapes affair blew the Attorney appeared to be more concerned with the possible offences connected with the obtaining of the tapes than with the probable offences disclosed in their contents. He criticised me for criticising him about that. In his statement of 28 February he still seemed to be preoccupied with the people who taped the conversations and transcribed them rather than with the alleged offences that the tapes and transcripts indicated had taken place, because he then said:

Although the most obvious grounds for investigation by the Special Prosecutor clearly concern the circumstances of the interceptions, there are several other possible offences under Commonwealth law that may have been committed and which will require further investigations.

Even at that stage, on 28 February, the Attorney had seen that priority number one was to catch the scoundrels who had been brave enough to tap and to transcribe alleged skulduggery by people in high places. My criticism of the Attorney remains on that score. Admittedly, the Attorney did not go as far as Mr Wran, who tried to dispose of the matter simply as a conspiracy of smear and sneer. He suggested that because the tapes were not made by his own criminal investigation unit they were false. That was a quite extraordinary conclusion by Mr Wran, and one which fooled no one.

As it is, it took consistent prodding, mainly from the Age, to induce the Attorney-General to take the actions that he has taken, for which I have already commended him. I have already indicated my concern about the form of the investigation that the Attorney has initiated, and about its focus-namely, criminal prosecution, which may well preclude the investigation from ranging as far and as wide as a more general brief might have permitted. The Democrats wanted this whole question referred to the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union from the outset, or a like commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is an arm's length commission.

—An arm's length commission, yes. But that is not the only point. The other important point is that Mr Costigan does not have as his final criterion only criminal prosecution. As I understand it, Mr Temby, unless he can see the light at the end of the tunnel being criminal prosecution, must stop going down that trail and follow another one. Mr Costigan has no such inhibitions in the way in which he investigates matters put before him. On a matter such as this, the Democrats would have by far preferred the wider brief of Mr Costigan. Therefore, we are critical to that extent.

SPEECH.PARA: I come again to the Opposition's stand on this matter in wanting material from unauthenticated and ungenuine tapes produced at large before this Parliament. I invite honourable senators to contemplate the number of legal tape recordings made in Australia by people such as the Australian Federal Police; not illegal recordings such as those about which we are talking. I think that even the Opposition concedes that they are illegal. I do not hold the view that the person or persons who taped these conversations did wrong. It was illegal. I tend to the view, a personal view, that they could well have been made by honest men or women who had had such a gutful of corruption in the New South Wales Police Force that they were impelled to this action. That is my personal view of the motivation of the people who did this.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that that is right.
—Therefore, the tapes should be taken seriously.
—Indeed they should.
—That is the very theory that I put yesterday. I agree with you.

—Senator Chaney has no argument from me on that. He never had one from the start. They are illegal. However, I suggest that Senator Chaney contemplate the number of legal tapes in existence which have not been able to be meddled with or doctored, namely, those tapes undertaken by the Australian Federal Police, particularly its drug investigation unit, on a legal judicial warrant. There are thousands of them. Those sorts of tapes would make fascinating listening-legal, accurate and undoctored, and the transcripts totally vouchable for, if that is a correct term. I would be prepared to bet that most of the names of the well known members of this Federal Parliament occur in those tapes. Remember that these tapes would have been taken of conversations on a telephone by one criminal to another criminal or by two persons contemplating a criminal act, otherwise the Australian Federal Police would not have got the warrants; so, these are conversations between villains, between crooks. One of the quirks of the criminal mind of a crook is to say that he has a well known politician in his pocket. I have no doubt that on those tapes my name, the names of well known members of the Government and of the Opposition occur, by some villain saying: 'Oh So-and-so, he's right. He's been on the take for years, and we've got him'. It is a well known weakness in which villains indulge when communicating with each other.

SPEECH.PARA: What would be the Opposition's view if I moved an amendment to the Opposition's motion to the effect that all transcripts of all tapes of the Australian Federal Police concerning drug activity in which leading members of the Government, the Opposition or the Democrats were mentioned should be tabled in the Senate? I wonder what the Opposition's attitude would be? There would be total and utter outrage. Opposition members would say: 'How dare you impugn the good character of people simply because some crook mentions the name of Don Chipp, or whoever, in a conversation. How dare you drag through Don Chipp's name and blacken it in this way'. I remind the Senate that this would be about genuine authenticated tapes-which was the very thing that Senator Haines and the Democrats wanted and to which we would have agreed the other day but against which the Opposition voted.

I have a high regard for Senator Chaney. Today I could not believe my ears when he asked what was wrong with the situation that happened on the AM broadcast this morning when a certain person who had been named in the Queensland Parliament-by two ex-Liberals, one of whom had been expelled from the Liberal Party for treachery for leaking party room secrets, and another member who had done a secret deal with Joh Bjelke-Petersen before the election--

TALK.START.PARA: —You have to watch ex-Liberals, haven't you?

—Listeners ought to have the benefit of Senator Peter Baume's interjection, Mr Deputy President, with your permission. He said: 'You have to watch ex-Liberals, haven't you?'. I concede the wit behind his interjection. That is all that I concede.
—He is not a chip off the old block.

—No, indeed not. But here we have a person named in the Queensland Parliament by two nefarious ex-Liberals. Senator Chaney says: 'Okay; he was named under parliamentary privilege. But that man who was named was able, on AM this morning, the distinguished program broadcast by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, to say: ''It is a lot of rot. It is not true''. So everything is fixed.' I could not believe my ears. I could not believe that a person as experienced in politics, public life and the law as Senator Chaney is would say that that exercise was all right. Yet I have not heard subsequent speakers from the Liberal benches go against that. In this public life there is no question but that if mud is thrown, some of it sticks, no matter how unjustified that is.

SPEECH.PARA: I have had some copies of these transcripts for several months. I have made that fact public. The person who originally had the tapes gave the transcripts to me, among others, apparently for his own protection. He then immediately announced to the criminal world that he had done that, for which I have never thanked him since. But that was the motivation of Mr Bob Bottom in handing the transcripts to me and to some others. For many of these transcripts there is no partner tape-there is simply a transcript; a piece of paper, as Senator Tate said-but they contain the name of a national identity, much loved, much respected, who is allegedly in a business in Sydney. A person associated with the freehold of that business is the most notorious crime figure in Australia. I am totally persuaded that this much loved national personality who has a business there has not the slightest idea that those premises are owned by the notorious creature who owns them. But if we were to let the tapes lie on the table of the Senate that would necessarily be the subject of a page one headline in every newspaper tomorrow and that highly respectable, incredibly decent human being who is a national figure would be associated with a crime figure. That is where the danger lies in this issue.

Lastly, the timing of this debate leaves a lot to be desired. Senator Durack has given notice that on the next day of sitting he will move that a joint select committee be appointed to inquire into and report upon, among other things, whether the judge has been guilty of misbehaviour and whether he has revealed any incapacity. I must say that the Australian Democrats are attracted to the general concept of that proposition. That is a different proposition from laying on the table of the Senate for the whole of the world to see tapes or transcripts incriminating innocent people-guilt by association. I say at this stage that the wording of Senator Durack's notice of motion leaves a lot to be desired. It states:
That a Joint Select Committee be appointed to inquire into and report upon the conduct of the judge referred to in the tapes . . .

What sort of conduct does he mean? Is it the judge's conduct at a local cricket match or his conduct from the time he was born until now? The notice does not say where or when. I give notice to the Opposition that if it is seeking any sort of support from the Democrats on this question-it will need that support for the motion to have any chance of being passed by the Senate-there would need to be much more consultation with us than there has been over this matter so far . The words in this notice of motion are too preposterous to contemplate, but let it be known that we are attracted to the idea of having a joint select committee or perhaps even a select committee of the Senate look at the conduct of the judge in question on the evidence in a sober, proper, dignified way. I say that we are not unattracted by the concept. It is worthy of consideration. I go no further than that. Paragraph 3 of the notice of motion states:
That the inquiry commence after the polling day of the New South Wales election .
I thought: 'At last the Liberal Party has become responsible and, rather than demeaning this important issue to win a few votes at the New South Wales election--

TALK.START.PARA: —Or lose a few.

—Or lose a few. I thank Senator Mason for his interjection. I ask expert tacticians such as Senator Sir John Carrick, who has been in the business for a long time and is one of the best political brains in New South Wales, to contemplate the behaviour of the Liberal Party over the last few weeks and the plummeting in the support for that fine man, Nick Greiner, for whom I have undoubted admiration, and the summiting in popularity of that other man, Neville Wran, whom I hold in contempt. I wonder whether there is a lesson to be learned about politicking and demeaning this sort of issue. I would have thought that there were bigger issues at stake than simply the New South Wales election. I commended the Liberal Party when I saw this notice of motion. I thought that at last it was not going to dirty this very important vital issue about a senior judge in order to win or lose a few votes in the New South Wales election. But without notice, without warning, whilst the Opposition had indicated its intention to submit a matter of public importance about deficits, I think, Senator Chaney moved this censure motion. I think honourable senators opposite have only themselves to blame if the currency of this debate, which is a highly important matter, is debased by these tactics. With those remarks, I formally state that the Democrats will not support the Opposition in its motion of censure of the Attorney-General.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The post of Attorney-General, the first law officer, carries with it special responsibilities to the office and to the members of the pubic whom he represents. These responsibilities are quite separate and are over and above the duties which the Attorney has to the Government of which he is a part. I remember that when my friend Robert Ellicott , as Attorney-General, felt that there was a conflict between his role as Attorney-General and his role as a member of the Government, a political role, he had no hesitation in resigning from the post. He did that as a matter of principle. But this Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans), the man who is the subject of this censure motion, does not in our view show the same concern for the primacy of his role as first law officer and the protector of the public good.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a serious matter to move a motion of censure and we regard the course we have embarked upon today as a serious one. It is a heavy matter. I believe this is the first time since the election a year ago that we in Opposition have moved such a motion. I am supporting this motion as a member of the Opposition but also as a New South Welshman. I am supporting it also in the context of the election campaign under way in which the Labor Premier of New South Wales has invited the people of my State to make a judgment on him and his Government on the basis of their understanding of certain material contained in the allegations which come from what are now known as the Age tapes. It is a matter of importance to my State, to the people among whom I live and to the Senate.

Above all, the Attorney-General has brought this censure motion entirely upon himself. It relates directly to his handling of very serious allegations against a number of persons including a member of the judiciary. These allegations go to affairs in New South Wales and to people's confidence in the maintenance of law in Australia. Senator Gareth Evans once again has put into doubt his position as Attorney-General, as a person fit to be a senior Minister in the Government. He has once again cast doubts over the office of Attorney-General by the way in which he has handled this matter. He has repeated the errors which he made in relation to the Combe case and he has repeated some of the errors in relation to the spy flights. Once again we have seen an attempt to reveal as little information as possible, to cover up what could be covered up, to release information only when he had to and to make subjective judgments away from the public view whenever any political sensitivity is involved.

Quite clearly, the first task of the Attorney-General in dealing with these tapes and the allegations should have been to distance himself completely from the investigations, to remain aloof so that in due course he could exercise the judgments which are his as Attorney-General, free from any kind of criticism that he had involved himself in the process in a way which could make people uneasy or give rise to criticism. He should have established an objective inquiry as publicly as possible. It is incredible, and at the very least inconsistent, that Senator Evans did not proceed in this way. I remind honourable senators that the allegations contained in these tapes could not be more serious. It is alleged that public servants in my State were buying jobs, that trials and prosecutions in New South Wales were fixed not once but quite regularly. It is alleged that sexual favours were bought for senior judges and there were allegations of links between politicians, the judiciary and senior crime figures.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are only allegations.

—Here we have Senator Gietzelt interjecting. I wonder why he is so sensitive. It is alleged that a solicitor was involved with a person who is widely considered in my State to be not of good repute. As a result of these allegations the Age newspaper has said in as careful a way as it could that an evil web had been revealed and had to be unravelled. It stated that the matters were too important to be set aside or dealt with in any way lightly. We had the same newspaper saying in its editorial on another day that the crime links were too grave to ignore. It set out the reasons why these allegations, based on tapes and transcripts which it believed to be genuine, should be acted on most seriously.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly, the Government considered the tape allegations to be serious. It thought them to be serious enough to seek the advice of Mr Ian Temby, QC. It thought them serious enough to seek the advice of the Solicitor-General. It thought them serious enough for the Attorney-General, himself, very unwisely, to visit the judge to converse with him on the matters that were raised. The Attorney has asked us as an Opposition to accept his assurances that the steps he took and the opinions he obtained were conclusive and should have been good enough. We do not accept it.

It is interesting to note also that the Attorney-General seems to have set aside for some special kind of treatment the matters raised in the tapes relating to the senior judicial figure. We know that names have appeared in newspapers. The front page of every newspaper across the nation today carried names. A judge has been named. But the Government has still refused, in spite of that, to confirm or deny whether those names are correct or incorrect. In response to questions asked today it has refused to take the opportunity to clear either the name of the judge who was named or the names of all the other judges. The senior judges in Australia are hopping mad about this affair. The Government had a chance today to make it clear that they were not the people who were being named. The Attorney-General could have done that but he declined to identify the judge who was involved. He refused to identify the judge so that the other judges who were so concerned could say to people: 'It is not us. The newspapers are correct'.

I do not wish to follow up the question of the person being named. On the issue of serious allegations against a prominent member of the judiciary, Senator Gareth Evans, with advice from Mr Temby, took it upon himself to be both judge and jury. Really, that is just not good enough. It is not just a legal matter. I say to all the lawyers in this Parliament who have argued the law: We have listened with interest, but there are other ramifications. This is a political matter in New South Wales. The people have to go to the polls for an absurdly early election in about two and a half weeks, called--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I take a point of order. I draw your attention to standing order 419. The Opposition speaker is digressing to other matters. He has not shown any relevance to the matter under discussion. The matter under discussion is the censure of the Attorney-General. It has nothing to do with the New South Wales State election.
—Order! At the moment Senator Baume is relevant. He cannot develop too much the New South Wales State election. He must concentrate on the censure motion.

—I do not wish to discuss the issue of the New South Wales State election. I wish to indicate that there is a link between the Age tape allegations which are before this Senate and the reasons the Premier of New South Wales gave for bringing the people to an early election, requiring them to vote in two and a half weeks on matters on which the people of New South Wales do not have the facts. They do not have the substance of the allegations and cannot therefore make up their minds in any reasoned way. The Parliament and the people of New South Wales need the facts. After all, as we had to extract with difficulty from Senator Evans, and as Senator Durack has referred to today, it is for the Parliament and not the Executive to make a judgment on a motion in accordance with section 72 of the Constitution which gives the Parliament a very clear role in respect of this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Evans has consistently sought to limit, deny and prevent this Parliament getting the information which should be its right. He has sought to delay it and limit it. It is not good enough. We are concerned that he should have arrogated to himself decisions concerning the judge when there are real questions arising. We want to know that Senator Evans is at arm's length from that procedure. We want to know that Senator Evans is at arm's length from the judge in a professional, personal or political sense, that he has been acting as Attorney-General, as he said today, and not in some other role. In the light of everything that has come out how can he argue a dispassionate role for himself in this matter as Attorney-General? We are concerned on that matter.

Senator Evans has based his views on a judicial figure, based in itself upon the opinion of an eminent QC, Mr Iam Temby. I do not in any way question the professional integrity of Mr Temby. But I question the judgment of an Attorney- General who was foolish enough to select for this task someone who is a political partisan, who has very recently been an Australian Labor Party candidate for election. The foolishness of the Attorney-General is evident in the way in which he is proceeding.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whom are you talking about?

—I am talking about the special investigator. It is just not good enough. The public and the Parliament must have the information. We believe that Senator Evans never should have visited the judge; it was not an appropriate role or action for an Attorney-General. He should have stood aloof and he did not do so. He should have recognised the conflict of interest that could arise by his going to see the judge who was named and by his then being required to exercise a judgment about the matters raised in relation to that judge. I cannot accept that the Attorney's judgments or actions in this matter have been wise, prudent, or consistent with his role.

SPEECH.PARA: The other part of the Oppositions' censure motion concerns the refusal of the Attorney-General to make information available to this Parliament. All we asked for was information which would be edited and sanitised to remove names. Either Senator Chipp chose to ignore that fact or he did not understand it. At no stage did we ask for the revelation of information which would identify individuals. The people of New South Wales want to know what are the allegations. We did not ask in our motion two days ago for any names to be released. In fact I think we specifically sought to have names expunged.

TALK.START.PARA: —And identifying characteristics.

—We wanted identifying characteristics expunged. The whole argument which Senator Chipp has raised falls to the ground. We have not sought to identify, denigrate or make it very difficult for particular individuals. What did we have? We had an attempt by the Australian Democrats, working as the limpet fish of the Australian Labor Party, to emasculate the motion we put up. With the help of Senator Chipp it was emasculated. The motion that was eventually passed provided an excellent vehicle for the Labor Party to be able to delay, forever if it wished, the release of any information and to hide behind the fact that it was merely seeking to authenticate. Let us be clear once again that we have been seeking to have put before the people of Australia information which does not identify people but which identifies allegations. The people of Australia are entitled to know what were the allegations that caused a very responsible newspaper so much concern and have caused a large number of responsible people to be so worried.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the Senate that just 10 days ago, on 21 February, the Sydney Morning Herald published an editorial headed 'Justice behind closed doors'. That editorial described the situation, part of which is our concern today. From these tapes it has appeared that it was wrong for the Attorney-General to do anything less than provide a full and public disclosure to this Parliament of the matters involved in the tapes and the transcripts-not to identify people, not to identify names, not to identify special characteristics which might allow us to know the identity of people, but to identify the matters. It is the refusal of the Attorney-General to go down that track which gives us the second limb of our motion of censure.

As long as this matter remains unresolved it is potentially damaging and reflects very badly on every member of a small group of citizens who make up the senior judiciary in Australia. All of them are complaining that they feel tainted. They require action which will clear their names. Let me say once again that Senator Gareth Evans has brought this matter upon himself. It is in the tradition of his action in the Combe affair, in the tradition of his action in relation to South West Tasmania. This issue now is urgent. The people of New South Wales are anxious to know what is the material which has caused Mr Wran to scuttle to the polls so quickly to avoid having it brought into the public place . What is the material which the Attorney-General has referred to a number of investigators?

Public concern is not satisfied. What the Government has done has not satisfied anyone. Public disquiet had not been assuaged. It has not been assuaged by the Attorney-General by his actions and it has not been assuaged by the weak defence he put up today. The numbers in the Senate will determine the outcome of this censure motion, but let the Attorney-General know that we moved this censure motion reluctantly and only after much concern and much soul searching. It is not a course that we welcome. Senator Gareth Evans is an attractive man who has been a failure as an Attorney-General, not only in the political sense, not only as a Minister in the ordinary sense, but also we believe to the office which he was sworn in to represent. As regards the allegations, I do not care how long it takes, but the people are going to know the facts one day, and when that happens the people will judge.

—Senator Archer should ask the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney). —Senator Walters bleats out-she is suffering from a disease which in sheep is called blast-'Name them'. The Attorney-General today said he would not name them, and that has been the consistent position of the Government since this matter began. The Government will not be about, on the basis of fairly spurious information, bandying names about. The Opposition may be not so concerned. Turning to another matter, I wrote down a passage of the speech made by the shadow Attorney-General of this country, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Senator Durack).
