On the basis of the allegation that there is quite a likelihood-there is quite a likelihood that it is not, in total-that the material is authentic-
—We are only going on what Senator Evans said about it.

—Yes, I know. The Opposition has, day after day, pursued this matter at Question Time, in matters of public importance, in all sorts of activities in the Senate, to try to see whether the material, authentic or not, is any grist for the mill.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to go through some of the questions of substance. First of all, the Attorney-General has been accused about the way in which he has handled the matter. I remind the Senate that the Attorney-General, on the first day the Parliament met, brought down a lengthy statement about the matter. He provided the Leader of the Opposition with opinions from Mr Temby, now the Director of Public Prosecutions.

TALK.START.PARA: —One man's opinion.

—One man's opinion. He provided the Leader of the Opposition with a copy of an opinion of the Solicitor-General. He brought down a lengthy statement in the Senate and since then he has elaborated on that statement in a number of respects.
—The opinions are illogical.
—That is an extraordinary thing. Senator Missen said that the opinions are illogical.
—I said that on Monday in detail.

—I am sorry, I did not hear the honourable senator at that time. But his leaders are so sensitive about that question that there has been no attack at all on the opinions. That has not been the burden of the Opposition's complaints at Question Time or at any other time. The burden of its complaints has been to find what it calls material which may or may not be authenticated.
—Not at all; you have not been listening.

—I would have thought that at least one of the honourable senator 's matters of public importance would have been devoted to that question; but it has not been. The point I was making before I was interrupted referred to the question of the handling of this matter by the Attorney-General. I was making the point that he has taken every reasonable step from the beginning of this matter to make as much information as possible available to the Parliament, consistent with the protection of the reputation of an individual, based on considerations of privacy. Consistent with that, all the information that it is possible to bring to the Parliament has been brought to the Parliament by the Attorney-General. The Opposition has asked numerous questions over a long period . It has not succeeded in extracting anything which in any way reflects inconsistency in those statements which have been made by the Attorney-General and the statement which was made on the first day of the parliamentary session.

SPEECH.PARA: The second charge, of course, relates to failure to provide information and in a sense I have commented on that. As I said earlier today in this place, on the one occasion that the Opposition had the opportunity to see that further information was tabled which would not necessarily assist it, it abandoned that opportunity in a fit of pique and is still complaining about that abandoned opportunity today. The major question in this matter goes to what is the duty of parliament. I take it that that is the reason for the Opposition seeking information in the way in which it has been doing, unless the reason for seeking that information relates to Senator Baume's revelation about there being an election in New South Wales. But assuming the best motives on behalf of the Opposition, assuming that it is genuinely concerned that allegations have been made against a Commonwealth judge, and that it is concerned with the substance of those allegations, the simple point I make is that it is often overlooked in the heat of this debate that we are dealing with tapes which were taken illegally-that is common ground between the parties-in respect of which there are transcripts, not necessarily direct transcripts, but summaries, as I understand it, of what is said to be in the tapes. This is the information which the Opposition has and which it is asking the Government to table in this place.

That is the nature of the information. I find it a very spurious exercise for an Opposition to embark on a fishing expedition which is now seven days old in order to try to substantiate facts allegedly about a Commonwealth judge and probably about other people, based on illegally taken tapes of private conversations. That is the standard which the Opposition adopts in this matter. What the Government, of course, is concerned to do-and there were all sorts of allegations in speeches that have been made in this place today-is establish a standard where the privacy of an individual is not affected by that sort of process in Australia. That is all that the Government has sought to do. Under section 72 of the Constitution, a Federal judge may be dismissed by a petition of both Houses of the Parliament. I think there is no disagreement with the view that if the Parliament were to make a judgment about that issue, it would have to do so judicially. I refer to the opinion of the Solicitor-General on that matter. He made the point, which is made, of course, in Quick and Garran and other authorities on the Constitution, that:
. . . the duty of Parliament is practically indistinguishable from a strictly judicial duty.

TALK.START.PARA: —He said that, did he?
—I am putting that as an authority of Quick and Garran and the Solicitor-General.
—Oh, are you?

—Yes, I am. No doubt the honourable senator will cite his own authorities, and they are likely to be him. But if one accepts that view, in any judicial proceeding the sort of material which is sought and has been sought in question after question in the course of the last seven days is not material upon which any judge or magistrate would act.
—Why not?

—Because it would not be admissible in evidence. Perhaps the honourable senator will give us a legal opinion about that at a later stage. Before any proceeding which requires a judicial act comes before a court for consideration, there has to be a prima facie case made out which is investigated in normal proceedings by a committal. I refer the Senate to the statement of 17 February by the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) and the Attorney-General. In the last paragraph of that statement this point is made:

SPEECH.PARA: Both the police report and Mr Temby's opinion make it clear that there is no basis upon which any further police or Special Prosecutor investigation of the alleged behaviour of the judge, as revealed by the tapes and transcripts, could be justified.

On the basis of that, of course, it is open to Senator Missen and others to attack the character of somebody who gave that opinion, or to attack the police, the Solicitor-General or anybody else because it is alleged that those opinions are substituted for the opinions of Parliament. The point I simply make is that before that sort of material is admissible, it ought to be examined, as it has been. I do not know who else it would be suggested, from the Opposition side, should have examined that material other than the people whom the Attorney- General asked to examine it. So the point I make is that it is our view that the Parliament has a duty in this matter, both in respect of the preservation of privacy of individuals in relation to the source of the material which Parliament may wish to deal with and certainly in the way that that material is handled, in order that the preservation of civil liberties may be observed by this Parliament. It is quite extraordinary to find somebody like Senator Durack, the shadow Attorney-General, referring to material which may or may not be authenticated. We would argue that the Parliament, conscious of separation of power issues, should be very careful before it interferes in any judicial office . That sort of attitude is not being displayed by the Opposition.

I said something earlier about the question of motives in relation to this matter. I suppose they were best revealed by Senator Baume when he referred to the New South Wales election which is to take place shortly-a quite extraordinary reference to make in a speech which was allegedly devoted to the behaviour of the Attorney-General and the conduct of a Federal judge. That admission has been made again and again by Opposition speakers in the same sort of way in which Senator Baume made it; a concern to influence events in New South Wales being the prime concern and a concern which is detrimental, of course, to the civil liberties of the judge in question. So the sound and fury has all the flavour of an election stunt. It has all the flavour of this Opposition. It has been handled badly from the beginning. The Opposition has given no indication day by day of its intentions, what it is seeking in terms of information or what it is seeking to establish.

TALK.START.PARA: —Smearing!

—The Opposition has made smear after smear by way of question and innuendo in respect of information which on its own admission it had. It is extraordinary that an Opposition with that information seeks to raise this issue again and again in this Parliament. There can be no other explanation for it than the one given by Senator Baume. Piety in respect of this matter rings very hollow. I suppose the Opposition will pursue this matter in various ways, as it has pursued other issues with the same effectiveness. That does not alarm the Government at all. I said earlier today, and I repeat it, that in relation to the Attorney-General's handling of this matter he may have aroused some passion and some ire but that is not a charge justifying a censure motion.
—I agree with that.
—Senator Chaney certainly has had his ire roused at various times .
—I agree with that.

—I am happy to say that Senator Chaney agrees with me. He has indicated that he should not have got embittered or angered by the Attorney- General; he should have restrained his passions as Senator Baume earlier in this debate was quite incapable of doing. That is not the basis of a censure motion against an Attorney. Nor is the failure to provide information, having regard to the history of this matter, a basis for a censure motion against an Attorney. Samuel Beckett once wrote a great play called Krapps Last Tape. I might invert the title of that play for the benefit of the Opposition. That is what the dealings in Parliament in the last seven days have been like.
—Don't you recall the matters of public importance on the Alice Springs railway and also on the resources rental tax?
—I do recall those matters. That is an amazing achievement for the Opposition. I congratulate Senator Durack on it. I am very surprised--
—I am not surprised that you have no fire, no enthusiasm. I am not surprised at all. There is none there.
—Senator Walters is a wheelbarrow full of surprises. I am not surprised that she is not surprised. That has nothing to do with the topic of this discussion.
—It is an impassioned defence of the Attorney.

—I do not want to make an impassioned defence of the Attorney. All the passions have raged on the Opposition side. Of course, the result is a tale full of sound and fury which at this stage signifies nothing. The passions will go on but they will get dimmer as time goes by because there is really no substance in the Opposition's case. I do not want to make passionate speeches for the Attorney. I appeal to the Opposition to see where this Parliament is going. This is an Opposition which relies on unsubstantiated material illegally obtained which invades the privacy of individuals. This is an Opposition which relies on all those things to embark on fishing expeditions in respect of information which it already has. That is a classic abuse of the processes of this Parliament. It is a classic abuse of the processes of the Senate. It is a classic abuse of the censure procedure against a Minister in a government. That is what the Opposition has done continually. As I said, I am not here to provide impassioned defences of anybody. All the passion has been on the other side. That passion has concealed a great deal of absence of fact and argument. The debate has very largely been passion, some of which I suppose has been engendered by the Attorney-General's responses to questions which have not been comforting to the Opposition. I understand that. That is what has happened here over the last week. It is a very sad situation for the Parliament that we have an Opposition which is not only inept generally in conducting its business but which has proved its ineptitude in its conduct of this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —This censure motion against the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) concerns his handling of the tapes which were published by the Age newspaper, the contents of which are now widely known. Those tapes and transcripts concern some 3,000 conversations, some 524 pages and some dozen or so tapes. They concern illicit drugs, prostitution, the rigging of race meetings, the alleged bribery of magistrates and the judiciary and the alleged bribery of public servants. They make allegations against a judge named on the tapes. In spite of these facts the Government says that the Opposition, day by day, is smearing. I think it is important to put this matter in perspective.

SPEECH.PARA: These tapes appear against the background of five royal commissions-the Moffitt Royal Commission on Alleged Organised Crime in Registered Clubs in New South Wales, the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking, the Woodward Royal Commission into Drug Trafficking and the Williams Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs. All of these commissions have said that there is corruption in Australia of a massive and organised kind and that crime is inbuilt into the community, reaching right throughout the community. They have stated that crime reaches into the political and judicial spheres. I think that nobody says that Moffitt, Costigan, Stewart, Woodward and Williams are smearing. I wonder why? The Government has not said that a number of people who are mentioned on the tapes are also mentioned many times through the reports of those five royal commissions. For example, it is alleged the tapes concern the man Trimbole who is wanted, I understand, for the Griffith murder. His name is contained in those reports. Is that a smear? Is it a smear to say that these names are on the tapes even though the tapes are unauthenticated and not properly verified? Is it a smear to say that these names should be taken seriously? Is it a smear that the New South Wales Solicitor- General, Mary Gaudron, says that the tapes contain some serious matters that should be investigated?

What a strange thing it is that the Government can say only that we are smearing when in fact it knew that in regard to a major part of those tapes it had no recourse but to refer the matters to a special prosecutor and to the Stewart Royal Commission. If indeed the substance of those tapes is such that they should be studied by a royal commission-unauthenticated as they are-why should not they be studied by an inquiry and by this Parliament? The fascinating aspect of the situation is that the Attorney-General, in deciding these things, hived the tapes and the transcripts off into two quite separate sections. Those aspects that related to matters other than the judge have gone in their proper process to royal commissions and inquiries for proper investigaion. Well they may. Nobody in the Government would say that the great body of those matters-I think the Attorney-General said 2,980 conversations-are smears and because they are unauthenticated should be disregarded. On the contrary. Is the Government going to disregard all references in the tapes to Trimbole? If it is willing to take them seriously, should it not take seriously every other page of transcript and every other situation? No, the Government does not do that at all. It decides to have selective investigation. It has said that there shall be only one type of investigation of the judge and that shall by be a special investigator appointed by the Attorney-General, namely, the Attorney-General himself.

In the year that the Attorney-General has been in office he has gone from crisis to crisis. He has always been in turmoil. His only recourse here simply is to hurl words of abuse across the chamber. He has been in a state of panic and calamity the whole time. The Press has drawn attention to this matter. The Attorney-General-the person who should be aloof, who should be quite apart from investigations and who, in the end, should be the person objectively judging matters free of politics-chose to be the only investigator. Fundamentally this censure motion is on this key point that the Attorney said that he would be the only person to do so. There would be no investigation by the Solicitor-General, the head of his Department or a special investigator. He was to be the person who would decide what questions would be asked of the judge and what questions would not be asked of the judge, and who would decide what the Parliament should be told on this matter. That is the crux of this matter. Is that smearing?

The Attorney-General and two Queen's Counsel have said that the responsibility for judging the conduct of a judge lies with this Parliament. It does not lie with the numbers in the Labor Caucus. It is not good enough for the Attorney- General to tell us that the lower House has not acted to do something because that is simply a numbers game. The responsibility of the Attorney-General is to be free of the numbers game, to be quite separate from that, and to recognise, to use the words that the Attorney used today, that Parliament has the decisive constitutional role to decide and adjudicate on the conduct of a judge. Nobody else has that role. There is no justiciable situation outside; it is for the Parliament. Therefore the Attorney-General has the absolute responsibility to come into this place and give us the information on which we are to base our decision.

However, he put himself in what I believe is an intolerable situation, a situation which raises the very question of his future tenancy of his office, because when the Attorney went to see the judge he made subjective judgments as to what he should and should not ask the judge and how he should respond. He went to the judge having heard the tapes, having heard the alleged voice of the judge in conversation on the tapes. Knowing the judge, as he must as Attorney- General, he would therefore be able to make a value judgment as to whether it was the judge's voice or not. Why did he put himself in this situation? Why would anyone do that? He went there having decided to ask about certain things. The Opposition has questioned the Attorney-General about whether he asked the obvious question of the judge, namely: 'Is that your voice on the tapes?' This is the key test.

If the senior law officer of Australia were to go to a judge and investigate on behalf of the community of Australia whether or not a judge had had a series of conversations, would not the main question be: Is that your voice on the tapes? The Attorney has not replied to us on that. That raises a very interesting situation. Out of it has come a number of things. He says the tapes create a prima facie plausibility. That is very interesting. The Attorney says that real difficulties may be encountered with the transcripts because there are no tapes to back them up, but there is a prima facie plausibility on the tapes. It is not suggested that a conversation of some kind did not occur between the judge and the solicitor. Indeed, there is virtually an admission that that happened. However, the question lies with the interpretation of the matter. The Attorney- General does not say to us, 'This is what I asked and this is the response I got ', so that the only places that have the responsibility and obligation to evaluate this matter-the Senate and the House of Representatives-can do so. On the contrary, the Attorney says that he will be the sole investigator.

The Attorney relies and falls back on two opinions; the opinions of the Solicitor-General and of Mr Temby, QC. I will rely on the opinion of Mr Temby, QC. Maybe he was a Labor candidate, but let me rely on his opinion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Charming! Keep it up.
—I have been invited to do so. Mr Temby in his opinion poses the question:

SPEECH.PARA: Has (the Judge) acted injudiciously?
He goes on:
On the material I have seen his conduct cannot be so categorised, unless it be established that he well knew that a man with whom he was having frequent dealings was of poor reputation.

We know the test of whether a judge acts injudiciously. On Mr Temby's say so he acts injudiciously if it can be established that he well knew that a man with whom he was having frequent dealings was of poor reputation. Did the Attorney- General say: 'I tried to find out from the judge whether that is so or they are the facts of the matter'? It is alleged that the solicitor was a man of known poor reputation. I will read what Mr Temby went on to say because I have been invited to do so. He said:
It places a Judge in an invidious position if he has frequent dealings with any person of poor reputation.

Has it been determined by the Attorney-General whether the judge had frequent dealings with a person of poor reputation? Mr Temby then went on to say something else. Honourable senators should not put any qualifications on it because Mr Temby did not. He continued:

Presumably (the judge) now realises this and will act more carefully in the future than he has done in the past. If there is doubt in this regard, it may be that he should be approached and advised as to the desirability of not further nurturing the relationship he has with (the Solicitor) if it presently remains on foot.
Here is quite a clear case.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have left out two lines at the bottom of page 6.
—I am perfectly happy to read the lines again because this is fundamental to the situation. Mr Temby asks:

SPEECH.PARA: Has (the Judge) acted injudiciously?
He goes on:
On the material I have seen his conduct cannot be so categorised, unless it be established that he well knew that a man with whom he was having frequent dealings was of poor reputation.
I pause there and ask: Did the Attorney-General test this? Did he ask: Do you know that this solicitor has allegedly been convicted in the courts and is of poor reputation? Mr Temby goes on:
(Judges) occupy lofty and rather isolated positions, and it may be that (the Judge) did not know in any detail what (the Solicitor's) reputation was.

I presume that the Attorney-General would establish with us that the judge in question had only a very passing acquaintanceship with the solicitor; that he has no long established acquaintanceship at all. Mr Temby continued:

Even if he did, there is room for debate as between persons of good sense and goodwill as to whether any people, including those who hold high office, should be traduced by reason of the reputation of their friends and acquaintances, in the absence of actual and established improper conduct on their part.

Mr Temby put the test and the Attorney-General fails completely because he did not seek to do these kinds of things. In a series of tapes it is alleged that the judge in question sought politically and publicly to denigrate the character of a person and the judge gratuitously allegedly put forward ideas about denigrating and damaging a local alderman by vouchsafing the information that he was a homosexual who frequented gay bars and therefore his reputation could be damaged. Is this the conduct of a judge? Is this the conduct of a man? Do the tapes suggest that this was a casual conversation between a judge and a solicitor? Is this the sort of conversation that one would have occasionally with a solicitor? The conversations suggest that he approached a very senior Minister in the Wran Government to fix a job for a person. Where is the separation of powers between the judiciary, the Parliament and the Executive if this is so?

We come back to the test that was put to us. The tapes that deal with drugs, prostitution, race rigging, bribery and the fixing of the judiciary are not traduced and are not said to be rubbish. It is important that they should be the subject of investigation by the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking and other royal commissions. Yet the rest of the tapes go to the Attorney-General who decides that he will be the sole investigator, the sole person who is judge and jury? He cannot see that that put him in the position of subjective compromise and that he has now done great damage to the office of Attorney-General. He cannot see that the questions are being asked and will continue to be asked. Did he know this judge personally? Was there a long association with this judge? Had there been a close association? Had there been in the past or now any conflict of interests? He cannot see this. Because he cannot see this, he deserves to be censured.

Any man who excercised such bad judgment as the Attorney exercised during the Tasmanian dam incident, using the streaker's defence which he did, and any man who came into this chamber today and said that he stood for common decency, human rights and due process and yet was responsible for the Moscow-style trial of David Combe is not fit to hold the office of Attorney-General. Nobody could have done more to harm human rights and human liberty than to force a man to agree to a statement under duress, as was the case with Mr Combe. We have the strange situation that, in the view of the Attorney-General and of Mr Temby, private conversations on the telephone are not to be taken seriously. They are not to be taken legally at all; they should be disregarded. Yet Mr Combe was scarred for life on exactly that basis. This Attorney-General, who supposedly values human liberty, did not see that the right thing for the Government to do was to set up an inquiry into Combe's actions. He had to be dragged screaming before a royal commission and was condemned by his own people in that affair.

The reason for the censure motion today is to make the point that if an Attorney-General is to serve his office well he must be a man of intellectual capacity, capable of being objective and standing aloof from the numbers game. I put the test very seriously to him:

He said that 2,980 pages of the transcript can go before a royal commission because they are about drugs, prostitution and race rigging. He said that we cannot condemn them because they contain the names of people whom the Stewart Royal Commission, the Woodward Royal Commission into Drug Trafficking, the Williams Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs and the Moffitt Royal Commission on Alleged Organised Crime in Registered Clubs in New South Wales know very well to be bad people. They are not scuttle-butt, to use the words of the Attorney. We must take them seriously. Yet with the other tapes concerning the judge we are in an entirely different situation. The Labor Party knows that it has the numbers in the lower House. It knows that it can get a quick trick given the numbers of the Democrats in the Senate. Yet an Attorney-General should be above that. He should be above the numbers game. His job is to carry out his responsibility. As he said today, Parliament plays the decisive constitutional role in regard to the removal of a judge on the grounds of his conduct. Yet he has absolutely refused to allow a full and frank discussion on this matter. He has gone on in the way he did with Mr Combe until inevitably Combe's name was exposed, because the Government dragged him behind closed doors and sought to put up a phoney explanation that they were distancing themselves from lobbyists.
Government senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—Let them shout. These are the human liberties people. What has the Government done in this situation? It has done exactly the same thing. It has not set up a decent inquiry. A judicial inquiry is right for 2,980 pages, but an inquiry regarding the other tapes is wrong. What an extraordinary piece of selective thinking. Why did the Attorney-General ever get into the situation of choosing himself as the investigator? Why did he when it was quite clear that he would compromise himself and his office and when he knew that the responsibility in the end lay with Parliament? What kind of arrogance is that? What kind of disregard for democracy is it for a man to say: 'I will come into this chamber. I will tell you what I will let you know and no more. I will answer questions if it suits me to do so, and no more. I will not let you know anything else.' He says that Parliament should not call for the information on this matter; Parliament should leave it to him. He says: 'I applied the test of Mr Temby because this matter rests upon him. Mr Temby said that a judge can be said to have acted injudiciously if it can be established that he well knew that a man with whom he was having frequent dealings was of poor reputation'. Mr Temby went on to say that we had better tell this judge that he ought not to deal any further with this man of poor reputation. Mr Temby assumed the validity and authenticity of the material. The Attorney has indicated to us that it would be wrong to assume that the tapes in question did not contain some authenticity. What an astonishing situation! The Attorney says: 'You say that I am withholding information from you. You say that I should be censured for persistent refusal to provide information'. But let us ask the Attorney-General whether he asked the judge in question whether he had had frequent dealings with the man he had been talking to on the telephone. Did the judge have frequent dealings with this man? Was that so? That piece of information has been withheld, has it not? Did the Attorney ask the judge whether he knew that this solicitor was of poor reputation, as Mr Temby indicated?
—Yes, I did.

—If he did ask those questions and if the answer was that the judge did have frequent dealings with this solicitor-it is no good Senator Evans trying to whisper to me. The way to tell these things is not by whisper now; it is to tell them while one is on one's feet during Question Time.
—Are you in possession of the material? Has the Opposition got the material or part of it?
—If the Attorney-General is asking me whether I have seen the tapes-
—I am asking you: Has the Opposition got the tapes?
—I have never seen them.
—Order!
—I am not asking you that: I am asking you whether the Opposition has them.
—Order! Senator Evans!
—Answer me, you fraud, you windbag! You are a fraud, a windbag and a hyprocrite.
— Order!
—I think that those who are listening to this debate ought to understand that was the Attorney-General speaking.
—Order! There are too many interjections. I suggest to Senator Sir John Carrick that he not answer the interjections and that he speak through the Chair.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I am delighted to do so. The President has asked the Attorney-General in the past not to intervene when other honourable senators were speaking, because the Attorney was heard in silence. I invite those who are listening to understand that these are the general tactics of the Attorney-General. He stands censured today because all he can do is to hurl abuse. All he can do with his intellectual snobbery and arrogance is try to talk down the Opposition and to tamper with the very framework of democracy. I was asked whether I am aware of or did I see the tapes or the transcripts. I can answer without qualification that I have not done so. I have simply read what is in the Press. Indeed, I do not ask to see the transcripts of those things that go before the Moffitt Royal Commission or others, because what the Attorney has failed to say-
—The Moffitt Royal Commission was about you.

—Let Senator Grimes shout. After all, he is the Minister for mistakes. Senator Grimes, who now shouts, is the Minister of whom the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said: 'We have made a mistake'. It was not the Senate stopping him-intellectually the idea was wrong. The whole tenor of the Government's argument has been that we have raised a smear. That was said by the Attorney-General about the Rex Jackson tapes in October-November, when the Attorney-General did the same kind of thing. For days and days he said that there was nothing in them and that he would not read them. He was reluctant. Yet he knows now that those were taped conversations of a person trying to rig three people to be drug distributors for a major drug importer.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I will hear silence before I call Senator Sir John Carrick .

—No wonder those opposite raise their voices! The fact is that what was reluctantly forced out of the Attorney-General in October- November ended up in the resignation of a Minister in New South Wales, Rex Jackson. Is this whole thing a smear? Is it wrong? Did we smear Rex Jackson? Did the Commonwealth Government of the time, the Fraser Government, smear when it gave information which would not have been acted on otherwise and which proved that a senior police officer, Superintendent Allen, who had been favoured by the brilliant Mr Wran, needed to resign from the force? Was the Four Corners royal commission, the Street Royal Commission, a smear? It ended up with a judge saying that a man had to be committed for trial and that there had been a breach of judicial practice. One man was convicted and another man was committed for trial. Are these smears? Is not the situation that five royal commissions have shown the most ghastly wave of crime and corruption through the whole fabric of the Australian community, which commissions got their evidence in identical fashion-not authenticated and not tested? Is it not also a fact that evidence obtained illegally in Australia is not inadmissable as evidence but has to be proven? That is very important. To suggest that because something is obtained illegally it cannot be acted upon judicially is nonsense.
—That is what Senator Button was trying to say.

—That is what they are all trying to say. They are trying to say that it is a smear, but five or six royal commissions have proved them wrong. They are trying to say that we cannot deal with things that are not authenticated. Yet they gave evidence to the Stewart Royal Commission. They are trying to say that Mr Temby supports them. I come back to this situation: The Attorney-General stands condemned. He was the lone investigator and for his own political motives, whatever they are, he did not pass the test.
—You contemptible person.
—Order! The Attorney-General will withdraw that remark.
—I withdraw.

—Every time the Attorney-General does this, he reinforces the importance of the censure. If one pressed these matters, I think it would be found that there might well be a case to be answered, that a judge might well have known that a man with whom he was having frequent dealings was of poor reputation. If that is the test of Mr Temby, the only place it can be tested is in this Parliament. The Attorney-General has said that the place to test this is the Parliament, but, of course, he is not going to do that until after 25 March, as he said, because of action he has taken. In fact he stands condemned because his actions are political and they are not the ordinary behaviour of an Attorney-General.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the following censure motion moved by the Leader of the Opposition ( Senator Chaney):

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate censures the Attorney-General for his handling of the Age tapes , and in particular his persistent refusal to provide information to the Parliament in order that it might properly perform its role in matters relating to the Judiciary.

I have been in this place in the past when we have debated censure motions. They have been occasions of high drama. They have been occasions of very serious import. They have been occasions when most honourable senators on both sides have been present to hear the debate, because it is a serious motion and, as a result, a serious debate. That is not what has happened this afternoon. If the Government can be excused for not getting too enthusiastic about this debate, it is because of the absence of enthusiasm from all speakers opposite with the exception of the last, Senator Sir John Carrick, with no one listening to the debate. I suppose that the last speaker, as he has done in the past, demonstrated what this motion is all about. His last words, when he brought up the importance of this to the New South Wales election, really demonstrated to us what it was all about. He also demonstrated the sorts of tactics he was only too willing to use when he was Leader of the Government in the Senate and now uses as an Opposition backbencher, tactics which some of his colleagues do not always use.

Let me give a couple of examples of what he did this afternoon. In mentioning Mr Temby, a gentleman of impeccable legal qualifications who was recognised by his peers by being elected president of an Australian legal association, Senator Sir John Carrick, in a snide remark, said: 'I will not mention the fact that he was a Labor candidate'. Why would Senator Sir John Carrick bring up that snide remark other than to try to blacken Mr Temby's name indirectly? He also said in this place that the judge should have known that the solicitor with whom he was dealing in 1979 and 1980, according to these alleged tape conversations, had been convicted in the courts when that conviction in fact occurred after those conversations. How on earth could the judge have known that at the time? Senator Sir John Carrick often does this. He often uses these tactics. When someone on this side decides to respond to those tactics in kind, Senator Sir John Carrick generally gets very upset. I do not want to see him upset.
Let me take up a couple of his other points. Senator Sir John Carrick should read Alfred McCoy's book Drug Trafficking in Australia in which Dr McCoy says:
During the 11 years from 1965 to 1976, with the Liberal-Country Parites in power, the State-
that is, New South Wales--
endured a period of political and police corruption unparalleled in modern history.

Senator Sir John Carrick mentioned the Moffitt Royal Commission on Alleged Organised Crime in Registered Clubs in New South Wales. The Moffitt Royal Commission exposed penetration of licensed clubs by organised crime in New South Wales during the period of the former Liberal-Country Party Government. It mentioned the flourishing of elaborate illegal casinos. It mentioned the domination of SP bookmaking by organised crime. During that time there was a Liberal-Country Party Government. The Premier of that State was Sir Robin Askin. We have seen the articles about him, which have never been denied. A senior official of the New South Wales Liberal Party at that time was Senator Sir John Carrick, the honest man who sanctimoniously says: 'I knew nothing about all that corruption. I was a friend of the Premier. I was the State Secretary in New South Wales'. There is endless evidence of what was happening in New South Wales at that time, and this gentleman, a knight of the realm, casts aspersions on people in this place and on judges on no evidence at all.

I am an ex-citizen of New South Wales. I know people in New South Wales. I know what happened in New South Wales when no one could get into business or do anything without the kick-backs. Senator Sir John Carrick was the Secretary of the Party, and he says: 'I knew nothing about it. I was pure. I sat up there in Ash Street. I wrote the minutes and I did the books. But I knew nothing about what was going on'. He will never get up in this place and deny that anything was going on. This is the person who speaks in the way in which he did about the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) when the Attorney-General has spent the last seven or eight days in this place answering endless questions and taking part in debates upon matters of public importance.

About three-quarters of our time has been spent on what? We should look at what we have been debating. Allegedly, a series of telephone conversations were intercepted, recorded and transcribed by a person or persons unknown, a manifestly illegal act and a gross invasion of privacy. The tapes were made available to the Age, and the Age printed transcripts. But the tapes were first rejected by the Sydney Morning Herald, which would not have a bar of them because they could not be authenticated, and the transcripts certainly could not be authenticated. The Age could not even get it right. In printed alleged transcripts of the tapes which had the judge saying one thing and the solicitor saying another, which reflected badly on the judge, but when the tapes were heard by other people, including members of the Opposition, it was found that it was not in fact the judge who was speaking the words attributed to him but the solicitor. Since then we have had rumour; we have had innuendo; and we have had disgraceful behaviour by members of the Liberal Party and the National Party, not only in this place but in the Queensland Parliament. This culminated last night in the naming, under privilege in the Queensland Parliament, after a spurious question, of the people who were allegedly taped in these circumstances . The tapes have not been authenticated. The transcripts have not been authenticated.

We had a debate in this place two days ago in which the Opposition, the Liberal Party, had the opportunity to vote for a motion for the production of the tapes and these transcripts. With the exception of Senator Lewis, who, I understand, would not take part in such hypocrisy, the Liberals voted against it. Today Senator Durack comes into this chamber and says that he wants a select committee to investigate the whole affair. This afternoon, after Question Time, and without warning, a motion for the suspension of Standing Orders was moved, which of course the Government took up. Since soon after 3 o'clock this afternoon-and if the recent additions to the speakers list are any indication, we shall be continuing on the same subject tomorrow morning-we have been listening to this debate and waiting for something new to happen, waiting for some decent arguments to be put forward. All that we have heard is Senator Peter Baume, the first one, admitting that what the Opposition is about is the New South Wales election. Then we heard the tirade from the knight of the realm opposite who comes in here and casts aspersions on anyone who dares to get up. I dare say that when it is all over, he will be indignant and will say what terrible people Grimes and others who follow are for daring to question his past activities when he does what he has done today and what he has done so often in the past in this place, which is to blackguard people, individually and collectively, and then to squeal like a stuck pig when someone responds. Of course we will respond to that sort of nonsense. Why should any honourable senator put up with such hypocrisy from someone who for so long was the secretary of a Party which was known to be corrupt by everyone in Australia? Why should we put up with such hypocrisy, such handwringing, such nonsense, as we put up with from Senator Sir John Carrick? He cries and he bleats every time it happens. I hope that he cries and bleats now.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is only Balmain boys who do that.

—Balmain boys do not cry. When I was at school in New South Wales , most North Sydney Tech boys did not cry, either. Senator Sir John Carrick is the first one I have met who has cried. No wonder they do not want anything to do with him. Tell us, Senator Sir John Carrick, about the days in Ash Street. Tell us about your activities.
—They have moved to George Street now.
—They have moved because there are too many ghosts in the old building, too many skeletons in the cupboards and too many ghosts and the place was not fit to inhabit. What did Senator Evans do?
—Just give us one word in favour of him.
—Senator Archer, you replaced an honourable man in this place. You replaced him by donating a house to the Liberal Party in Burnie to use as its headquarters. Deny it.
—I raise a point of order.
—Order! Senator Grimes, it is not in order to impute improper motives or behaviour to members except by motion.
—Mr Deputy President, I stated a fact.
—It does not matter whether it is a fact or not. That remark should be withdrawn.
—It is a fact, but I will withdraw it.
—I take a point of order, Mr Deputy President. Senator Grimes is not speaking in any way to the motion-
—Were any on your side?

—One can put up with the noise of the empty trumpets. Mr Deputy President, what Senator Grimes has been doing, in wasting time here now, probably to play out time until 7 o'clock, is making an attack upon my colleague Senator Sir John Carrick which, of course, is not relevant to the censure motion . The censure motion is not related to Senator Sir John Carrick or Senator Archer but to the Attorney-General. Senator Grimes is avoiding the subject. I suggest, Mr Deputy President, that you bring him into line and make him address the subject before the Chair.
—Senator Grimes is in order. He was, in my view, commenting upon remarks by Senator Sir John Carrick. However, I ask him now to return to the motion before the Chair.

—Good idea, Mr Deputy President. Let us talk about Senator Evans and what he has done. I repeat that what we have is a series of unauthenticated tapes and unauthenticated alleged transcripts of tapes. When this matter was raised, Senator Evans treated it with care and seriousness. Senator Peter Baume, I think, said this afternoon that Senator Evans's responsibility as the first law officer of this land is to the Parliament and the people of this country. That is right. It is also his responsibility to see that justice is done wherever possible, and he has a responsibility to individuals in this country. It is not an easy job. Senator Archer is interjecting. It is certainly a job beyond the capacity of Senator Archer. What did the Attorney-General do? He sought and received copies of the alleged tapes and the transcripts. He appointed to investigate the situation a man of impeccable reputation, a man who was smeared indirectly this afternoon by Senator Sir John Carrick, that honourable man, and by Senator Peter Baume. It was suggested indirectly that this man's political affiliations had something to do with his appointment. We have received a report that has been grievously misquoted this afternoon by Senator Sir John Carrick, that honourable man.

SPEECH.PARA: The Attorney-General appointed a man of impeccable reputation to investigate the next little affair that arose, an affair of which he was aware, because it was mentioned in the tapes and it was later raised in this Parliament-the Sala affair. The Attorney-General appointed a man of impeccable reputation to investigate that, and that man has reported on the matter. At all times in this place the Attorney-General has striven to protect the rights and privacy and to deal with natural justice with those people, including the judge, who were named in the tapes and whose names have been bandied around this country ever since the tape transcripts appeared in the Age. He has done so under considerable pressure in this place from members of the Opposition, who are unwilling to name people themselves but willing to list plenty of people by inference, and who are unwilling to come forward with any facts although they have the tapes and transcripts in their possession. He has at all times answered in as much detail as he could, protecting the rights and privacy of the people involved. He has done so with openness and while under considerable stress in debate and in Question Time. He has acted with honour, he has acted well and he has treated honourably the position-

TALK.START.PARA: —And with great loyalty.

—That was a charming interjection. I said that to ensure that it will be recorded in Hansard. It was a charming interjection. It was typical of the honourable senator. Senator Evans has done that consistently for six or seven days since the beginning of this parliamentary session, with all the nit- picking, all the inferences and all the nasty interjections from those opposite. Members of the Opposition failed to get a motion through this place to have those tapes-as they said, with the names crossed off-exposed to the light of day in this place. They failed to do so because they would not vote for the motion themselves. This morning they gave notice, through the shadow Attorney-General, of a motion which they were going to debate tomorrow, but they decided that they were getting too much of a caning in the Press for not putting up or shutting up , so they have now come up with this censure motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Is it not bad enough that in this country we have people acting illegally, taping conversations in the way in which they have been? Is it not bad enough that those tapes, without any authentication, and transcripts of other alleged tapes, without any authentication, have been bandied around this country? Not only the Government but also the Opposition has copies. The Australian Democrats have copies. The so-called respectable Press such as the Age has copies. The Toorak Times has copies. The only two people who do not have a copy, apparently, are Senator Archer, who could not be trusted, and Senator Missen, who probably would be shocked. Is it not bad enough that we have that sort of situation without the Opposition trying to debase this place by having those things tabled so that they can be treated as privileged documents and bandied around even further?

Who are the people who are trying to do this? Who are the allies of the Opposition? We had last night in the Queensland Parliament the extraordinary situation of Mr Jennings, who was expelled from the Liberal Party in Victoria for treachery-he is an extraordinary character-and who then joined that political garbage dump, the Queensland National Party, putting up a dorothy dixer to no one other than Mr Lane. Mr Lane is a Minister in the Queensland Government who left the Liberal Party-he is a turncoat-to join the National Party. His greatest distinction as a member of the police force was to arrest a man and charge him with obscene language only to have the charge thrown out because the man was proven to be deaf and dumb. These two characters, under the privilege of the Queensland Parliament, named the people involved. In the Senate this afternoon Senator Chaney put forward as justification for the questions that were asked about the names and in justification for seeking the production of those tapes the fact that those names were produced last night in the Queensland Parliament by a couple of such unsavoury characters.

I might add that last night in the Queensland Parliament another member of the National Party, a friend of Senator Bjelke-Petersen, made the following charming remark: 'What the Federal Government should do is introduce the ministry for dogs, led by a bitch, Senator Susan Ryan'. These are the sorts of people with whom the Opposition is associated. These are the sorts of people who are saying in this place that Senator Evans is not doing his job properly because he will not indulge in the sort of much-raking exercises in which the Oppositon wants him to indulge.

Nothing would have been easier for Senator Evans, if he were an unscrupulous Attorney-General, than to let all this stuff out and to say: 'God, we cannot put up with all this stuff; we will have a royal commission or something like that'. Instead, he asked people whom even Senator Missen would recognise as respected legal people of high repute to give him an opinion on what had happened. He looked at the tapes and the transcripts and said, quite justifiably and quite reasonably, as Mary Gaudron said in New South Wales: 'We have to get these tapes . We do not know whether they are authentic. We do not know how fair dinkum they are. Let us find out. But even if they are authentic there is nothing on these tapes about the judge'-it seems to me that the judge is the only one about whom the Opposition is worried-'and we should respect the rights of that judge just as we should respect the rights of any ordinary citizen'.

As Senator Chipp said today, we have come to a great point in this country if people can illegally tap telephones and illegally intercept conversations and, having done so, produce them anonymously and distribute them around the country anonymously. Tapes can be spliced or altered if necessary. Bits of conversations can be put together selectively. That is possible. We have seen an example of how easy that is this afternoon with Senator Sir John Carrick's selective quoting of the Temby report. The material has been distributed in that way and we have no idea from where it has come. Not too many people in this place would like their personal conversations to be spread about the country in this way. This matter has been brought into this place under privilege and the Opposition has said: 'This is a terribly important matter. We should not worry about whether the tapes are fair dinkum, accurate or anything else. We should not worry about who took them or about who did the transcribing'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who says that?

—Senator Chaney says that. He says: 'We should bring them into this place and we should all sit around like a lot of voyeurs, have a good laugh and a good listen, and then castigate whoever happens to be recorded on the tapes.'

SPEECH.PARA: Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 6.58 p.m., under sessional order the debate is interrupted. I put the question:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the debate on the Sex Discrimination Bill in another place on Monday Mr Gerry Hand, who is the spokesman for the socialist Left faction in that place, made baseless accusations against me. Although the daily Hansard is not yet available, for reasons that would be known to you, Mr Deputy President, Mr Hand's tirade was carried by Australian Associated Press in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: Gerry Hand (Labour Victoria) criticised the Bill opponents . . .
Tasmanian independent Senator Brian Harradine had used 'outright lies' in his campaign against the Bill yet had not had the courage to actually vote on the Bills passage, he said.
Senator Harradine is without doubt the greatest exponent of the Goebbels' theory of distort, distort and distort and maybe the people will believe what you say,' said Mr Hand.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I take a point of order. I do not want to inhibit what Senator Harradine is saying. I realise the difficulty he is in as Hansard is not available. But I think he is in contravention of standing order 414, which says he is not allowed to quote, except from Hansard, any debate in the current session. I realise we have problems because an industrial dispute has resulted in Hansard not being available.
—Senator Harradine is making what is in effect a personal explanation.

—Mr Deputy President, if I may address you on the point of order, standing order 414 refers to debates in the Senate, not to debates in the House of Representatives. I think it is in order for Senator Harradine to proceed.
—Senator Harradine is in order. In any case he is making what is in effect a personal explanation.
—I had hoped to make this personal explanation after Question Time. The report continues:

SPEECH.PARA: I put it to you that Senator Harradine is an opportunist of the lowest or greatest type.

The Australian and the Canberra Times carried part of the AAP report. My record over 25 years in the anti-discrimination struggle is well known both inside and outside the trade union movement, but apparently not by Mr Hand. Instead, Mr Hand, from under the cloak of parliamentary privilege, used the tactic of character assassination. Mr Hand could not give one example of anything that I have said about the Bill which was untrue. Honourable senators will recall that my main concern with the Bill was to have it amended in a manner necessary for me to honour my commitment to both cherished family values and anti- discrimination measures.

Because of the arguments I and others advanced, the Bill was substantially amended. Mr Hand's statement that I did not have the courage actually to vote on the Bill's passage was dishonest and followed a similar statement by the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, Senator Ryan, on 16 December. I will not go into that at this stage. I remind honourable senators that on that day I participated in 38 of the 39 votes taken on the Bill. I refused to participate in the last vote of the day in protest against the gag and because the Bill equates a de facto relationship with marriage and fails to protect the individual's genuinely held, informed, conscientious belief.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance has provided the following supplementary information with respect to Senator Messner's question upon notice, on 16 December 1983, concerning Division 312 of Appropriation Act (No. 1) 1983-84:

ANSWER.PARA: Since answering the honourable senator's question on Division 312 of Appropriation Act (No. 1) 1983-84 (Hansard, of 28 February 1984, page 98), a determination pursuant to that division was made on 16 February 1984 in the sum of $38,270,500. A direction was also made on the same date allocating that sum to relevant departmental and agency heads of expenditure. Particulars of the determination are to be submitted to the Parliament pursuant to the terms of Division 312.
